Objectives

After studying this chapter, you should be able to

  • 1 A Describe investing and distinguish investing from saving, speculating, and gambling
  • 1 B Explain the differences between retail investors and institutional investors
  • 1 C Identify the types of insurance products supported by general account and separate account assets and describe the movement of funds in and out of general and separate accounts
  • 1 D List the professional roles found in the investment function of financial services companies and describe each role’s general responsibilities
  • 1 E Differentiate between a financial services company’s front-office, middle-office, and back-office investment operations
  • 1 F Identify and describe specific insurance company functions that interact with the investment function
  • 1 G Explain why financial services companies may outsource investment management duties to external vendors
  • 1 H Describe the sources and uses of investment data and how investment professionals manage and analyze data
  • 1 I Describe important elements in data governance and information security for financial services companies

Many companies in the financial services industry—such as asset management companies and insurance companies—engage in investment activities while conducting business. Each company has different reasons for investing and different practices for managing investments. Successful investments enable a company to be more effective in offering financial services to customers. Therefore, all employees of financial services companies can benefit from understanding the role that investments play in their company’s financial well-being.

Many people are uncomfortable with investing topics. Investing has a reputation for being complex, mysterious, even scary. For people who want to understand more about investing, learning about the investment process can be intimidating. The terminology can be confusing, and the sheer number of investment types and strategies can seem overwhelming.

This textbook simplifies fundamental investing concepts and describes the process that financial services companies use to make investment decisions. Along the way, you will discover how investments support the products that life insurance companies offer and how effective investment management is part of an insurer’s comprehensive risk management strategy.

This chapter introduces you to the basics of investing. You will learn about (1) the difference between investing and speculating, (2) the main types of investors, and (3) sources of insurers’ investment funds. This chapter also provides an overview of an insurer’s investment function, including the work that investment professionals perform, the systems they use, and their interactions with other functions.

Subsequent chapters build on the foundation established in this chapter by providing more details about how the investment function operates within life insurance companies.

pages.title: What Is Investing?
pages.contents:
What Is Investing?

An investment is any use of an investor’s resources that is intended to generate a positive return of some kind. Examples of investable resources include time, energy, and money. For the purposes of this text, we focus on the investment of financial resources, known as capital. In the context of investing, capitalis a financial resource available to initiate an investment.

Investors strive to use capital productively to create additional value or wealth. For instance, companies invest capital now in projects that will grow their business in the future, and individuals invest capital now to have more money available later for spending.

EXAMPLE

Example 1: Camion Industrial Corporation, a company that manufactures building equipment, is not manufacturing equipment quickly enough to meet customer demand. To increase production capacity, Camion invests money in a project to build an additional manufacturing plant. Once complete, the plant will enable the company to supply more equipment to customers.

Example 2: Annabelle Boneca, an employee at Camion, regularly puts some of her monthly salary into a savings account intended to cover her anticipated living expenses during retirement. At her current savings rate, Annabelle estimates that her total savings will not grow fast enough to meet her retirement needs. So, she invests additional savings in the stock market with the expectation that these investments will provide her with extra money that she can use to reach her savings goal.

Investing typically involves conducting research and analysis to determine the fundamental value of an asset, which is an item of value that an entity owns. Assets can be tangible or intangible:

  • A tangible asset is an asset that has a physical form.

  • An intangible asset is an asset that represents ownership of a legal right or another nonphysical resource.

The following chart provides examples of tangible and intangible assets.

Tangible Assets

Intangible Assets

Cash

Securities

Real Estate

Patents

Automobiles

Copyrights

Collectibles

Computer Software

Commodities

Leases

Equipment and Machinery

Licenses

Based on research and analysis of multiple factors, an investor develops an estimation of an asset’s value. Keep in mind that value and price are not necessarily the same thing. To an investor, price is what you can buy or sell an asset for, while value is what you believe the asset is worth.

An investor believes that an asset’s price will eventually rise or fall over time to meet his interpretation of the asset’s value. Therefore, an investor’s assessment of an asset’s value influences the investor’s actions in the marketplace for that asset. For example, if an investor believes an asset is more valuable than the current price indicates, then the investor should consider purchasing the asset to benefit from the anticipated future increase in the asset’s price.

To understand what investing is, let’s consider what investing is not. First, investing is not the same as saving. A saver sets aside money to avoid spending it right now. In other words, a saver defers spending some of her money until a later point in time.

Typically, the amount of money a saver has increases when she contributes additional money to her savings. In addition, the saver can receive interest income if the money is held in an interest-earning account—such as a savings account, which pays interest on deposited funds, typically from the day of deposit to the day of withdrawal. If the savings are held elsewhere, such as in a personal safe or under a mattress, the saver does not earn interest.

In contrast, an investor takes capital and puts it to work by investing in assets. If an asset’s price rises above the investor’s purchase price, the investment has gained in value. Once an asset has been sold for a gain, the investor earns a return on investment, or a profit earned on invested capital during a defined time period. Furthermore, an investor may—depending on the type of investment—receive payments from an investment. Such payments, which you will learn more about in Chapter 2, represent income to the investor.

Investment gains and investment income both increase the amount of money the investor has. However, asset prices fluctuate, so investments can lose value; selling an asset for a loss causes the investor to lose money.

As investors can potentially lose their invested capital, investing is generally riskier than saving. To compensate investors for the increased level of risk, the potential rates of return on investments are generally higher than the interest rates on savings accounts.

Because of the potential for investment gains and income, an investor has the opportunity to increase his accumulation of funds faster than he would by saving. Therefore, we can sum up the main difference between saving and investing in the following statements:

  • A saver’s funds typically accumulate through a combination of (1) additional contributions to savings and (2) receipts of interest income (if the money is held in an interest-earning account, such as a savings account).

  • An investor’s funds typically accumulate through a combination of investment gains, investment income, and additional contributions of money.

Although an investor may engage in speculative or gambling activities, investing is not the same as speculating or gambling.

 

Investing or Speculating?

In a financial context, speculation is the practice of engaging in a financial transaction—particularly, a risky transaction—with the intent of benefiting from a short-term fluctuation in an asset’s price.

In general, investors consider a wider range of factors over a longer length of time than do speculators. Speculation does not require a careful examination of an asset’s current or projected value. Instead, speculators consider a limited set of factors, such as an asset’s current price and patterns of price changes. Speculators believe they can identify asset trends without having a comprehensive understanding of asset values.

EXAMPLE

Adam Cain is a commodities speculator. Adam notices that, every few years, corn prices spike in the United States. Looking closer, he sees that harsh weather preceded and adversely affected corn production in each year that the price spiked.

At the beginning of the year, Adam observes that the weather in the United States has been colder than the last few years. Remembering the pattern he noticed, Adam thinks that the weather will hurt corn production in the upcoming year. Knowing that a reduced supply would prompt a surge in corn prices, he purchases a contract for 15,000 bushels of corn that locks in the price of the bushels for six months.

Analysis: If the price of corn rises during the six-month period, the contract becomes more valuable and Adam can sell it to a corn buyer for a profit. Therefore, by purchasing the contract now, Adam is positioning himself to benefit if the price of corn increases.

Investors and speculators also differ in their approach to risk. Investors assess the risk associated with an investment and only accept the risk if the anticipated return is suitable for the level of risk assumed. In general, speculators are willing to take on larger risks in return for the chance of larger rewards. Speculators are also more likely to borrow money to make concentrated bets in the hope of amplifying returns.

Many investors are more conservative than speculators and limit exposure to unnecessary risks. In addition, some investors are subject to regulations that limit the types of investments that they can make. For example, regulators place investment restrictions on insurance companies. Because of regulations involving their use of capital, insurers generally are cautious investors that do not speculate.

Investors tend to hold investments longer than speculators and use different selection methodologies. Investors employ a deliberate, strategic process to carefully select investments to hold for a specific length of time. Speculators are opportunistic, hoping to take advantage of quick movements in an asset’s price. In their rush to exploit a brief window of time, speculators may base decisions on limited information.

 

Investing or Gambling?

Investing and speculating are different from gambling, which is the act of wagering something of value—such as money—on the outcome of an event involving chance. If a gambler’s bet is successful, he wins a prize. However, if his bet is unsuccessful, the gambler loses the item of value that he wagered.

Many gamblers bet on outcomes that have very low odds of success. For example, you are gambling whenever you buy a lottery ticket. Your ticket usually has unfavorable odds—such as a 1-in-300 million chance—of winning the drawing.

Some gamblers believe that by observing past outcomes, they are able to predict future outcomes of random events. However, in random events—such as coin flips or games of chance—outcomes occur independently, meaning a single outcome is not affected by previous outcomes and does not affect future outcomes. Thus, the gambler’s fallacy, also known as the Monte Carlo fallacy, is the mistaken belief that random events become less random—and more predictable—the more frequently certain outcomes are observed.

Why is the gambler’s fallacy also called the Monte Carlo fallacy?

A famous example of the gambler’s fallacy occurred on August 18, 1913, at the Monte Carlo Casino in Monaco. At one of the roulette tables, some gamblers noticed that the ball kept falling on black.

Even though each spin of the wheel had the same odds of the ball landing on red as earlier spins, the gamblers started to believe that the growing streak increased the odds that the next roll would end with the ball landing on red. As the streak of rolls landing on black continued, more gamblers got involved. With each roll, gamblers placed larger bets on the ball landing on red. However, the ball kept landing on black.

The ball finally landed on red after landing on black twenty-six times in a row. Because of the extremely unlikely occurrence of the streak, gamblers at the roulette table lost millions of francs betting against black.

Because the odds are against them, gamblers typically have to rely on luck to be successful over time. In contrast, speculators and investors apply their skills to increase the likelihood of experiencing favorable outcomes. Speculators who can skillfully spot short-term trends are more likely to capitalize on asset price fluctuations. Investors who can skillfully assess asset values are more likely to select long-term investments that earn positive returns.

Compared to speculators and investors, gamblers have the least amount of control in preventing the loss of committed capital. For a gambler, a bad bet wipes out all of the capital wagered on the bet. Speculators and investors can sell assets before they lose all of their committed capital.

pages.title: Types of Investors
pages.contents:
Types of Investors

All types of investors buy and sell assets, such as securities. Securities are financial assets that represent either (1) an obligation of indebtedness owed by a business, a government, or an agency—in which case the security is a debt security—or (2) an ownership interest in a business—in which case the security is an equity security. A collection of securities and other types of investments owned by the same person or organization is called an investment portfolio. An investor usually assembles an investment portfolio to meet a defined set of financial goals.

Investors vary according to their goals, size, skill, experience, and amount of capital. In general, the two main types of investors are retail investors and institutional investors.

 

Retail Investors

Retail investors, also called individual investors or small investors, are individual investors who buy and sell securities for their personal accounts.

Retail investors conduct investment activities on their own behalf using their own funds. Retail investors are considered “unsophisticated investors” because they usually do not have the skills or resources to conduct extensive investment research and analysis on their own. While some retail investors are organized and methodical, many do not have a clear plan or coordinated system that guides their investment activities.

Many retail investors do not have large amounts of capital to devote to investing. As a result, they usually make relatively small trades. Therefore, one retail investor is unlikely to significantly affect the market for a given security based on his individual involvement.

Because of a lack of knowledge and resources, many retail investors are not inclined to branch out into a variety of asset types. Instead, they concentrate their efforts on the types of investments that they are comfortable with and can manage on their own. They also may not have enough funds to participate in investments with financial barriers to entry, such as high minimum initial investments.

 

Institutional Investors

Institutional investors are organizations that hold financial assets and trade securities in large volume. Examples of institutional investors are insurance companies, mutual funds, endowment funds, private foundations, retirement plans, and pension funds.

Institutional investors conduct investment activities on behalf of companies or groups of client accounts. For example, a pension fund invests to support payments made to its pensioners. Institutional investors pool funds from their clients to pursue investment opportunities more effectively than the individual clients could on their own.

Institutional investors are considered “sophisticated investors” because they can employ investment professionals who specialize in specific areas of investment research and analysis. They also have the resources to conduct portfolio management of their investments. In investments, portfolio management is the administration of investment policy, strategy, and operations for a specified group of investments. To coordinate the efforts of investment professionals, the typical institutional investor has an investment group, or investment function, that follows a well-defined process and uses a comprehensive strategy to meet the investment goals of the institution.

Unlike retail investors, most institutional investors have significant resources to devote to securities trading. Therefore, institutional investors are more likely than retail investors to place trades that are large enough to influence the price for a given security. When one market participant meaningfully pushes the price of a security beyond the range in which other market participants were expecting it to trade, the result is called “moving the market.”

EXAMPLE

Algravita Fund Company, a large institutional investor, has decided to place a large trade to add shares of Landgen Corporation to its funds. The number of Landgen shares that Algravita wishes to purchase represents 73% of the average daily trading volume for Landgen shares. If Algravita executes its entire trade in one day, it will significantly push up the price of Landgen shares for other market participants who wish to buy shares. In other words, Algravita’s trade will have a big impact on the market for Landgen shares by effectively moving the market.

In addition to moving markets, the size of institutional investors usually allows them to have more influence than retail investors. For example, because they usually have more publicly traded stock shares than retail investors, institutional investors generally have more votes on certain corporate matters, such as the election of a publicly traded company’s board of directors.

Typically, institutional investors have more access to information than retail investors. For instance, they might have the opportunity to meet personally with a company’s executives and ask questions. Institutional investors also have more access to external research on specific securities, security issuers, and markets.

Institutional investors also have the ability to negotiate trading fees. Institutional investors typically pay varying fee rates that depend on the size of their trades. In contrast, retail investors usually pay a flat fee rate to broker-dealers, regardless of the size of their trade. A broker-dealeris a financial institution that (1) buys and sells securities either for itself or for its customers and (2) provides information and advice to customers regarding the purchase and sale of securities. Because of trading costs, retail investors usually trade less frequently than institutional investors.

Institutional investors can devote more time and energy to exploring and holding a wider range of asset types. They also have the expertise to participate in complex markets and the means to participate in investments with certain restrictions, such as minimum investment amounts. Therefore, institutional investors generally have more investment options than retail investors.

Institutional Investors

pages.title: Insurers as Institutional Investors
pages.contents:
Insurers as Institutional Investors

As one of the largest institutional investors in the world, the insurance industry possesses significant investment capital. For instance, at the end of 2016, U.S. insurers reported more than $6.1 trillion of cash and invested assets. 1

By investing in a wide range of businesses and industries, insurers supply funds that businesses use to engage in productive projects. Thus, insurers help facilitate economic growth around the world.

As institutional investors, insurance companies primarily invest to support their insurance products. Like many financial services companies, insurance companies have an investment function that handles investment activities on behalf of the company.

 

The Investment Function

The investment function plays an essential role in the operation of insurance companies. By carefully selecting and prudently managing investments, the investment function helps an insurer cover obligations, protect capital, and increase profits.

For insurers, assets supporting an insurance product need to grow at least as quickly as the product’s liabilities, which are the current and future financial obligations an insurer has to its customers. For instance, life insurers must grow assets over many years to support the benefits provided under life insurance policies and annuity contracts. By effectively investing an insurer’s assets, the investment function helps the company meet its contractual obligations and strengthens the company’s financial position.

Many types of financial institutions—including life insurance companies, banks, and retirement plans—use asset-liability management (ALM) to coordinate the risks that simultaneously affect the company’s investments and products. Within life insurance companies, ALM coordinates the administration of an insurer’s asset portfolio—its investments—with the administration of its liability portfolio—its obligations to customers—so as to manage risk and still earn an adequate level of return.

Insurance regulators must be able to verify that insurance companies are financially healthy and can meet obligations to their customers and creditors on time. Therefore, solvency regulations set standards for ensuring that insurers hold sufficient assets to support their obligations. Furthermore, regulations require that insurers hold additional capital to offset certain investment risks. We go into further detail about regulations in Chapter 10.

The investment function helps an insurance company meet its capital requirements by growing assets and also takes measures to protect capital from financial risks. You will learn how investment professionals manage financial risks in Chapter 8.

While growing assets to cover liabilities and meet regulatory requirements, the investment function can generate excess investment returns. However, investment professionals must exercise caution to avoid assuming too much risk, which could jeopardize the company’s solvency.

Still, insurance companies count on the investment function to produce additional funds for operational flexibility and profitability. Insurers use the money from excess investment returns for actions such as

  • Paying operating expenses

  • Lowering policy premiums

  • Paying policy dividends

  • Investing in employee training

  • Hiring new employees

  • Improving equipment and technological capabilities

  • Initiating business growth projects, such as developing new products and expanding product lines

  • Returning profits to company owners

A thriving investment function is beneficial to all of a company’s stakeholders, including its employees. For example, profitable insurers stay in business and can afford to devote more money to providing employee benefits and paying salaries and commissions. Therefore, all insurance company employees have a vested interest in the ongoing success of the investment function.

 

Movement of Funds

For an insurance company, most of its investable capital comes from the policy premiums that the company receives. An insurer divides its assets into two main types of accounts—a general account and one or more separate accounts. The movement of funds through the investment process differs depending on whether the funds support the general account portfolio or a separate account portfolio.

 

General Accounts

A general account, also called a general account portfolio, is a life insurance company investment account in which the insurer maintains assets that support all of the insurer’s contractual obligations for guaranteed insurance products, such as whole life insurance or fixed annuity products. General account assets also support any guarantees found in variable products.

For the general account, the insurance company bears the investment risk and the risk attached to paying the insurance benefits or other product guarantees to customers. Because the customer has a claim to benefits and product guarantees under an insurance or annuity contract, the insurer is responsible for making sound investments that enable it to fulfill its guarantees.

The customer does not have a direct interest in the financial success of general account investments. From the customer’s point of view, as long as the insurer can meet its policy obligations, the customer typically is not concerned with how the company invests the premiums.

When a customer pays a premium for a fully guaranteed product, a portion of the money is usually invested through the company’s general account. Within the general account, the company’s investment function grows the money over time through its investments.

For general accounts, the path of funds is relatively simple. After a customer’s premium is in the company’s accounts, it becomes a part of the funds available for investment professionals to use to purchase assets for the general account.

When an insurance policy’s benefits become payable, the company draws from the general account to pay those benefits. Sometimes, incoming cash flows from investments can fund outgoing cash payments of benefits. Other times, the company may need to sell invested assets to raise the cash for benefit payments.

In addition to death benefits, a life insurer may pay withdrawal benefits, policy loans, premium refunds, and surrender benefits from its general account. The general account is also used to pay for guarantees in variable products, such as guaranteed minimum benefit riders and fixed fund options.

 

Separate Accounts

In addition to offering guaranteed products, life insurance companies offer nonguaranteed products in the form of variable life insurance and variable annuities. To support nonguaranteed products, insurance companies use separate accounts. Separate accounts, also called separate account portfolios, are asset accounts that are (1) maintained by an insurer apart from its general account and (2) used to manage the funds associated with the company’s variable products.

The term “separate account” is primarily used in the United States. In Canada, products that combine insurance benefits and investment performance are called segregated funds. Other countries may call such products unit-linked portfolios. For simplicity, this text uses the term “separate accounts” to refer to accounts supporting variable products inside and outside of the United States.

Unlike general account products, the customer—not the company—bears most or all of the investment risk associated with a separate account product. We say “most or all” because a variable product may have contractual guarantees that cushion a customer from portions of the investment risk. For example, a customer’s variable annuity may contain a provision guaranteeing a minimum rate of return for a specified time period, even if the invested assets earn a lower rate than the guaranteed rate during that period. In this example, the guarantee is funded through the general account.

For a separate account product, the insurance company sets up an individual account linked to the customer, and the customer has a direct interest in the investment performance of the assets supporting the account. The customer typically elects to allocate her premium payments into at least one of several investment fund options, called subaccounts. In addition to subaccounts, many variable products offer a fixed fund option, which guarantees a fixed rate of interest for a specified period of time. Premiums allocated to a fixed fund option are administered and invested with the insurer’s general account.

The insurer tracks the market value—in investing, the current price an asset would sell for in the marketplace—of the subaccounts, and the customer’s account value rises or falls in accordance with the change in the market values of the subaccounts the customer selected. Therefore, the benefit amount of a variable product typically depends directly on the investment performance of the assets in the customer’s account.

When the customer of a variable product pays a premium to the insurance company, part of the money is usually invested with the company’s separate account assets. The insurer uses separate account funds to purchase shares of the specific subaccounts chosen by the customers.

When a policy’s benefits come due, the company typically draws funds from the separate account assets to pay the benefits. Again, money for a guaranteed benefit would come from the general account instead of the separate account.

Similar to the general account, incoming cash flows from separate account investments can fund outgoing cash payments of benefits. If the company needs to sell invested assets to raise cash for benefits, it sells shares of the appropriate subaccounts.

pages.contents:
Overview of the Investment Function

Financial services companies typically employ a variety of investment professionals to carry out the responsibilities of the investment function. A company’s internal controls can affect how responsibilities are divided.

Companies vary in the kinds of arrangements they have with their investment functions. Within the investment function, operations tend to be divided into two or three categories. An insurance company’s investment function receives support from and provides input to other functional areas in the company.

Companies may outsource investment management duties to external vendors. A vendor, also known as a service provider or a solution provider, is a third party that a company hires to perform specific tasks or provide specific services.

Companies can gain access to external data through vendors. The investment function collects and analyzes external and internal data by using specific information systems.

 

Roles of Investment Professionals

The investment function of insurers and other financial services companies typically has the following professional roles:

  • Chief Investment Officer. The chief investment officer (CIO) is a senior-level executive who manages a company’s investment function. The CIO is responsible for implementing the company’s investment policies within the investment function. In addition, the CIO advises the company’s senior executives and board of directors on investment matters and can recommend changes to the company’s investment policies.

  • Portfolio Managers. A portfolio manager is an investment professional with broad authority and accountability for fulfilling the mission and objectives of an investment portfolio. A portfolio manager is responsible for constructing the portfolio and managing the portfolio’s assets to meet the portfolio’s established risk constraints and return requirements. Within an insurance company, a portfolio manager is typically assigned to handle assets that support a particular product or business line.

  • Investment Analysts. An investment analyst, sometimes called a securities analyst or financial analyst, is an investment professional responsible for monitoring issuers of securities and making trading recommendations. Some analysts are generalists, whereas others specialize in a specific asset type or industry. Investment analysts provide research and insights that support investment decisions made by portfolio managers.

  • Traders. A trader is an investment professional responsible for executing purchases and sales of publicly traded securities under instructions from a portfolio manager. At smaller firms, a trader may handle a broad range of securities; at larger firms, a trader may specialize in trading a specific type of financial asset. Traders constantly monitor financial markets to ensure that they execute trades at the best possible prices, thus maximizing the benefits of the portfolio managers’ investment decisions.

  • Investment Operations Professionals. Investment operations professionals provide administrative support to the investment function. Trade settlement specialists monitor executed trades to ensure that the exchange of securities and cash is completed with trading partners in a timely manner. Other operations professionals maintain records of investment transactions in internally managed computer systems. Companies may hire external parties for some administration activities.

  • Investment Risk Management Professionals. Investment risk management professionals focus on identifying and measuring risks that affect a company’s investments. For example, asset-liability management risk is the risk that a company’s capital could be depleted due to a narrowing of the difference between returns earned on assets and liabilities or a mismatch in cash flows for assets and liabilities. Asset-liability managers monitor a company’s assets and investments supporting a specified product line, such as annuities. Asset-liability managers help a company manage risk for a given product line by (1) tracking cash inflows and outflows and (2) projecting mismatches between assets and liabilities. At some companies, the portfolio managers may perform some asset-liability management duties, such as ensuring that sufficient funds are available to support a product’s liabilities. In many companies, asset-liability managers and other investment risk management professionals provide risk reports to the company’s board of directors.

  • Investment Information Technology Professionals. Investment information technology professionals maintain the technology for software and information processing packages, data reporting, data communications, information feeds, and data storage. In recent years, information technology professionals have increased the resources devoted to information security—the physical, technical, and procedural steps a company takes to prevent the loss, wrongful disclosure (accidental or intentional), or theft of information.

Role

Description

Chief Investment Officer (CIO)

The CIO manages the investment function and is responsible for implementing corporate investment policies within the function.

Portfolio Manager

A portfolio manager constructs an investment portfolio and manages its assets to meet its established objectives and constraints.

Investment Analyst

An investment analyst supports a portfolio manager by researching and recommending potential investments.

Trader

A trader executes portfolio trade orders as directed by a portfolio manager.

Investment Operations Professional

Investment operations professionals provide administrative support, such as monitoring executed trades and maintaining records.

Investment Risk Management Professional

Investment risk management professionals identify and measure risks related to the company’s investment activities.

Investment Information Technology Professional

Investment information technology professionals maintain the technology that the investment function uses.
 

Internal Controls

Companies split up responsibilities within the investment function as a form of internal control. According to the principle of segregation of duties, also known as the principle of dual control, an employer should design jobs so that incompatible functions are assigned to different individuals. In this context, incompatible functionsare job duties in the normal course of employment that, when combined, place an employee in a position where he could commit an illegal act or could conceal errors or irregularities.

When incompatible functions are combined, a company is also less likely to detect unintentional errors that its employees commit. Segregating—or “separating”—duties helps a company safeguard its assets by providing a framework in which the company can quickly detect and address suspicious actions, errors, and irregularities.

An effective internal control system separates the custodial, authorization, and accounting tasks associated with the company’s assets. In this context, custodial tasksinclude the physical or electronic handling of assets. Therefore, an employee who assumes physical or electronic custody of securities should not be the same employee who maintains the accounting records for those securities. Furthermore, employees with custodial or accounting tasks should not have authorization to buy, sell, or otherwise dispose of securities. Institutional investors often use an external provider for custodial tasks to comply with the need for internal controls.

For financial transactions conducted by internal employees, many financial services companies require that an employee with a sufficient authorization limit officially authorize a transaction before it can occur. An authorization limit is the maximum monetary amount that a company employee has official power to approve for disbursement without prior approval by another company employee with higher authority.

Depending on their role in the investment function, individual employees have different levels of authorization to complete financial transactions.

EXAMPLE

A junior securities trader may have to obtain authorization for all security purchases or sales in excess of $2 million. The trader has sufficient authorization to complete any transaction below that threshold.

A senior securities trader may have to obtain authorization for all security purchases or sales in excess of $10 million. If the junior securities trader is seeking authorization for a $3 million purchase, the senior securities trader can authorize that transaction.

 

Organization of the Investment Function

Financial services companies can organize their investment functions in a variety of ways. For insurance companies, examples of these arrangements are as follows:

  • The company operates the investment function in a department within the company. With this arrangement, the company may obtain specialized investment management services from external sources.

  • The company previously had an internal investment department, but established it as a separate company that retains a corporate affiliation with the insurance company. In these cases, the separate investment management firm performs most investment services for the insurance company, while also providing services to other clients—including other types of institutional investors.

  • The company does not employ many internal investment professionals in its investment department. Instead, such companies obtain most of their investment services from external providers. The external investment management firms have no past or current affiliation with the insurance company.

  • A financial services company includes an insurance company and an investment management firm. The insurer and investment management firm are subsidiaries, or companies that are owned or controlled by another company, known as a holding company. A financial holding companyconducts activities that are financial in nature or incidental to financial activities—such as insurance activities, securities activities, banking, and investment and advisory services. In this situation, the affiliated investment management firm can provide services to the financial holding company and the affiliated insurance company, each of whom is an institutional investor.

EXAMPLE

The Dexicos Financial Group, a financial holding company, has several subsidiaries. One of the subsidiaries, Dexicos Investment Management, performs the investment function for all other subsidiaries of Dexicos Financial Group. Dexicos Investment Management also provides investment management services for institutional investors outside of the Dexicos Financial Group.

In the following illustration, the orange arrows indicate that Dexicos Investment Management is providing services to entities within the holding company. In addition, they provide services to entities outside of the holding company, as indicated by the green arrow.

Regardless of the manner in which an insurer organizes its investment function, the investment operations themselves are similar across many types of investment functions.

Within an investment function’s organizational structure, companies often divide operations activities into the following classifications:

  • Front-Office Operations. Front-office operations typically consist of investment operations activities that deal directly with the securities marketplace, trade negotiations, and trading securities. Front-office functions encompass portfolio management, asset management, asset trading, investment analysis, and investment research. Because many roles in the front-office directly interact with clients and visibly affect client accounts, they are often called “client-facing” roles.

  • Middle-Office Operations. Middle-office operations typically consist of trade-support operations, including investment forecasting, securities regulatory compliance, trade settlements, funds disbursement, investment risk management, and portfolio performance reporting.

  • Back-Office Operations. Back-office operations typically consist of official company record-keeping operations, including investment accounting, investment reporting, investment information technology, data governance and security, and management of vendor relationships.

The middle-office and back-office operations support the activities of the front office. Some financial services companies divide investment operations into just two categories—front-office and back-office operations. Such companies consider middle-office activities to be a part of back-office operations.

Interaction with Other Functions

Within an insurance company, the investment function interacts with several functional areas that provide support to or require input from investment professionals. Notably, the investment function works with the risk management, accounting, treasury operations, product development, and investment marketing functions.

 

Risk Management

While every function plays a role in managing an insurer’s risks, some insurers have a separate unit devoted to risk management and analysis. Other insurers may include risk management activities in other functions, such as finance.

The risk management function (1) measures and monitors the company’s exposures to multiple types of risks and (2) analyzes the probabilities and impacts of potential risk events. In addition, the risk management function may be responsible for overseeing the company’s capital management and asset-liability management efforts.

The risk management function monitors the financial risks associated with investment operations. Risk management professionals also review investment activities to verify that investment professionals are following company policies regarding appropriate levels of risk exposure.

Insurance regulators and securities regulators also scrutinize insurers’ investment activities. Together, an insurance company’s risk management professionals and investment professionals ensure that the company complies with regulations.

We cover the relationship between risk management and the investment function in greater detail in Chapter 6.

 

Accounting

The accounting function records, tracks, and reports on a company’s financial transactions, including investment transactions. Accountants gather financial information and distribute it to company managers. Insurers use records of transactions to generate financial statements and reports for regulators and other external stakeholders.

Accountants also ensure compliance with complex financial reporting standards related to the investments of insurance companies.

 

Treasury Operations

In insurance companies, the treasury operations function manages and maintains records and reports for all of an insurer’s cash transactions, specifically money deposited or withdrawn from accounts at a bank or other financial institution. Employees in treasury operations set up bank accounts and disburse policy proceeds via checks and electronic funds transfer.

A company’s treasury function, through its cash management activities, keeps the company’s cash reserves at needed levels. Cash management includes cash forecasting, bank relations, bank account administration, and short-term lending and borrowing activities. Cash forecasting involves tracking and predicting the movement of money into and out of the company.

Although the treasury function and the investment function are usually separate within an insurer, they must work together. Investment employees make strategic decisions and execute transactions to manage the company’s assets, while treasury employees handle the resulting cash inflows and outflows. Together, they ensure prudent management of the company’s finances.

 

Product Development

In life insurance companies, actuaries play a significant role in product development. An actuary is an expert in financial risk management and the mathematics and modeling of insurance and annuity products, as well as other financial instruments. Actuaries help insurers develop assumptions used in pricing new products.

To create a product’s financial design, actuaries and other product development team members require information from investment professionals. During product planning and development, investment professionals identify the types of assets that are available to match the characteristics of a given product. Investment professionals also evaluate any product design assumptions involving the assets backing a product and support the long-term matching of assets with a product’s liabilities.

 

Investment Marketing

A company’s investment marketing function is responsible primarily for the marketing and sales of investment services to potential institutional investment clients. When making client presentations, the company’s sales professionals rely on information that investment professionals provide.

The investment marketing function develops all of the information for use in product or service descriptions and promotional information about the company’s institutional investment management services. The marketing unit then creates, produces, and distributes the communications pieces.

In addition, a unit within client communications prepares all responses for requests for proposals received from potential clients. A request for proposal (RFP) is a document that an organizational buyer submits to possible suppliers that provides detailed information about the organization’s needs and invites the supplier to bid on satisfying those needs. Investment professionals provide details to help marketers complete RFPs submitted by possible customers of their investment services.

Employees in an investment marketing group may also support training programs for an institutional investment product. For example, an insurance company might educate its own sales staff or the client’s staff about the different subaccounts available to variable annuity customers.

Insurer Function

Relation to the Investment Function

Risk Management

Monitors financial risks associated with investment operations and verifies that investment activities follow corporate risk policies.

Accounting

Uses investment transaction records to generate the company’s financial statements and regulatory reports.

Treasury Operations

Handles the company’s cash flow operations, which are affected by investment transactions.

Product Development

Develops product assumptions using information provided by investment professionals.

Investment Marketing

Incorporates information from investment professionals when promoting investment services to potential clients.
 

Outsourcing Management Duties

Some financial services companies manage their invested assets internally. However, other companies may not have the resources—or the desire—to hire investment professionals who have expertise in each aspect of investment management. These companies may rely on external vendors to perform certain investment management duties. The practice of hiring an external vendor to perform specified operational functions is called outsourcing.

A financial services company can partially or completely outsource investment management duties. Outsourcing is particularly attractive to smaller companies and companies that do not possess the internal expertise to manage specific types of assets.

EXAMPLE

Palvica Regional Bank is a small institutional investor with a limited investment staff: three portfolio managers, one investment analyst, and one securities trader. While the company’s investment professionals are skilled in managing securities issued in North America and Europe, they want to expand their portfolio holdings by adding securities issued in Asia.

Palvica’s investment team recognizes that it does not possess the expertise to invest in Asian securities. Therefore, the company hires Ukugo Investment Group, an investment management firm that specializes in selecting and managing Asian securities for institutional investors. By outsourcing to Ukugo, Palvica is able to broaden the types of assets it invests in on behalf of its clients.

 

Systems and Data

For investment professionals, constant access to real-time financial market information is critical. Financial markets are fluid, with prices changing throughout the day, so investment professionals can face an urgency to act on current financial market pricing. As a result, financial services companies must take special care to ensure that external data feeds continue without interruptions.

Institutional investors use systems and databases to collect, organize, and analyze information. Because financial services companies collect a large amount of information, they have corporate policies to manage and protect their data.

 

Sources of Data

Investment professionals use data that come from internal and external sources. Investment operations within the company generate some internal data. For example, companies keep records of their own account balances, asset values, executed trades, transaction costs, and cash inflows and outflows.

The company’s portfolio transactions generate other internal data. For instance, a company tracks changes in the composition of a portfolio’s holdings after recent purchases increase the percentage of one asset type relative to other asset types. Companies can calculate portfolio performance over varying lengths of time, from a single day to several decades.

Although internal data are useful for internal evaluation, investment professionals work primarily with data generated externally. In addition to real-time prices, investment professionals look at data related to financial markets, companies, industries, and market economies.

External data help investment professionals assess asset values and investment opportunities. For instance, many investors examine financial statements from publicly traded companies to determine those businesses’ financial health and growth prospects. Shares of companies that are poised to outperform their competitors could be attractive investments for institutional portfolios.

External data also help investment professionals make portfolio decisions. For example, studying historical patterns can be useful in predicting the direction of asset prices in the future. Therefore, many investment professionals use historical data to anticipate market trends, which enable them to position portfolios so as to profit from their insights.

An institutional investor that employs multiple investment analysts can deploy them to gather large quantities of data. However, many companies find it more efficient to use external vendors to acquire data for their analysts. Some vendors also provide services to organize and analyze the data they collect.

Bloomberg L.P. is a popular external data vendor for institutional investors. Bloomberg provides subscribers with access to real-time financial markets data through its proprietary computer system, known as the Bloomberg Terminal.

Bloomberg also offers financial news, analytics tools, trade execution capabilities, and electronic communication between subscribers.

 

Types of Systems and Databases

The volume and complexity of investment data require financial services companies to merge information from multiple internal and external data sources. To manage all of their gathered information, companies use information systems.

The investment function uses several types of information systems:

  • Investment accounting systems support general ledger processing, reporting to clients, and compliance with internal and external controls. These systems also generate sales proposals to institutional clients.

  • Trade management systems—also known as order management systems—are associated with trading platforms and support the processes of trade initiation, trade execution, and transaction recording. These systems allow traders to monitor and execute trades electronically in real time.

  • Portfolio management systems support investment management activities. These systems display cash balances and portfolio holdings, monitor investment transactions, track asset and portfolio market values, support portfolio performance measurement and analysis, generate investment reports, and comply with internal policies and external regulations.

  • Risk management and analysis systems support the processes for risk management, asset analysis, asset-liability management, and scenario analysis. Many risk analysis systems are dedicated to a single type of asset instead of all asset types.

 

Data Analysis

Investment professionals use data to help them discover investment opportunities. To draw relevant insights from their data, they conduct data analysis, which is a process of applying a variety of analytical techniques to collected data, and using the results of the analysis to formulate recommendations concerning a research objective.

Advancements in technology have made it easier for investment professionals to conduct quantitative research, which is research designed to generate concrete information about people and their behaviors that can be analyzed, summarized in the form of numbers, and easily communicated to others. For example, many computer programs now conduct data mining, a type of analysis in which numerical data are examined to uncover trends, patterns, and relationships. The ability to identify trends faster than other investors is a competitive advantage for an institutional investor.

Technology will continue to change investment management as analytical capabilities grow increasingly sophisticated. Computer scientists are working on artificial intelligence (AI)—the development of intelligent machines that work, “learn,” and react like humans. Applying AI to investing goes beyond tasking machines with sifting through enormous volumes of data; AI will help analysts interpret data, thus turning the data into useful information.

Because of advancements like AI, investment analysts will be able to spend more time on qualitative research, which is research that uses subjective data collection methods and produces results that are difficult to summarize in numerical form. Qualitative research examines what people think, how they feel about the subject under study, and the words they use to express those thoughts and feelings.

EXAMPLE

Heidi Nilsen, an investment analyst, is performing research on a company for a possible investment. Heidi has conducted quantitative research, including studying the company’s financial reports and the company’s sales trends relative to its competitors. She wants to conduct qualitative research to develop a sense for the level of confidence that the company’s managers have in its ability to increase product sales in the future.

Heidi watches a recent television interview that the company’s chief executive officer (CEO) gave to a business news channel. In addition to the substance of the CEO’s answers, Heidi studies the CEO’s tone of voice and body language during the interview, hoping to infer clues about the executive’s true feelings regarding his company’s prospects.

Because people can track and present data about investment performance in so many ways, investment professionals use data visualization tools to put data into context. A data visualization tool is a technology-driven graphical display that conveys an intuitive understanding of data.

Data visualization tools graphically present data in easy-to-understand formats—for example, with charts, graphs, and tables—making it easier to analyze and evaluate the performance of individual assets and investment portfolios. Figure 1.2 is an example of a chart that investors might use.

 

Data Governance

Financial services companies contain many functions—including the investment function—that rely heavily on information, so companies need internal guidelines for handling data. Data governance is the process of establishing organizational ownership and accountability for data so that business processes are optimized and data are secure and protected.

Data governance provides a framework for organizational decisions about how to manage data, realize value from it, minimize its cost and complexity, manage risk, and ensure compliance with ever-growing external requirements for information.

At some companies, data governance is the responsibility of one of the standing committees that report to a company’s board of directors. A standing committee can keep the board and executives informed of data governance issues that can affect the company’s performance.

Regardless of a company’s organizational structure, successful data governance requires oversight from senior managers to support efforts at the functional level and ensure close coordination with the information technology (IT) unit.

 
Information Security

For financial institutions, the unauthorized intrusion into a company’s information systems to move money out of accounts, compromise confidentiality of data, and engage in any number of other activities that could disrupt financial markets are of great concern. Therefore, holistic data governance involves establishing information security measures.

EXAMPLE

As a matter of company policy, Dexicos Investment Management restricts user access to its trade management system. Furthermore, users can only perform certain activities in the system depending on their role in the trading process:

  • Only traders can initiate and execute trades.
  • Portfolio managers and traders can view transaction information but cannot edit records.
  • Only trade settlement specialists and other investment operations professionals can enter and edit transaction records.

Analysis: By limiting access and user capabilities within the system, Dexicos prevents unauthorized users from viewing and manipulating information pertaining to the company’s trading activities.

The investment function is a particularly attractive target for cybercriminals who wish to steal funds or information, disrupt normal business operations, and destroy public confidence in financial markets. To fend off malicious cyberattacks, companies engage in a type of information security known as cybersecurity, which encompasses measures undertaken to protect a company’s computer networks, systems, and data from unauthorized access. The following insight provides examples of some cybersecurity practices a financial services company may use.

INSIGHT

Cybersecurity Practices for Financial Services Companies

A financial services company may implement any of the following cybersecurity practices:

  • Conduct annual risk assessments to identify internal and external threats to data security.
  • Address system vulnerabilities by keeping computer software up to date, installing software “patches” for vulnerable applications, and using firewalls, which are combinations of hardware and software that create electronic barriers between the public and private areas of an insurer’s systems.
  • Protect data through encryption, a type of technology that encodes data so that only an authorized person possessing the required hardware and/or software can decode that data.
  • Regularly create data backups, which are copies of computer data that are usually stored in offsite locations. Data backups prevent the permanent loss of important information and aid in restoring critical operations if a disruptive event occurs.
  • Restrict user access to systems and enhance user authentication measures. Authenticationis the technological process of ensuring that someone requesting or sending information is who he claims to be.
  • Regularly train company employees on cybersecurity threats, their role in managing information, and the company’s cybersecurity policies and procedures.
  • Establish a testing schedule to ensure that cybersecurity policies and procedures are working as intended.
  • Set up a committee to issue cybersecurity reports to the company’s senior managers and board of directors.
  • Create incident response policies to outline how the company will respond in the event of a successful breach of security.
  • Monitor and comply with applicable government regulations regarding cybersecurity.

External vendors pose a significant risk to a company’s cybersecurity. Even if a financial services company is vigilant about protecting its data, it cannot assume that its business partners are exercising the same level of care. Therefore, a comprehensive cybersecurity policy should include the monitoring of vendors, including examining the vendor’s security practices and establishing procedures for a coordinated response to cyberattacks to contain the damage of successful breaches.

An investor who wants to earn an investment return must choose a way to commit capital to the investment. He places his capital in an investment vehicle, which is the medium used to represent an investment interest in an asset. Other terms for an investment vehicle are financial instrument, funding vehicle, and funding instrument. For simplicity, we use the term investment vehicle throughout this text. Many types of investment vehicles exist—such as stocks, bonds, real estate properties, mutual funds, and exchange-traded funds.

Insurance companies and other institutional investors place money into investments through investment vehicles. In this chapter, you will learn about some of the major investment vehicles that life insurers use in their portfolios. In the next chapter, you will read about additional investment vehicles that life insurers use to earn returns.

Asset Classes

Institutional investors can choose to invest in many types of assets. Because of this diversity, investment professionals categorize invested assets in different ways. One popular way of categorizing assets is by asset class. An asset class is a group of similar investment vehicles linked by related risk and return features.

Investors expect the various assets belonging to an asset class to behave similarly in the marketplace. Furthermore, in a given market environment, a particular asset class will behave similarly to some asset classes and differently than others.

Typically, an investment portfolio includes assets that represent multiple asset classes. An important aspect of portfolio management is managing risks to the portfolio. As such, a portfolio manager chooses assets and asset classes to reduce investment risk. Two portfolio management strategies for reducing investment risk are

  • Diversification, which is a technique for spreading risk by investing in a variety of assets with different risk characteristics. One way of diversifying a portfolio is by holding investments from several asset classes.

  • Hedging, which is a risk management strategy that involves balancing one risk with a complementary risk that ideally offsets the original risk. An asset can act as a hedge against other assets, asset classes, or certain market conditions.

In Chapters 7 and 8, you will learn more about how portfolio managers use diversification and hedging to manage risk in investment portfolios.

Although no consensus exists over which groups of assets constitute asset classes, three of the most commonly recognized asset classes are cash (and cash equivalents), bonds, and stocks. Other types of assets that are important to insurers include real estate, mortgage loans, structured securities, derivatives, and alternative investments. You will learn about structured securities, derivatives, and alternative investments in Chapter 3.

pages.title: Cash and Cash Equivalents
pages.contents:
Cash and Cash Equivalents

The most basic asset to hold is cash, which is money held in the form of a currency. From a country’s perspective, domestic currency is the currency issued by the country’s monetary authority, and foreign currency is any currency issued by other countries. Currency issued by one country can be exchanged for currency issued by another country through foreign exchange (FX) markets, which convert currencies used by buyers into currencies acceptable to sellers.

Cash can be held in a physical form, such as coins or paper bills. Cash is also held in virtual form in accounts such as checking accounts and savings accounts.

Cash equivalents are investments that are not cash but that can be converted to cash within 90 days with little or no risk of losing value. An example of a cash equivalent is a money market account, which is an account that pays interest on deposited funds based on current interest rates for highly liquid, low-risk assets with short-term maturities.

The most appealing aspect of cash and cash equivalents is their liquidity. In the context of financial products, liquidity is the ease with which an asset can be converted to cash for an approximation of its underlying value. Cash is immediately available to make purchases or pay expenses, and cash equivalents are available very quickly.

Cash is primarily considered a savings vehicle because it does not earn a return on investment. For example, you cannot sell a $20 bill for $25. However, some cash equivalents—such as money market accounts—earn investment income in the form of interest payments. Thus, cash equivalents can serve as savings vehicles or short-term investment vehicles.

Most investors hold cash and/or cash equivalents in their portfolios. For instance, insurers typically hold cash and cash equivalents because they must always have some cash available to pay expenses and liabilities, such as claims.

Cash equivalents are illiquid assets.

pages.title: Bonds
pages.contents:
Bonds

Recall from Chapter 1 that one type of security—known as a debt security—represents an obligation of indebtedness owed by a business, a government, or an agency. When most people think of debt securities, they think of bonds. A bond is a security that represents a debt that the borrower—the issuer of the bond—owes to the bondholder—the person or company that buys and owns the bond. Essentially, the bondholder lends money to the issuer in exchange for regular interest payments and future repayment of the loan. Because interest payments generally provide a predictable stream of income to the bondholder, bonds are considered fixed-income investments.

Investors can compare the income received from different types of bonds by evaluating bond yields. Yield is a ratio measuring an asset’s rate of return on income paid to the asset holder. Yield is expressed as a percentage and is generally calculated by dividing an asset’s income payments during a specified period—such as one year—by the asset’s price. In addition to bonds, investors also calculate yields for other types of income-generating investments. You will read about bond yields and other return calculations in Chapter 4.

Many institutional investors hold bonds to earn regular income and steady investment returns. As the table earlier in this chapter shows, bonds are a significant portion of life insurers’ investment holdings. Bonds are particularly suitable for life insurers’ general account portfolios because insurers have long-term liabilities, need to protect capital, and experience regular cash outflows. In addition, bonds help with asset-liability management because insurers can match the cash flows of bonds with the cash flows of their liabilities. We explain how bonds meet insurance company needs in later chapters.

 

Bond Characteristics

A legally enforceable contract, called the bond indenture, specifies the promises of the bond issuer and the rights of the bondholder. A bond indenture establishes the bond’s features, such as

  • Par value. A bond’s par value—also known as principal, face value, or face amount—is the designated legal monetary value assigned to each bond—generally $1,000 or $10,000. For example, if a company issues (sells) twenty-five bonds at a par value of $1,000 per bond, it has raised $25,000 (25 x $1,000). In this case, $25,000 represents the amount the company borrowed from its bondholders.

  • Maturity date. The maturity date is the date on which the bond issuer must repay to the bondholder the amount originally borrowed (the par value). The length of time from a bond’s issue date to its maturity date is called the term to maturity. Bonds are available with a variety of stated terms to maturity—generally, from one year up to 30 years.

  • Coupon rate. The coupon rate is the interest rate that determines the amount of the periodic interest payments made to the bondholder. Until maturity, the bond issuer usually pays the bondholder interest on the par value. These coupon payments are made at specified intervals—typically semiannually, meaning every six months.

EXAMPLE

A bond with a par value of $1,000 pays a 3% coupon rate. Therefore, the bond issuer pays $30 in annual interest ($1,000 x 0.03) to the bondholder. Each semiannual payment to the bondholder is $15 ($30 / 2).

Most bonds are fixed-rate bonds, which means the coupon rate does not change during the bond’s term. However, some bonds specify coupon rates that fluctuate or “float” in specified ways. For example, a floating-rate coupon could be based on the variations in a certain index, which is a statistical measurement system that tracks the performance of a group of similar investments.

In addition, some bonds do not offer periodic coupon payments. A zero-coupon bonddoes not make coupon payments during the term of the bond; instead, the bond is sold at a discount to its par value and the principal is paid in full at the bond’s maturity date. Put differently, the interest that the bondholder should receive is factored into the principal payment at maturity.

In general, bonds are repaid on the maturity date. However, bond indentures also state conditions under which an issuer can retire—or repay—the bond before the maturity date. For instance, a callable bond allows the bond issuer to retire the bond prior to its maturity date at a specified price per bond, known as the call price. If market interest rates fall, a call provision benefits the bond issuer by enabling the issuer to repay a bond with a high coupon rate and subsequently issue a similar bond with a lower coupon rate.

The prospect of early repayment is a risk for the holder of a callable bond. As we explain in Chapter 4, investors require higher potential rates of return for riskier investments. Therefore, callable bonds typically have higher yields than noncallable bonds with comparable bond features.

 

Protections for Bondholders

Bond covenants are provisions in a bond indenture intended to protect the interest of the bondholder by mandating issuer behavior. Affirmative covenants require the issuer to take certain actions, while restrictive covenants—also known as negative covenants—restrict the issuer from taking certain actions that would be harmful to the bondholder. An example of a restrictive covenant is a financial covenant, which may stipulate that an issuer must not exceed particular financial measures—such as a maximum ratio of liabilities to assets.

Bond issuers that are having difficulties meeting a bond’s obligations often seek to alter the terms of the debt. Thus, a bond issuer may initiate debt restructuring, which is an agreement between a debt issuer and a lender, typically representing the lender’s concession to (1) extend the maturity date, (2) accept a lesser amount in repayment of the debt, or (3) otherwise alter the terms of the debt agreement. In debt restructuring for a bond, the issuer negotiates with the bondholders.

Despite bond covenants and debt restructuring options, bond issuers may default—fail to fulfill their financial obligations—on their bonds. In the event of a bond default, bondholders have a claim against the issuer’s assets. The claim priority of a bondholder depends on whether the bond is a senior bond or subordinated bond. In the event of the issuer’s default, a

  • Senior bond is a bond that has a higher claim priority than that of other bonds from the same issuer

  • Subordinated bond, also known as a junior bond, is a bond that has a lower claim priority than that of other bonds from the same issuer

In addition, bonds can be either secured or unsecured:

  • A secured bond is a bond in which the issuer pledges something of value—called collateral—to guarantee the safety of the bondholder’s investment.

  • An unsecured bond, also called a debenture, is a bond that is not backed by collateral but is backed only by the full faith and credit of the issuer.

Secured bondholders typically have first priority in satisfying their claims against a defaulted issuer’s collateral. Thus, secured bonds are often senior bonds. If the bond issuer does not have any outstanding secured bonds, senior unsecured bondholders have a higher claim priority on the issuer’s assets than subordinated unsecured bondholders. However, in a default, holders of unsecured bonds rarely receive the full value of their investments. Figure 2.1 illustrates bond types classified by claim priority and security.

 

Bond Issuers

The major bond issuers are corporations, local governments, national governments, and supranational entities.

 

Corporations

Corporations are the primary nongovernmental issuers of bonds. Corporations typically issue bonds to raise capital, which they use to expand their business activities. Bonds issued by corporations, called corporate bonds, are classified by the industry of the issuing company. For example, utility bonds are issued by providers of utilities, such as telephone and electric companies.

As you saw from the table earlier in this chapter, corporate bonds are one of the largest holdings in life insurers’ general accounts. Corporate bonds are also significant holdings in many other institutional investors’ portfolios.

 

Local Governments

Local governments and local government agencies issue bonds to raise funds for public works—such as schools, parks, bridges, highways, and hospitals. The bonds issued by city, county, and state governments are called municipal bonds, or munis. Outside of the United States, investors might refer to municipal bonds as sub-sovereign bonds. For example, Canadian provinces issue sub-sovereign bonds to borrow money for public works.

The two main types of municipal bonds are

  • General obligation bonds, which are backed by the full faith and credit of the issuer—which includes the taxing and further borrowing power of the issuer

  • Revenue bonds, which are supported by a specific income-producing project—such as a toll road

The interest income from municipal bonds is typically exempt from federal, state, and local income taxes if the bondholder resides in the state that issued the bond. However, life insurance companies do not benefit from these income tax exemptions and generally hold municipal bonds that are fully taxable.

Municipal bonds have some potential disadvantages. For example, many munis are relatively illiquid and have call provisions.

 

National Governments

To cover the cost of public spending that is not fully supported by tax revenues, many national governments issue federal government bonds—also called sovereign bonds—in either their domestic currency or a foreign currency. Federal government bonds issued by the U.S. government are usually referred to as Treasuries. The following chart shows the principal types of Treasuries:
