The U.S. government, including the U.S. Treasury and various federal agencies, is the world’s single largest borrower. Government bonds issued by the United States are backed by the full faith and credit of the federal government. Because default by the United States is highly unlikely, investors consider Treasuries to be essentially risk free, thus making them one of the safest investments in the world. For this reason, Treasuries are popular with life insurers and other institutional investors.

In general, investors consider sovereign bonds to be among the least risky investments because governments are able to collect taxes to service their debts. In addition, governments are motivated to fulfill their debt obligations, because they don’t want to jeopardize their ability to borrow at relatively low interest rates.

 

Supranational Entities

Some bonds are issued by multinational or supranational entities—such as regional development banks—which operate in more than one country. For example, the World Bank issues bonds to promote economic development projects in member countries. Bonds issued by supranational entities are commonly referred to as supranational bonds. Some life insurance companies invest in supranational bonds.

 

Credit Ratings

Bond investors expect to receive regular interest payments and a return of principal upon maturity. To evaluate how likely bondholders are to receive the interest payments and principal they are owed, investors look at credit ratings. Credit ratings are grades or scores that assess the creditworthiness of specific bonds and bond issuers. Issuers that are more likely to fulfill their debt obligations and avoid defaults are less risky and earn higher ratings.

For companies and governments, credit ratings affect the coupon rates that they have to pay on the bonds they issue:

  • Issuers with high ratings can generally offer lower coupon rates because their bonds are reasonably safe investments.

  • Issuers with lower ratings generally must offer higher coupon rates to entice investors because their bonds are riskier.

Credit ratings are grouped by quality. Bonds that are in the highest rating classifications are known as investment-grade bonds. Some institutional investors investing in bonds are restricted—by internal controls, regulators, or both—to investment-grade bonds.

Bonds that are not investment-grade bonds are known as high-yield bonds. High-yield bonds are also called junk bonds or speculative bonds. Investment-grade bonds pose lower levels of risk to bondholders, while high-yield bonds pose higher levels of risk. Thus, new issues of high-yield bonds generally offer higher coupon rates than those of investment-grade bonds that are issued at the same time.

Some institutional investors employ credit analysts to evaluate bond issuers and assign a proprietary rating. In addition, most investors look at ratings from external credit rating agencies. A credit rating agency is an independently owned, private organization that evaluates the financial condition of companies and governments and provides information about bonds and bond issuers to investors and potential customers.

Although insurance companies use popular credit analysis services to evaluate bonds, insurance regulators increasingly emphasize that companies must perform analysis independently of the rating agencies. Therefore, life insurers cannot rely entirely on external services to assess the credit quality of bonds.

The National Association of Insurance Commissioners (NAIC) also provides ratings for bonds. These ratings are intended to provide support for solvency monitoring of insurance company investments. You will learn more about the application of the NAIC’s bond ratings in Chapters 7 and 10.

pages.title: Stocks
pages.contents:
Stocks

Recall that an equity security is a security that represents an ownership interest in the issuing company. When most people think of equity securities, they think of stocks, which represent equity ownership through units called shares. A person or organization that owns shares of a company’s stock is a shareholder—also known as a stockholder.

In general, the historical return on stocks has been substantially higher than the historical return on bonds. Also, stocks are generally very liquid assets, and are often more liquid than bonds.

On the other hand, stocks are associated with higher risks than bonds. Stock prices are typically more volatile than bond prices. Shareholders also have fewer protections against a company’s default than bondholders do.

Stocks can earn returns through price appreciation and dividend income. Price appreciationis an increase in the market value of an invested asset. A dividend is a distribution of a company’s profits payable to owners of the company’s stock.

Depending on the institutional investor, stocks can make up a significant portion of an investment portfolio. For life insurers, stocks make up a large share of the assets held in separate account portfolios. However, stocks make up a smaller share of general account portfolios because of regulations that restrict the amount of common stock an insurer can have in its general account.

 

Common and Preferred Stocks

Companies issue two basic types of stock. A common stock is a type of stock that usually entitles the owner to (1) vote on the selection of the board of directors and on other important company matters and (2) receive dividends on the stock, if they are declared. Not all common stocks pay dividends.

In contrast, a preferred stock is a type of stock that typically does not carry the voting rights of common stock but does carry a stated dividend rate. Companies pay dividends to preferred shareholders before common shareholders.

Preferred stocks are hybrid securities because they have characteristics of both equity and debt securities. Like the fixed-interest payments of bonds, preferred stocks have fixed dividend rates. Preferred stocks also have par values, like bonds. Like equity securities, preferred stocks can appreciate in price—although preferred stock prices typically appreciate less than common stock prices.

In the event of a company’s liquidation, owners of preferred stock have a higher claim priority over company assets than common shareholders. However, a company’s bondholders have a higher claim priority than its preferred and common shareholders.

As mentioned above, common stocks typically have a stronger potential for price appreciation than preferred stocks. Therefore, many institutional investors focus on common stock over preferred stock. For example, insurance companies typically own little preferred stock.

 

Dividends

Companies are not required to declare dividend payments on common stock. If a company pays dividends to shareholders, it typically follows an established payment pattern—such as on a quarterly basis.

When a company reduces or eliminates a dividend, the company’s share price usually falls. Hence, dividend-paying companies strive to pay dividends regularly unless extraordinary circumstances force the company to reduce or eliminate them.

Companies can pay cash dividends, stock dividends, or special dividends:

  • A cash dividend is a cash payment to a shareholder for each share of stock the shareholder owns. Cash dividends, which are paid at a stated price per share, are the most frequent form of dividends for common stocks. For example, if a company declares a cash dividend of $0.25 per share, a shareholder owning 100 shares will receive $25 (100 × $0.25).

  • A stock dividend is a type of dividend in which a company distributes additional shares of its stock to shareholders. Stock dividends are expressed as a stated percentage of the shareholder’s number of shares. For example, if a company declares a 5% stock dividend, a shareholder owning 100 shares will receive an additional five shares (100 × 0.05). A stock dividend does not increase or decrease a shareholder’s proportionate share of ownership in the company. For instance, if a shareholder owns 2% of a company before the stock dividend is distributed, she will own 2% of the company after the distribution.

  • A special dividend, sometimes called an extra dividend, is a nonrecurring dividend that is usually paid in cash and is considerably larger than the normal dividend a company pays. Companies may declare special dividends to reward shareholders for onetime events, such as a period of exceptionally strong earnings.

pages.title: Real Estate and Mortgages
pages.contents:
Real Estate and Mortgages

Another type of investment is real estate, which is property that consists of land and any buildings or natural resources on it. Two examples of real estate assets are your house and your employer’s office building. Like a stock, real estate is considered an equity investment because it is an ownership asset.

However, real estate can also serve as the basis for a fixed-income investment. A property owner can secure a long-term loan, called a mortgage, by pledging the real estate property as collateral. The borrower agrees to pay off the mortgage loan with regular payments of principal and interest. A mortgage is a debt for a borrower but an investment for a lender.

 

Types of Real Estate Properties

Depending on its intended use, a real estate property is generally classified as

  • Residential. This type of property is intended to be used as a place of residence for the owner. Residential real estate can be a single-family property or a multifamily property, such as a duplex.

  • Commercial. This type of property is owned for the purpose of producing income. Examples of commercial real estate properties are multifamily residential properties (such as apartments), office buildings, hotel and resort properties, industrial properties, and retail properties—such as shopping centers.

  • Agricultural. This type of property is intended for agricultural use or as undeveloped, open space—also known as raw land. Important agricultural uses for real estate include dairy farming, crop production, ranching, agribusiness, and timber production.

 

Real Estate Appraisals

The value of a real estate property depends on many factors. Location is one of the most important factors in a property’s value. For example, properties in thriving metropolitan areas are typically more valuable than properties in less desirable locations. In addition, properties in popular locations are generally more liquid—and result in higher sales prices—because popular locations attract more potential buyers than unpopular locations.

The size of a property also affects its value. For instance, a small apartment building with 15 units will be valued differently than a large apartment building with 300 units. To compare properties of different sizes, residential and commercial property values are quoted by square footage—such as $100 per square foot.

Another factor affecting value is the use of the property. A property might have one value as a home and another value when used as office space. Improving a property or converting it to a new use is also likely to change the property’s value.

To determine the value of a real estate property, a qualified professional—called an appraiser—conducts an appraisal, which is an estimate of a property’s value as of a given date. Appraisers follow professional standards in determining property values. A property’s value varies depending on the approach the appraiser uses. Different approaches include

  • Market value appraisals, in which the appraiser estimates the price a buyer would be willing to pay for a property in current market conditions. Typically, an appraiser estimates market value using the comparables method, which estimates the market value of a property by referring to recent selling prices for other properties having similar characteristics.

  • Value-in-use appraisals, also known as use value appraisals, in which the appraiser estimates a property’s value to a particular user. Sometimes a property is dedicated to a particular use or has special benefits. In such cases, a value-in-use appraisal can be lower or higher than a market value appraisal for the same property. For example, a church building has a special purpose that is not accounted for in a market value appraisal.

  • Investment value appraisals, in which the appraiser estimates the value of a property to a particular investor, with the property valued at its highest and best use. Unlike a value-in-use appraisal, the investor is assumed to be making the best use of the property. This appraisal approach usually results in higher values than market value appraisals.

  • Insurance value appraisals, also known as replacement value appraisals, in which the appraiser estimates the amount an insurance company would potentially cover under property insurance if all buildings and fixtures on a property were destroyed. An insurance value appraisal excludes the value of the land. Thus, the insurance value appraisal of a specific property is typically lower than the market value appraisal, value-in-use appraisal, or investment value appraisal.

  • Liquidation value appraisals, in which the appraiser estimates the price that a property would bring if the owners were forced to sell it quickly, under distressed circumstances. An appraised liquidation value for a given property is typically lower than its appraised market value or appraised investment value.

The following chart summarizes the types of real estate appraisals covered in this section.

Type of Appraisal

Basis for Property Valuation

Market Value

Property’s current market price, estimated using comparables method

Value-in-Use

Investment Value

Property’s value to a particular investor, who is assumed to be making the best use of it

Insurance Value

Amount an insurance company would cover under property insurance, which excludes the land’s value

Liquidation Value

Price that a property would bring if its owners were forced to sell it quickly, under distressed circumstances
 

Real Estate Ownership

Real estate ownership provides benefits to investors. Owners can rent out properties and receive rental income. In addition, owners have the potential for capital gains if their properties appreciate in value. A capital gainis the amount by which the selling price of an investment is more than its purchase price.

Real estate also helps with portfolio management. For example, real estate returns are not strongly linked to stock and bond returns. Therefore, real estate ownership diversifies an investment portfolio.

Moreover, real estate properties are attractive assets for investors who want to hedge against inflation. Inflation is a prolonged rise in the average level of prices in an economy that decreases the purchasing power of the economy’s currency. Typically, real estate prices rise during periods of inflation, thus protecting the purchasing power of investors’ capital. You will read in Chapter 4 about the effect that inflation has on investment returns.

As with most investments, real estate also carries risks. Rental income can be unpredictable because property owners may experience vacancies in rentable properties. If an economic downturn occurs, real estate investments can be negatively affected by decreasing property valuations and increasing vacancies. In addition, real estate investments are relatively illiquid because they usually take longer to sell than other types of assets.

 

Mortgage Loans

Some institutional investors supply funds to borrowers through mortgage loans, which borrowers use to purchase properties. The level of protection provided to a lender depends upon whether the mortgage is a recourse loan or a nonrecourse loan:

  • A recourse loan is a mortgage or other secured loan that allows the lender to seek financial damages if the borrower fails to pay the loan, and the value of the property is not enough to cover the outstanding liability. The lender can obtain legal action, known as a deficiency judgment, to enforce collection of the outstanding amount owed from the borrower’s other assets.

  • A nonrecourse loan is a mortgage or other secured loan that allows the lender to seize the property if the borrower fails to pay the loan; the lender can then sell the property to satisfy the outstanding debt. If the property’s value does not entirely satisfy the debt, the contract does not permit the lender to pursue the borrower for the additional funds, and the lender must take a loss. Typically, mortgage loans that life insurance companies hold are nonrecourse loans.

Most lenders for recourse as well as nonrecourse loans expect loan balances to be amortized at a steady rate. Amortization is the reduction of a debt by regular payments of principal and interest that result in full payment of the debt by the maturity date. Mortgage lenders develop amortization schedules for borrowers to repay loans by a given date.

Like bonds, the income collected from a mortgage can provide a predictable stream of cash flows that is a good match with an insurer’s obligations for products that provide periodic income payments, such as payout annuities. However, mortgages tend to be somewhat riskier investments than bonds, and are less liquid than bonds. Moreover, credit rating agencies do not rate mortgages. Therefore, mortgage investors may find it challenging to evaluate the risk of defaults by borrowers.

The two main types of mortgages are residential mortgages and commercial mortgages.

 

Residential Mortgages

A residential mortgage is a loan secured by a single-family home. Residential mortgages can be conventional or nonconventional:

  • A conventional mortgage loan is made on the basis of the borrower’s credit rating and the value of the collateral that is the basis for the mortgage.

  • A nonconventional mortgage loan does not satisfy lender requirements for conventional loans, but does satisfy U.S. government criteria—such as those specified by the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) or Federal Housing Administration (FHA)—and thus qualifies for government-provided mortgage insurance that guarantees the mortgage.

Residential mortgage lenders evaluate potential borrowers for their ability to repay loans. Lenders consider factors such as a borrower’s credit rating and current income to assess the borrower’s risk of defaulting on the loan.

Some borrowers repay their residential mortgage loans before they are scheduled to. When early repayment occurs, lenders receive fewer interest payments than anticipated. The risk associated with the early return of principal for a mortgage is called prepayment risk. Partly because of prepayment risk, insurers that invest in residential mortgages do not usually hold individual mortgage loans.

 

Commercial Mortgages

A commercial mortgage is a loan secured by commercial real estate. Although commercial mortgages can be structured in a variety of ways, a typical commercial mortgage is a nonrecourse, fixed-rate loan with a partial repayment of interest and principal during the loan period, and a balloon payment—a lump-sum payment of the final amount of the mortgage—on a specified date.

Most of the mortgages that insurers hold are commercial mortgages that finance retail stores, shopping centers, office buildings, factories, warehouses, hospitals, and apartment buildings.

 

Real Estate Investment Trusts

Investors can invest indirectly in real estate and mortgages through real estate investment trusts. A real estate investment trust (REIT) is a corporation or trust that uses the pooled capital of a number of investors to purchase and manage real estate property or mortgage loans. Investors sometimes consider REITs to be a separate asset class because of their unique features.

REITs often specialize in a single type of real estate—such as apartment, retail, office, residential, or industrial properties. The two primary types of REITs are

  • Equity REITs, which use capital to purchase income-producing assets, such as apartments or office buildings. The REIT owns each property in the portfolio and is responsible for managing its properties. The REIT produces revenue for investors by collecting lease and rental payments.

  • Mortgage REITs, which invest in loans to borrowers who wish to purchase real estate. A mortgage REIT can invest in individual mortgages or in investment vehicles that represent a group of mortgages. The REIT earns income from the interest on the loans.

Investors purchase shares in a REIT and earn a share of the income that the REIT generates. By law, a REIT must distribute at least 90% of its taxable income to shareholders annually in the form of dividends. Thus, REITs are attractive to investors seeking income-generating investments. In addition, REIT dividends generally offer higher yields than stock dividends.

Another benefit for investors is that REITs use professional real estate managers, who know how to acquire, finance, develop, and renovate properties, and to negotiate leases to get the most return for shareholders.

Compared to other forms of real estate investment, REITs typically offer investors less opportunity for price appreciation. However, REITs provide liquidity and diversification benefits for real estate investors. Therefore, insurers and other institutional investors view REITs favorably.

Some REITs are traded on securities exchanges. A securities exchange is an organized marketplace where members of the exchange buy and sell specific types of securities—such as common stocks and bonds. REITs traded on securities exchanges are called public REITs.

Public REITs tend to be more liquid than private REITs, which are privately traded and limited to institutional investors and other affluent investors. The majority of REITs are private REITs.

Because REITs invest in real estate and mortgages, they share similar risks. For example, a REIT that owns apartment buildings will earn less income if its apartments have to lower rental rates. In addition, REITs may be concentrated in a specific geographic area or type of property. For instance, a REIT that mostly owns regional shopping centers is at risk if such centers lose popularity with consumers.

pages.title: Structured Securities
pages.contents:
Structured Securities

A structured security—also known as structured debt or a structured debt security—is an investment vehicle that repackages pools of existing debt obligations into a new form of financial security that is tradeable and generally promises investors a stream of payments. Because they are tradeable, structured securities are used to provide liquidity to groups of illiquid loans, including mortgages.

In general, structured securities are not traded on exchanges. Most trading of structured securities occurs in over-the-counter (OTC) markets, which are electronic communications networks over which securities that are not bought and sold on an exchange are traded. Typically, securities traded in OTC markets are less liquid than securities traded on exchanges.

As fixed-income investments, structured securities generally provide investors with fairly predictable income payments. Structured securities can also offer higher yields than similarly rated bonds. In addition, structured securities help institutional investors diversify their portfolios.

The risk associated with a particular structured security depends on the credit quality of its loan pool and its repackaging. Furthermore, structured securities are usually less liquid and harder for investors to evaluate than bonds.

 

Securitization

The process of purchasing, combining, and repackaging debt into structured securities is called securitization. Note that while securitization bundles debt to create a new security, the process does not change the riskiness of the underlying pool of debt. Figure 3.1 illustrates the securitization process.

To securitize debt, a loan originator typically creates a special purpose entity. A special purpose entity (SPE), also known as a special purpose vehicle, is a business organization that is formed for a specific purpose and usually for a limited time. The SPE buys a package of loans to be securitized. Then, the SPE takes actions to enhance the credit profile of the structured securities it intends to issue.

As part of credit enhancement, the SPE typically divides the securities into several ownership classes, known as tranches—“tranche” is the French word for slice. Each tranche is a different tier or layer of the structured security, and each represents a distinct packaging of investment traits—such as cash flow patterns, credit quality, investment risks, and priority given to owners.

Although other tranche configurations are possible, most securitized debt has the following four tranches, in order of seniority:

  • The AAA debt tranche is the most senior tranche, meaning it has the highest claim priority on the debt pool’s cash flows. Of all tranches in a structured security, it is the most creditworthy, the first to collect payments from borrowers, and the first to make payments to investors. For these reasons, the interest rate for this tranche of a structured security tends to be lower than on lower tranches of the same security. For the same reasons, investing in this tranche is very attractive to life insurers.

  • The AA debt tranche is the second-most-senior tranche. It is second to collect payments from borrowers, and second to make payments to investors.

  • The A debt tranche—also known as the subordinated debt tranche—is the third tranche and has the lowest priority of the three debt tranches. It is third to collect payments from borrowers, and third to make payments to investors. Because the A debt tranche is considered riskier than the AAA and AA tranches, it tends to have a higher interest rate than the more senior tranches.

  • The equity tranche is the lowest tranche in a structured security. It has last priority for payment relative to other tranches. The equity tranche is considered the riskiest tranche; due to its low payment priority, it is the most likely to be affected by loan defaults and late payments by borrowers. However, it also has the potential to earn the highest rate of return because it receives all remaining cash after the other tranches have received their payments. Thus, if the structured security’s debt pool experiences fewer defaults and late payments than expected, the equity tranche will receive more money than expected.

Structured securities are rated by credit rating agencies. The practice of establishing tranches—some having seniority, while others are subordinated—enhances the credit quality of the senior tranche. Frequently, issuers of structured securities undertake credit enhancements to increase the credit ratings of their securities; higher credit ratings can increase the securities’ appeal to investors.

After establishing tranches, the SPE issues and sells shares in the structured securities to investors, including life insurance companies and other institutional investors. Each structured security represents an ownership interest in the underlying loans. For a fee, the loan originator—or a third party—collects incoming payments on the original loans and distributes the scheduled payouts to the investors in the structured securities.

Securitization creates liquidity for loan originators by enabling them to transfer loans to SPEs. However, the transferring of debt obligations can decrease loan originators’ exposure to default risks, which arguably motivates them to issue more debt than they normally would.

As you will read in Chapter 4, structured securities played a role in the 2007-2008 global financial crisis due to factors such as lower mortgage lending standards, the complexity of securitization, and insufficient risk assessment by credit rating agencies. Since then, structured securities have received more scrutiny from regulators.

Two categories of structured securities are asset-backed securities and mortgage-backed securities.

 

Asset-Backed Securities

An asset-backed security (ABS) is a structured security backed by debt instruments other than real estate mortgages. Lenders use ABSs to convert packages of relatively illiquid loans—such as auto loans, credit card debt (also called credit card receivables), student loans, and home equity loans—into tradeable, liquid securities.

The riskiness of an ABS depends on the creditworthiness of the underlying debts. Therefore, credit rating agencies rate ABS tranches based on creditworthiness, probability of default, and any credit enhancements.

Similar to other structured securities, ABSs provide institutional investors with steady payments. The composition of an ABS’s payment to investors depends on the type of loans involved. The two types of loans packaged in an ABS are

  • Amortizing loans, for which each repayment reflects both principal and interest. Examples of amortizing loans include auto loans and home loans.

  • Nonamortized loans, for which minimum repayments typically consist only of interest, with repayment of principal required by the end of the loan’s term. Examples are credit card debts and commercial mortgage loans with balloon payments.

In the United States, the insurance industry is one of the largest investors in ABSs. The main types of debt backing insurers’ ABSs are auto loans and credit card debt—both of which typically back the most liquid ABSs.

Another ABS of interest to insurers is a collateralized loan obligation (CLO)—a type of ABS that securitizes a pool of corporate debt, such as leveraged loans and other business loans. A leveraged loan, also called a bank loan or a syndicated loan, is a commercial loan characterized by high yields and floating interest rates. Banks give leveraged loans to businesses with a higher risk of default.

 

Mortgage-Backed Securities

Another type of structured security is a mortgage-backed security, which is created when individual mortgages are packaged to form a pool of mortgages. Many life insurers hold more mortgage-backed securities than asset-backed securities.

Like many fixed-income investments, mortgage-backed securities are traded in OTC markets. In general, mortgage-backed securities are more liquid than asset-backed securities. The two classifications of mortgage-backed securities are residential mortgage-backed securities and commercial mortgage-backed securities.

 

Residential Mortgage-Backed Securities

A residential mortgage-backed security (MBS or RMBS)is secured by a pool of residential real estate loans. Like residential mortgages, MBSs are subject to prepayment risk. For example, if economic conditions cause mortgage interest rates to drop, borrowers are likely to refinance—make new borrowing arrangements for a debt—to take advantage of lower interest rates. As a result, MBS investors are likely to receive less income than they expected.

The two primary types of MBSs are agency MBSs and nonagency MBSs. A third type—collateralized mortgage obligations (CMOs)—are created from agency MBSs and high-quality nonagency MBSs.

Agency MBSs—also known as agency mortgage-backed securities—are securities based on portfolios of residential mortgages that meet the guidelines as to credit quality, underwriting standards, and other risk factors set by one of several U.S. government agencies. The three main agencies that participate in the creation of agency MBSs are the

  • Government National Mortgage Association, known as Ginnie Mae

  • Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae

  • Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac

Ginnie Mae explicitly backs its MBSs—comprising pools of federally insured loans—with the full faith and credit of the U.S. government. Because Ginnie Mae guarantees the payment of principal and interest, its MBSs are considered safer than other agency MBSs.

Although agency MBSs from Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are less secure than Ginnie Mae MBSs, the U.S. government has signaled that it will not allow the two entities to fail, thus ensuring they will satisfy their obligations to investors. Because of this “implicit guarantee,” investors consider Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to be government-sponsored enterprises (GSEs).

Nonagency MBSs—also known as nonagency mortgage-backed securities or private-label MBSs—are securities based on portfolios of residential mortgages that do not qualify for agency MBSs. Nonagency MBSs are issued by private business entities—such as investment banks, financial institutions, and home builders. The loans held by nonagency MBSs usually have a higher—sometimes, significantly higher—risk of default than those held by agency MBSs.

A collateralized mortgage obligation (CMO) is a type of mortgage-backed security that is backed by a pool of residential mortgage loans, which are organized into classes based on their risk profile. CMOs typically use a portfolio of agency MBSs and high-quality nonagency MBSs as collateral. Therefore, CMOs are often the result of securitizing multiple MBSs.

Because CMOs typically involve high-quality mortgages or those guaranteed by the government, CMOs generally receive high credit ratings. As such, CMOs are attractive to institutional investors, including life insurers.

In addition, the design flexibility of CMOs means they can be structured to offer a targeted level of risk exposure and can be organized by maturity. Life insurers and other investors with specific cash flow needs can select CMOs that are tailored to their preferences.

Commercial Mortgage-Backed Securities

A commercial mortgage-backed security (CMBS) is secured by a pool of various commercial mortgages. In a CMBS, many single commercial mortgage loans of varying size, property type, and location are pooled and transferred to an SPE. In the SPE, the securities are divided into tranches, which are assigned ratings from credit rating agencies and sold to investors.

Like residential mortgage-backed securities, commercial mortgage-backed securities can be categorized as either agency or nonagency, depending on whether the underlying mortgages meet an agency’s guidelines. Agency CMBSs support certain types of borrowers—such as owners of multifamily properties or health care properties—that are aligned with a particular agency’s public policy goals.

CMBSs issued in the United States have limited prepayment risk because they include make-whole provisions that discourage prepayments. A make-whole provision compensates CMBS holders by requiring the borrower to (1) purchase substitute collateral—usually a portfolio of high-quality securities, such as treasuries—for the CMBS that generates enough cash to replace the cash flows lost because of prepayment, or (2) pay the holders a penalty. As a result, cash flows associated with CMBSs are reasonably predictable.

Insurance companies are major investors in CMBSs. However, insurers typically hold a larger percentage of MBSs in their portfolios than CMBSs.

pages.title: Derivatives
pages.contents:
Derivatives

A derivative is a financial security that derives its investment value from the value of another security. Because a derivative’s value is based on the underlying security’s value, the derivative can be used to hedge against that security’s adverse price movements. As such, investors use derivatives for risk management in portfolios. You will read more in Chapter 8 about how portfolio managers use derivatives.

In addition, derivatives can be used to speculate on an asset’s price movements or to increase leverage. In investing, leverage is the use of borrowing to enhance the potential return of an investment, at the risk of enhancing the potential loss on the investment.

Because derivatives can magnify losses, insurance companies are subject to regulatory restrictions on their investments in derivatives. Derivatives used by insurers and other institutional investors include options, swaps, futures, and forwards.

 

Options

An option is a type of derivative that gives the holder the right to either buy or sell a specified security—such as a stock or bond—at a stated price on or before a specified expiration date. Options give investors an opportunity to (1) reduce the risk of holding the underlying asset or (2) profit from an expected change in the underlying asset’s market value.

One party, known as the option writer, sells an option to an investor, known as the option holder. The option holder purchases the right to buy or sell the underlying security at the strike price. If the holder executes the option, the option writer is contractually obligated to fulfill the transaction at the strike price, regardless of the underlying security’s current market price.

Options contracts are written to last for a certain period of time, such as one year. If the holder does not exercise the option by the expiration date, the contract is closed and has no further value to the holder.

Options are either calls or puts, depending on the rights of the holder:

  • A call option, or call, gives the holder the right—but not the obligation—to buy an underlying security at a specified strike price, on or before the expiration date. To the holder, a call option becomes profitable once the underlying security’s market price rises above the strike price, because the holder can buy the security below its market value.

  • A put option, or put, gives the holder the right—but not the obligation—to sell the underlying security at the strike price on or before the option’s expiration date. To the holder, a put option becomes profitable once the underlying security’s market price drops below the strike price, because the holder can sell the security above its market value.

The following chart summarizes the rights and obligations associated with call options and put options.

When an option holder will realize a profit from exercising the option, the option is in the money. Option writers profit if an option remains out of the money and expires without being exercised.

 

Swaps

A swap, or swap contract, is a derivatives contract in which two parties agree to exchange one asset, liability, security, or cash flow for another. Swap contracts are not standardized; the parties to a swap often negotiate the exact terms of the swap.

Institutional investors commonly use

  • Credit default swaps (CDSs), in which the contract writer promises to pay a benefit to the purchaser if the purchaser experiences the credit default defined in the agreement. In effect, a CDS acts as a form of insurance that protects the purchaser against the risk that the issuer of a security—such as a bond or mortgage-backed security—will default.

  • Interest-rate swaps, which consist of an agreement between two parties to exchange a set of cash flows—typically with one cash flow based on a fixed interest rate and the other based on a variable, or floating, interest rate. Interest-rate swaps generally expire after a specified period of time. Because their assets and liabilities are sensitive to interest rates, life insurers are significant investors in interest-rate swaps.

  • Currency swaps, which are agreements to exchange principal and interest payments on a particular debt instrument payable in one currency for principal and interest payments on a similar debt instrument payable in another currency.

Although institutional investors can reduce certain types of risk by using swaps, they must carefully consider the level of counterparty risk involved. Counterparty riskis the potential that one party to a contract will fail to fulfill its obligations to the other party. Investors face counterparty risk in all financial contracts, but counterparty risk is an especially important concern in swap contracts due to the direct negotiation between the parties.

 

Futures and Forwards

Life insurance companies also use futures and forwards. Futures contracts, or futures, are limited-time agreements that give the owner of the agreement the right to buy or sell a certain asset at a specified future date and price.

Futures were originally established to trade contracts involving commodities, which are products comprising (1) natural resources that have been mined or extracted—such as copper, gold, coal, and oil—and (2) agricultural products and livestock—such as grains, coffee, sugar, and pork. Besides commodities, other assets commonly underlying futures contracts include currencies, market indexes, and interest rates.

Unlike options, which do not impose on the holder the obligation to buy or sell an underlying asset, futures impose on both parties the obligation to complete the transaction involving the underlying asset. However, futures contracts rarely result in the actual delivery of an asset. Investors typically purchase an offsetting futures contract that closes out the initial contract before the initial contract’s delivery date.

A futures contract can be considered a type of bet between two parties and is often used for speculation. Recall the Chapter 1 example of the commodities speculator. The contract that the speculator, Adam, uses to bet on the movement of corn prices is a futures contract. If Adam is wrong about the direction of corn prices, he will incur financial losses.

Similar to futures, forward contracts, or forwards, are limited-time agreements in which a seller promises to deliver a specified asset to a buyer sometime in the future for a price specified in the agreement.

Like swaps, forward contracts are negotiated between parties. Thus, like swaps, forwards expose each party to more counterparty risk than other types of investments.

Futures and forwards are similar, but there are some notable differences:

  • Futures contracts are standardized, while forward contracts are customized.

  • Futures contracts are more regulated than forward contracts.

  • Like options, futures are typically traded on securities exchanges. Like swaps, forwards are typically traded in OTC markets.

pages.title: Alternative Investments
pages.contents:
Alternative Investments

Cash, bonds, and stocks are universally considered traditional investments. Therefore, by definition, an alternative investment is any investment that is not considered a traditional investment. However, the term is subjective, because some investors consider real estate, REITs, and derivatives to be alternative investments, while others consider some or all to be traditional investments. (This text does not categorize real estate, REITs, structured securities, or derivatives as alternative investments.)

Alternative investments can be tangible assets—such as commodities, art, wine, jewelry, coins, baseball cards, and stamps. However, most institutional investors think of hedge funds and private equity funds as the primary types of alternative investments. We explore these in the next sections.

Institutional investors include alternative investments in their portfolios to benefit from these advantages:

Advantages of Alternative Investments

Higher potential returns than they can expect from traditional investments

Unique risk and return characteristics, which offer increased opportunities for diversification

Access to strategies or securities not available elsewhere

However, many alternative investments have potential disadvantages:

Disadvantages of Alternative Investments

Less liquidity than traditional investments

Certain restrictions that limit the ability to liquidate the investment, such as multiyear commitments

Limited information, which makes current market values hard to determine

Demanding requirements for participation, such as a high minimum for the minimum assets under management (AUM)—the amount of money that an advisor or company manages on behalf of a client

Complexity, requiring the investor to perform significant due diligence, which, in the context of investing, is the careful and thorough investigation of a potential investment

Lack of readily accessible data related to historical investment performance

Fewer disclosure requirements than traditional investments

High management fees and transaction costs

Three types of alternative investments that are important to life insurers and other institutional investors are hedge funds, private equity funds, and infrastructure investments.

 

Hedge Funds

A hedge fund is an alternative investment vehicle that (1) is often structured as a limited partnership, (2) pools capital from a limited number of sophisticated investors, and (3) is virtually unlimited in the investment strategies it can pursue. A limited partnership is a business organization that consists of (1) one or more general partners who manage and control a business and are legally liable for all the debts and obligations of the business, and (2) one or more limited partners whose main function is to provide investment capital.

Typically, hedge funds are available only to wealthy individuals and institutional investors and require large initial minimum investments. In addition, hedge funds usually restrict the investor’s ability to get out of the fund, particularly during the period immediately after the investor purchases shares.

Hedge fund participation is limited to sophisticated investors that need less regulatory protection than other investors. Therefore, hedge funds generally face less regulatory oversight and fewer disclosure requirements than other types of investment vehicles.

Because they have fewer regulatory restrictions, hedge funds have the flexibility to engage in a wide range of investment strategies. Most hedge funds focus on a particular fund style that takes advantage of the specialized expertise of their investment professionals.

Hedge funds started out as a means to hedge the risk from holding stocks, hence the fund type’s name. Over time, hedge funds increased their use of leverage to amplify returns. Now hedge funds can use derivatives and leverage to aggressively pursue investment gains and even speculate in markets.

Hedge funds can deliver exceptional returns relative to other types of investments. However, their concentrated bets can expose investors to significant losses. Because concentrated portfolios are less diversified—a concept we explain in Chapter 8—one investment loss could have a large effect on a concentrated hedge fund’s overall return.

 

Private Equity Funds

A private equity fund is an alternative investment vehicle that pools capital from sophisticated investors to invest in private companies. Like hedge funds, private equity funds are typically structured as limited partnerships and are available only to wealthy individuals and institutional investors.

Most private equity funds require a significant initial investment. Furthermore, investments in private equity funds are illiquid, so investors must be prepared to hold their investments for long periods—such as 10 years.

Types of private equity funds include

  • Venture capital funds. A venture capital fund provides capital and management expertise to target companies, such as start-up companies with high growth potential. A venture capital fund typically takes an active role in the growth of the target company by providing advice to management and setting goals for the company to achieve.

  • Leveraged buyout funds. A leveraged buyout fund, also known as an LBO fund, uses debt financing—such as leveraged loans—to purchase shares of target companies. LBO funds buy the outstanding equity of a target company and use the company’s cash flows to make loan payments on outstanding debt until the debt is repaid.

  • Mezzanine debt funds. Mezzanine debt is a type of subordinated debt that also gives the lender an equity stake in the borrowing company. A mezzanine debt fund provides mezzanine debt financing to established, profitable companies seeking funds for expansions, acquisitions, or other growth opportunities.

  • Distressed debt funds. A distressed debt fund, also known as a vulture fund, invests in bonds and other debt securities issued by target companies in financial distress. Distressed debt funds search for securities that are undervalued because of a high risk of default, but possess the potential for significant future returns if default is avoided.

 

Infrastructure Investments

Infrastructure refers to the basic facilities and systems that provide the services necessary for societies and economies to function. In other words, infrastructure comprises the physical structures that support cities, states or provinces, and countries. Examples of such structures include roads, bridges, tunnels, sewers, water supply facilities, cables, telephone wires, and electrical grids.

Traditionally, direct investment in infrastructure is done by governments and interested businesses. For example, an energy company may build a pipeline to expand operational capacity. The pipeline benefits the company by enabling it to generate more revenue. The country where the pipeline is built also benefits from enhancement of its infrastructure.

Many institutional investors already have indirect investments in infrastructure through municipal bonds issued by governments and corporate bonds issued by companies in certain industries. However, institutional investors can directly invest in infrastructure by providing capital for infrastructure projects.

As an investment, infrastructure can provide investors with diversification benefits because the risk and return characteristics are unlike many traditional asset classes. In addition, the cash flows generated by infrastructure are attractive to investors such as life insurers. Life insurers want to hold long-term assets to match cash flows with their long-term liabilities. Many infrastructure projects are long-term and have the potential to “provide stable and secure cash flows for life insurance companies, whose liability structure affords them more flexibility in investing in a relatively illiquid asset.” 1

Like other alternative investments, infrastructure investments are illiquid. Furthermore, investors may have difficulty (1) finding information for proper due diligence and (2) determining asset values for infrastructure assets.

Another aspect for institutional investors to consider is the infrastructure project cycle. Investors have to commit capital at the beginning to initiate the project, but builders need to complete development before investors can start receiving repayment in the form of incoming cash flows.

Types of Investment Funds

An investment fund—known in some countries as a collective investment vehicle—is a type of investment vehicle that pools capital to purchase a portfolio of securities. Investors own shares that represent their portion of the portfolio’s returns.

Collectively, investment funds possess large amounts of capital. Figure 3.3 illustrates the total net assets of investment funds registered in the United States (as of 2017).

Investment funds have the following characteristics:

  • Professional fund management. Investment professionals include fund managers, who select and manage securities according to a fund’s stated strategy, and fund analysts, whose research and analysis activities support fund managers.

  • Diversification. By holding multiple securities, each fund spreads out investment risk. Investors that hold multiple funds have the opportunity to further diversify their investments.

  • Economies of scale. Funds have economies of scale, which are unit cost savings that increase as the size of a business operation grows. In this case, units refer to the fund management services that a fund provides. Because funds have some fixed expenses—such as administration costs—an increase in the portfolio’s asset values generally decreases the fund’s cost relative to the services provided.

  • Designated investment styles. Each fund has a designated investment style that guides the fund’s asset selection and portfolio management strategies. In general, fund managers are required to stick to their fund’s style, although hedge fund managers have more discretion due to the lighter regulatory oversight of hedge funds. We cover fund styles in Chapter 7.

  • Required disclosures. Regulators require most funds to provide potential and current investors with a prospectus, which is a document that describes specific aspects of a fund being offered for sale—such as a fund’s goals, style, managers, expenses, fees, and past performance. The purpose of a prospectus is to provide transparency so that investors can make informed decisions regarding their participation in the fund. Hedge funds are not required to file a prospectus but may provide similar disclosures through an offering memorandum.

Fund investors generally benefit from (1) the expertise of fund managers, (2) access to a broad, diversified investment portfolio, and (3) lower transaction costs—through economies of scale—for a portfolio of securities than if they purchased the securities on their own.

Investment fund types vary in their expense and fee structures. In addition, ownership in each type of fund has different tax implications for investors.

In the previous section, you read about hedge funds. Other types of investment funds include mutual funds, unit investment trusts, and exchange-traded funds.

 

Mutual Funds

A mutual fund is an investment vehicle that pools the funds of investors and uses the funds to buy a diversified portfolio of financial securities. The value of each mutual fund share is determined by calculating the net asset value (NAV), which is the total value of the mutual fund assets—after expenses—divided by the total number of fund shares outstanding, which represents the number of fund shares that shareholders currently own. The NAV is calculated each day after securities markets close.

Before conducting business in the United States, mutual funds must register with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), which is a federal agency responsible for administering and enforcing federal securities laws and regulating the securities industry, as well as for executing policies that affect securities markets. For the purpose of federal securities regulation, mutual funds are legally structured as investment companies, which are entities that issue securities and engage primarily in investing, reinvesting, and trading in securities. As such, mutual funds are registered with the SEC as investment companies.

The investment management firm that registers a particular mutual fund with the SEC is known as the fund sponsor. To avoid confusion between the terms “fund sponsor” and “investment company,” this text only uses the term “investment company” when referring to the technical classification under U.S. securities laws.

Two types of mutual funds are open-end mutual funds and closed-end mutual funds.

 

Open-End Mutual Funds

Most mutual funds are open-end mutual funds. An open-end mutual fund establishes a portfolio of securities with a flexible number of outstanding shares and trades shares directly with investors.

When an investor invests in the fund, the fund issues more shares—thus increasing the total number of outstanding shares. When an investor redeems shares, the fund buys back the investor’s shares—thus decreasing the total number of outstanding shares.

Purchases and redemptions of open-end mutual fund shares are executed once a day, after the market closes. When an investor submits a purchase or redemption order, the price she receives per share is equal to the NAV that was calculated at the end of the day when the order is received. Because investors submit their orders before the NAV is calculated, they do not know the exact price they will receive on the shares they buy or redeem.

 

Closed-End Mutual Funds

A closed-end mutual fund establishes a portfolio of securities with a fixed number of outstanding shares that are traded on securities exchanges or in the OTC market. The fund does not issue new shares and does not redeem outstanding shares.

Investors can trade shares in a closed-end mutual fund at any time while the market is open. Because closed-end mutual fund shares are traded in the marketplace, share prices are determined by market forces instead of by NAV calculations. Therefore, a fund’s shares can trade at a (1) discount when the current market price is below its NAV, or (2) premium when the current market price is above its NAV.

 

Unit Investment Trusts

A unit investment trust (UIT) is a portfolio of securities assembled for a specific investment purpose and held for a designated amount of time. The shares of a UIT are called units. Like mutual funds, UITs are registered with the SEC by a fund sponsor.

UITs share characteristics of open-end and closed-end mutual funds:

  • Like open-end mutual fund investors, UIT investors can redeem units for cash, with the price of a unit equal to the UIT’s NAV.

  • Like a closed-end mutual fund, a UIT issues a fixed number of units; UIT units are issued on the fund’s creation date.

Unlike mutual funds, a UIT has a fixed investment portfolio. The portfolio’s securities holdings are determined prior to the creation date and usually do not change for the life of the UIT. UITs typically focus on bond holdings or stock holdings.

At the time of creation, a UIT establishes a termination date. Upon termination, any securities in the portfolio are sold and the proceeds are distributed to investors.

Based on the Investment Company Act of 1940—which you will learn about in Chapter 10—the SEC considers UITs, like open-end and closed-end mutual funds, to be a form of an investment company. In addition, the SEC typically classifies insurance company separate accounts as UITs because of their legal structure (the full explanation is beyond the scope of this text). Therefore, most separate accounts are registered with the SEC as UITs to comply with the Investment Company Act.

 

Exchange-Traded Funds

An exchange-traded fund (ETF) is a security that usually tracks a market index and trades continuously during the trading day on an exchange. For example, some popular ETFs track a stock market index called the Standard and Poor’s 500 Index—also known as the S&P 500 Index—which consists of 500 of the largest and most widely held companies in the United States.

Initially, ETFs only tracked basic market indexes. Over time, ETFs grew to track a larger number of indexes. In recent years, ETF offerings have expanded beyond indexes. For instance, some ETFs track groups of securities selected by investment professionals.

ETFs share some characteristics with closed-end mutual funds. For example, ETFs trade continuously while markets are open, thus serving as a highly liquid investment vehicle. In addition, an ETF can also trade at a premium or discount to the fund’s NAV.

Closed-end funds and ETFs possess some notable differences:

  • Closed-end funds have a fixed number of outstanding shares, while ETFs do not have a fixed number of shares. Through a process that is beyond the scope of this text, ETFs have the ability to create and redeem shares as needed.

  • Usually, fund managers choose the securities in closed-end funds, while many ETFs are designed to track a market index. In fact, ETFs that track market indexes are judged on how closely they replicate the index’s performance.

  • Closed-end mutual funds are more likely to trade at large premiums or discounts to their NAVs, while ETFs generally trade at prices close to their NAVs.

In general, ETFs have lower expenses and fees than mutual funds holding a similar group of securities. Furthermore, ETFs have the potential for more favorable tax treatment of capital gains.

As more ETF variations have come onto the market, the popularity of ETFs has grown significantly. Many institutional investors—including life insurance companies—hold ETFs in their portfolios.

pages.title: Capital Markets

Capital Markets

As previously stated, capital markets—including stock markets and bond markets—exist to move capital from net suppliers to net users. Capital markets make it easier for capital suppliers and capital users to find each other.

In capital markets, some entities—called participants—play a direct role, while other entities—called influencers—affect the markets without playing a direct role. In addition, some participants play more than one role, depending on the types of transactions in which they engage. The three main participants in capital markets are

  • Suppliers. These entities inject funds into the capital markets through their securities purchases. Retail investors and businesses participate as suppliers in the capital markets. In general, retail investors are indirect suppliers of capital through the financial services products that they purchase. For instance, if you purchase mutual funds for your personal retirement savings account, the funds then purchase securities for their portfolios.

  • Users. These entities draw funds from the capital markets through their securities sales. Typically, businesses and governments are users of capital. They apply the funds raised in capital markets on endeavors expected to provide long-term value.

  • Facilitators. These entities enable buyers and sellers to complete securities transactions. Investment banks are institutions that specialize in underwriting debt and equity offerings and act as intermediaries between issuers of securities and investors. Custodians keep physical or virtual custody of securities, maintain controls, and keep inventories of securities that specific investors presently own. Settlement agents hold securities while a transaction is in progress, ensuring that ownership is formally transferred from the seller to the purchaser only after the purchaser has submitted payment for the securities.

Institutional investors are large suppliers of capital. They collect funds from households, retirement funds, and other businesses. Through their investing activities, they move money into the capital markets. For example, insurance companies collect funds to support their insurance products and insert funds into capital markets through their investment purchases.

Institutional investors can also act as capital users. For instance, stock insurers sell shares of their stock to the public to raise funds for business operations.

By supplying funds to capital markets, investors provide an important service to the global economy. They supply capital needed for productive projects that generate economic growth. Countries with growing economies enable businesses to make more profits. Increasingly profitable businesses can afford to pay employees higher wages and hire new employees. Therefore, capital suppliers contribute to rising standards of living around the world.

Capital suppliers also promote capital efficiency. Excess funds from one part of the world flow to other parts of the world that are in need of financial resources. Both parties benefit from participating in capital markets: suppliers earn better returns on their capital than they could by saving, and users gain access to funding that may not have been available through other means.

pages.title: Capital Market Transactions
pages.contents:
Capital Market Transactions

Capital market transactions between buyers and sellers occur in primary markets and secondary markets. Many transactions occur via exchanges and involve intermediaries.

 

Primary Market

The primary market is the market in which new issues of securities—including stocks and bonds—are sold to investors for the first time. Issuers sell new issues of debt and equity securities directly to investors—mostly institutional investors and financial intermediaries—through the primary market.

The two methods of issuing securities in the primary market are public offerings and private placements.

 

Public Offerings

A public offering is a method of issuing securities in which the security issuer makes a new security available for sale to the public, usually through the services of an investment banking firm. For stocks, the first time a corporation’s stock is offered for sale to the public is called an initial public offering (IPO). Stocks, bonds, and other securities issued by public offering are often called public securities or publicly traded securities.

Many new securities issues require the services of an investment bank. Investment banks provide two broad types of services to issuers:

  • An investment bank underwrites an issue by buying the bonds or stocks from the issuer at a specified price, and then selling the securities to the public at a somewhat higher price. In a firm commitment contract, the bank enters into an agreement to buy all of the newly issued securities from the issuer. By doing so, the bank accepts the risk that it may sell the issue at a price below the price that it paid.

  • An investment bank sells issues of securities on a best efforts basis, in which the bank attempts to sell the new issue on behalf of the issuer on the best terms obtainable, but does not first purchase the bonds or shares from the issuer. The best efforts basis protects the bank in the event that it cannot sell all of the issue. Any unsold shares or bonds are returned to the issuer.

Typically, an issuer and an investment bank agree to either a firm commitment contract or a best efforts contract to complete a new issue. However, some issuers complete new issues without help from an investment bank. For example, the U.S. Treasury Department issues bonds and sells them at regularly scheduled public auctions.

Issuers also use public offerings to issue additional shares of publicly traded securities. Newly issued shares of a security increase the total number of shares outstanding of that security.

 

Private Placements

A private placement is a method of issuing securities in which the issuer sells the security directly to a limited number of qualified investors, typically institutional investors. Stocks, bonds, and other securities issued by private placement are often called private placement securities.

Private placement securities typically face fewer regulatory requirements because regulators assume buyers are capable of evaluating the securities and their corresponding investment risks. For instance, regulators do not require a prospectus for private placements.

Private placements offer the following benefits:

  • Lower transaction costs for issuers because of less extensive regulatory filings.

  • The potential for immediate funding for issuers because transactions are often conducted quickly between highly sophisticated investors.

  • Greater diversification of issuers because a larger quantity and wider variety of potential issuers are available than in the public markets.

  • Institutional investors can potentially earn higher rates of return than would be available from investing only in public securities.

  • Private placement bond investors are protected by covenants that tend to place more requirements on the borrower than do covenants in otherwise comparable publicly offered bonds.

  • Private placement stocks may offer investors a greater share of a company’s equity and higher dividend payments.

Banks, insurance companies, and pension funds are notable investors in private placement securities. For example, private placement bonds make up a significant percentage of the assets in the portfolios of insurance companies.

 

Secondary Markets

A secondary market is a market in which issues of securities are subsequently traded after the initial sale. The bulk of securities trading takes place in secondary markets.

While security prices in the primary market are often set in advance of sales to investors, secondary market prices fluctuate regularly due to market forces, such as changes in overall economic conditions. Prices also move when investor perceptions of a particular security’s value change due to current events or newly available information.

Secondary markets give securities their liquidity because of the large number of participants. When a market has more participants, more opportunities exist for transactions between participants. In addition, more transaction volume in a security means the transaction prices more closely approximate the current market value for the security.

Institutional investors occasionally sell securities in the secondary market by means of a secondary offering. A secondary offering—also known as a secondary distribution—is a sale of a large block of registered securities by a private investor through an investment bank, typically at a set price. Generally, the securities that institutional investors sell in a secondary offering were previously acquired in a private placement.

 

Exchanges

A security that is traded on a particular exchange is said to be listed on that exchange. Issuers must meet the listing requirements of a particular exchange in order for their security to be traded on the exchange.

Different types of stock exchanges have certain methods for matching buyers with sellers:

  • Auction-based markets. A trade occurs in an auction-based market if the highest bid price equals the lowest ask price. The bid price is the price a buyer is willing to pay for a share, and the ask price is the price at which a seller is willing to sell a share. If the highest bid price is less than the lowest ask price, no trade occurs. Watch Video 3.2 to see an example of a trade in an auction-based market. In the United States, the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) is primarily an auction-based network.

  • Dealer-based markets. In a dealer-based market, dealers act as market makers. A market maker is a securities dealer that holds an inventory of a particular stock and stands ready to buy and sell shares of that stock continuously at the published bid and ask prices. Dealers publicly post bid and ask prices for the securities in their inventory. In a dealer-based market, buyers and sellers can conduct trades immediately because market makers agree to trade at published bid and ask prices. In the United States, the National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotations (Nasdaq) is an example of a dealer-based market.

  • Alternative electronic markets. Alternative electronic markets allow buyers and sellers to conduct trades directly with each other. Traders place orders in an electronic trading network, and the network automatically matches buy and sell orders whenever possible. Large institutions can use alternative electronic markets to resell private placement securities to other qualified institutions.

Investment vehicles offer investors several types of possible returns, which, in turn, are influenced by multiple factors. To determine the success of their investments, investors monitor their investment returns, which they can measure using different methods.

All investing activities involve some element of risk. Institutional investors need to balance their pursuit of returns with their responsibility to manage risks. Some risks apply to entire markets, while others apply to specific assets.

In this chapter, you will learn about return and risk concepts. First, you will read about types of investment returns and see how different factors influence returns. Next, you will learn about some of the ways that investors measure returns and investment risk. Finally, you will read about certain risks that are relevant to life insurance company investments.

pages.title: Types of Investment Returns
pages.contents:
Types of Investment Returns

As stated in earlier chapters, the two primary sources of positive investment returns are price appreciation and income payments, the latter of which can come in the form of interest, dividends, or rental income.

When an asset’s market price changes, the owner of the asset faces two possible outcomes. The owner of an asset whose price has

  • Appreciated since purchase has an unrealized capital gain, or paper gain

  • Depreciated since purchase has an unrealized capital loss, or paper loss

An unrealized gain (or loss) represents the potential gain (or loss) that the investor would experience if she sold the asset at the current market price. Once the investor actually sells the asset, the unrealized gain (or loss) becomes a realized gain (or realized loss).

Investors can calculate their returns on individual investments based on their (1) realized gains and losses or (2) unrealized gains and losses. Investment portfolios usually combine the realized gains/losses and unrealized gains/losses of their holdings to report portfolio returns.

 

Capital Gains

Recall that an investor realizes a capital gain when he sells an asset at a higher price than his purchase price. By realizing a capital gain, an investor turns a potential profit into an actual profit. The actual profit is taxable as income. Typically, unrealized capital gains are not taxable income.

For tax purposes, capital gains are categorized by the length of time the owner held the asset:

  • Capital gains on assets held for one year or less before being sold are called short-term capital gains.

  • Capital gains on assets held for longer than one year before being sold are called long-term capital gains.

Typically, governments tax short-term capital gains at higher rates than long-term capital gains to discourage short-term investing and encourage long-term investing.

The tax rates for capital gains vary by country. Some countries tax capital gains at higher rates than other forms of income, such as wages; other countries tax capital gains at equal or lower rates than other forms of income.

Capital gains taxes reduce the actual profits that investors receive from realizing capital gains. Thus, an important aspect of portfolio management is managing tax exposure to maximize investment returns.

Certain investment vehicles—such as real estate, stocks, and funds that invest in stocks—are more likely to expose an investor to capital gains and capital gains taxes. For example, some mutual funds buy and sell stocks multiple times throughout the year and distribute capital gains to fund investors on a recurring basis, such as quarterly or annually. As a result, the fund investors have to pay income taxes on the fund’s capital gains. Therefore, many fund investors consider the likelihood of holding turnover—and the resulting tax liabilities—when investing in a mutual fund.

For an investor, realizing a capital gain is one type of taxable event. In the context of investing, a taxable event is an investment transaction that results in taxable income. Investors also experience taxable events by receiving income payments such as interest, dividends, or rental income.

 

Income Payments

As you learned in previous chapters, investors can receive payments of interest, dividends, or rental income from certain investments. The following chart provides examples of investment vehicles that are sources of income payments.

For fixed-income securities and other debt assets, individual interest payments depend on factors unique to the asset—such as the issuer’s credit rating, the amount of the debt, and the debt’s interest rate. A particular debt asset’s interest rate is also influenced by market interest rates, as you will learn shortly.

Investors may receive dividend payments from companies that choose to distribute a portion of their profits directly to shareholders of their stocks. The amount of a particular dividend payment depends on the number of shares held and the declared dividend rate. Whether a company pays a dividend depends on many factors. For example, high-growth companies usually do not pay dividends because they are directing capital into growth projects that they expect to deliver more value to shareholders than dividend payments. In addition, companies must maintain profitability to sustain dividend payments, so a dividend-paying company that is struggling financially may cut or suspend dividend payments and use the money to address cash shortfalls.

The amount of REIT dividends paid to investors depends on the amount of income taken in from the properties owned by the trust.

Investors that own real estate properties can collect income in the form of rent and lease payments. How much income an individual property generates depends on the type of property, the amount of space rented out, the property’s appraised value, the property’s location, and economic factors—such as market interest rates and rental rates of comparable local properties.
