pages.title: Factors Influencing Investment Returns
pages.contents:
Factors Influencing Investment Returns

Many factors influence investment returns. Some factors are specific to an individual investment, such as the issuer’s credit quality. One important factor for each investment is an asset’s price—particularly the price the investor pays at the time of purchase.

Other factors that influence investment returns affect certain asset classes or entire markets. Some of the broad economic factors that influence insurance company investment returns are interest rates, inflation, and the business cycle.

You will notice that some of these factors are interrelated. For example, interest rates and the business cycle often influence each other. Therefore, isolating the effect of a particular factor on an investment can be challenging. However, you need to understand these basic factors before you encounter investment risks later in this chapter.

Investment returns are also affected by taxes and transaction fees. For simplicity, we ignore these factors when discussing investment return measurement later in this chapter.

 

Prices and Yields

One of the most significant factors in determining the return of an investment is the price that the investor paid at the time of purchase. For instance, two investors who sell the same quantity of the same asset at the same sale price will experience different capital gains (or losses) if they paid different purchase prices.

EXAMPLE

Wayne O’Connell sold 100 shares of Hattime Corporation at $50 per share for a total of $5,000, or 100 x $50. He originally bought all of the shares at one time and paid $35 per share, for a total purchase cost of $3,500, or 100 x $35. Therefore, his capital gain on the stock is $1,500, calculated as $5,000 – $3,500, not including transaction costs.

Maureen Callahan also sold 100 shares of Hattime Corporation at $50 per share for a total of $5,000, or 100 x $50. However, she bought her shares five months before Wayne. She originally bought all of her shares at one time and paid $20 per share, for a total purchase cost of $2,000, or 100 x $20. Her capital gain on the stock is $3,000, calculated as $5,000 – $2,000, not including transaction costs.

Analysis: Because Maureen purchased her shares of Hattime at a lower price than Wayne, she realized a larger capital gain, even though both investors sold the same number of shares of the same stock at the same price and at the same time.

In addition to determining the size of a capital gain (or loss), the purchase price also determines the yield an investor can expect to earn on an investment. As you will read in Chapter 7, using yields to compare different assets helps investors evaluate and select investments.

For a bond, the yield to maturity (YTM) is the rate of return a bondholder will earn if he holds a bond until maturity. Although the calculation for the YTM is beyond the scope of this text, you should know that the calculation typically uses a bond’s current market price to determine the total rate of return on all cash flows received until maturity.

If an investor buys a bond at a price below or above par value, the YTM is greater or lower than the bond’s coupon rate. The following insight illustrates this principle.

INSIGHT

Note that if an investor buys the bond at

  • $98—at a discount to par value—the YTM is higher than the bond’s coupon rate
  • $100—at par value—the YTM equals the coupon rate
  • $102—at a premium to par value—the YTM is lower than the coupon rate

Investors may find other variations of YTM calculations useful for bonds with certain characteristics. For example, using YTM to evaluate a callable bond overlooks the risk that the issuer may retire the bond before the maturity date. In this case, the investor could look at the bond’s yield to call (YTC), which calculates the yield earned if the bond is held until the first call date. Because the YTC could be higher or lower than the YTM, a more conservative calculation, yield to worst, calculates the lowest possible yield while considering both call and maturity dates.

Bond investors do not always hold their bonds until maturity. In this case, an investor may want to calculate a bond’s yield for a shorter length of time, such as one year. To determine a bond’s one-year yield, investors calculate its current yield, which is the amount of annual interest received from a bond stated as a percentage of the current market price. The formula for the current yield of a bond is

 
Current yield = Annual coupon payment
Current market price

 

Because the current yield formula only considers a bond’s annual coupon payment, the yield signifies the return a bond investor would receive if she plans to hold the bond for one year. Like the YTM, an investor can perform a new calculation of a bond’s current yield whenever the current market price changes.

EXAMPLE

A bond with a $1,000 par value pays a 4% coupon rate, which means the bond’s annual coupon payment is $40, found as $1,000 x 0.04. Suppose the market price of the bond is $900 today, rises to $950 tomorrow, and drops to $850 one month from now. The current yields at each time are calculated as follows:

Analysis: When the bond’s current market price rose, its current yield fell. Conversely, when the bond’s price fell, its current yield rose. Thus, the bond’s yield is a function of its price.

Another observation is that the bond’s coupon rate and coupon payments did not change, even though the yield changed each time the market price changed. In addition, because all three calculations occur when the bond is trading at a discount to par value, all three current yields are higher than the 4% coupon rate.

As you can see from the YTM and current yield examples, an asset’s price and its yield generally move in opposite directions—meaning that they have an inverse relationship.

Using market prices, investors can calculate yields for many types of income-generating investments—including bonds, real estate properties, stocks, REITs, mutual funds, and ETFs.

 

Market Interest Rates

Market interest rates establish the cost of borrowing money in a given market. For lenders, interest rates represent the rates of return that they expect when they lend to borrowers. Lenders charge higher rates when the prospect of repayment by borrowers is less certain, and they charge lower rates to borrowers that are more likely to repay their debts.

Interest rates affect the actions of borrowers in an economy. Low interest rates spur economic growth by encouraging borrowing. A low cost of borrowing helps borrowers raise capital for new projects. As interest rates rise, the cost of borrowing increases, which discourages borrowing. If interest rates rise high enough, borrowers cut back on assuming debt to initiate new projects.

Besides encouraging borrowing, lower interest rates provide an incentive for consumers to decrease saving and increase debt-fueled consumption. For example, when rates are low enough, you may decide to take out an auto loan to buy the new car you have wanted. As rates increase, taking out a loan becomes less appealing.

Higher interest rates encourage saving because people and businesses earn a better rate of return on money put into savings than when rates are lower. Because saving is less risky than other uses of capital, saving is an appealing option for many.

In addition, higher interest rates increase the rate of return that a project has to earn to justify investing capital instead of saving it and earning the market interest rate. When interest rates are higher, fewer projects are able to provide a rate of return in excess of the market interest rate and project investment generally decreases.

Many institutional investors allocate capital to multiple asset classes and move capital between asset classes as market conditions change. Movements in market interest rates are one condition that can cause some asset classes to become more appealing than others.

 

Central Banks

Most countries have a central banking system or monetary authority that develops and oversees the country’s monetary policies, including the country’s desired interest rate. A monetary policy is the strategy that a country’s monetary authority uses to stabilize the economy by increasing or decreasing the supply of money. Generally, a central bank uses monetary policy to affect growth and the rate of inflation in its local economy.

A country’s central bank does not directly control market interest rates. Rather, the central bank sets a benchmark interest rate, and banks and other financial institutions set the interest rates they charge in the marketplace in relation to the benchmark interest rate. As such, market interest rates adjust in response to central bank changes to the benchmark interest rate.

In the United States, the Federal Reserve is the central bank responsible for conducting monetary policy. The Federal Reserve sets the federal funds rate (or fed funds rate), which is (1) the rate banks pay when borrowing from other banks and (2) the benchmark interest rate in the United States.

By raising the federal funds rate, the Federal Reserve increases borrowing costs for banks, thus indirectly decreasing the amount of money they have to lend to potential borrowers. For the Federal Reserve, raising the federal funds rate is part of a contractionary monetary policy, which decreases the growth of the money supply and the amount of credit available in the economy.

When the Federal Reserve lowers the federal funds rate, banks effectively have more money that they can use for lending to borrowers in the economy. In lowering the federal funds rate, the Federal Reserve is conducting an expansionary monetary policy,which increases the growth of the money supply and the amount of credit available in the economy.

Central banks influence market interest rates to increase or decrease economic activity. The intention of contractionary monetary policy is to keep an economy from growing at an unsustainably high rate by slowing economic growth. The intention of expansionary monetary policy is to spur economic growth by easing borrowing costs.

 

Effect on Investments

Interest rates affect an economy’s growth prospects, which also affect security valuations. For example, if rising interest rates result in increased borrowing costs for companies, the companies may (1) have a harder time making payments on their debts, which can hurt the market values of their issued bonds and (2) become less profitable, which hurts the market values of their issued stock shares. Falling rates generally have the opposite effect, making it easier for companies to make debt payments and devote capital to value-generating projects.

Changes to market interest rates do not have the same effect on all investments. Typically, fixed-income investments are more sensitive to interest-rate changes than equity investments. For example, when market interest rates

  • Rise, prices of existing bonds generally fall. Existing bond market values fall because new bond issues of a similar credit quality will pay investors higher coupon rates than existing bonds, which typically makes holding existing bonds less appealing.

  • Fall, prices of existing bonds generally rise. Existing bond market values rise because new bond issues of a similar credit quality will pay investors lower coupon rates than existing bonds, which typically makes holding existing bonds more appealing.

Because insurance companies typically have significant bond holdings in their investment portfolios, they closely follow interest-rate changes. Later in this chapter, we describe how interest rates pose risks to insurers’ investment returns and profitability.

The effect of market interest-rate changes on the prices of stocks is not as clear-cut as on bond prices. Companies in some stock market sectors—categories comprising companies in a particular industry that carry out a similar function within the broader industry—are more sensitive to interest rates than other sectors. For instance, rising interest rates are usually beneficial for financial sector stocks because financial services companies can earn more interest from their lending activities. As another example, falling interest rates are beneficial for the stocks of companies involved in construction and home improvement because low rates spur consumer demand for house purchases and upgrades.

Interest-rate changes also affect how investors allocate capital among asset classes. For example, when interest rates are low or falling, investors seeking income-generating investments may not realize a sufficient return by investing in bonds. These investors may turn to bond proxies, which are equity investments that can “act” like bonds by earning reasonably stable returns while earning higher yields than bonds. Two examples of assets that investors consider to be bond proxies are high-yield dividend-paying stocks and REITs. As interest rates rise, bonds become more attractive, and income-seeking investors are likely to move money from bond proxies back into bonds. At the same time, the decreased demand for bond proxies typically decreases their market values.

 

Yield Curves

Because interest-rate changes have a strong effect on the market values and yields of bonds, investors pay attention to the direction and intensity of interest-rate movements. Investors assess the impact of interest rates on bond yields by studying changes to the term structure of interest rates, which is the relationship between interest rates on bonds of the same credit quality but with different maturities.

The term structure of interest rates is represented visually by a yield curve—also known as a debt curve or a bond curve—which is a line graph that illustrates the relationship between the yields of debt securities and the maturities of those securities. A yield curve shows yield and term-to-maturity relationships at a given point in time.

To illustrate the yield curve for bonds in a given country, investors use government bonds. For example, in the United States, the yields of Treasuries typically provide the basis for a yield curve. In other countries, the basis for yields comes from debt securities issued by that country. As such, a sovereign yield curve, also called a sovereign debt curve or sovereign interest curve, refers to a yield curve representing the term structure of interest rates for a non-U.S. country.

The vertical axis of a yield curve represents yields and the horizontal axis represents maturities. As shown in Figure 4.1, yield curves generally take one of three shapes:

  • Normal. A normal yield curve shows an upward slope from left to right, indicating that yields on long-term debt securities are higher than yields on short-term debt securities. Investors require higher yields as the term to maturity increases to compensate for the increased risks of holding bonds for longer periods.

  • Flat. A flat yield curve shows a horizontal straight line, which indicates that yields on debt securities are not responsive to varying terms to maturity.

  • Inverted. An inverted yield curve shows a downward slope from left to right, indicating that yields on short-term debt securities are higher than yields on long-term debt securities.

In a normal yield curve, the degree, or intensity, of the slope—flattish, slightly upward, or sharply upward—indicates investors’ expectations for short-term yields and long-term yields. Higher long-term yields signal that investors expect interest rates to rise, which will decrease bond market values and increase bond yields. A normal yield curve also signals expectations of healthy economic growth, as rising interest rates are generally associated with periods of rising economic growth.

Investors compare yield curves from different dates to analyze the trends in a curve’s movements. A normal yield curve that starts to flatten—with rising short-term yields and falling long-term yields—could signal that investors expect a slowing rate in the pace of future interest-rate increases. A flat or practically flat yield curve signals that investors do not expect future interest-rate increases or cannot determine the direction of future interest-rate changes.

An inverted yield curve occurs when short-term yields rise above long-term yields. An inverted yield curve could indicate that investors expect interest rates to fall in the future. A jump in short-term rates could also signal that financing has become difficult for borrowers to obtain. Many investors see an inverted yield curve as a sign of an impending economic recession—a period of significant decline in economic activity, lasting more than a few months—because interest rates fall when an economy is weak.

In addition, an inverted yield curve changes investors’ attitudes toward owning long-term bonds. The prospect of decreasing interest rates encourages bond investors to buy bonds with longer terms to maturity, thus ensuring their portfolios will (1) hold bonds with higher coupon rates than those of newly issued bonds in the lower interest-rate environment and (2) benefit from increases in bond market values when market interest rates fall. Therefore, bonds with longer terms to maturity become more desirable than bonds with shorter terms. Decreased demand for short-term bonds decreases their market values, which increases their yields.

 

Inflation

Inflation is generally described as a steady increase in prices over time, which erodes the value of money, also known as money’s purchasing power. The rate of inflation expresses the percentage increase in the prices of goods and services during a specific period—typically one year—in a given economy. However, the rate of inflation can vary, resulting in

  • Hyperinflation, which is a rapid and unsustainable increase in prices in an economy over a period of time

  • Disinflation, which is a decrease in the rate of inflation; in other words, the rate of price increases is slowing over a period of time

  • Deflation, which is the decline in the general level of prices in an economy over a period of time

One of the goals of the Federal Reserve and other central banks is to stabilize the rate of price increases in their economies by moderating the year-to-year rate of inflation. (In addition, moderate rates of inflation are typically associated with steady rates of economic growth.) According to economic theory, increases in the supply of money in an economy can lead to increased inflation in that economy. Therefore, by influencing market interest rates—which affect the supply of money in an economy—central banks should be able to affect inflation rates. In reality, consistently achieving a desired change in the rate of inflation is challenging for any central bank.

Because inflation erodes the value of money in an economy, it can have a meaningful effect on debt securities, such as bonds and mortgages. In an inflationary environment, the burden—from the perspective of borrowers—of a debt amount erodes as the value of money erodes. Over time, the interest payments made by borrowers represent diminishing monetary value for lenders. Therefore, inflation becomes more important the longer an investor holds a debt security. In a deflationary environment, debt represents a greater burden for borrowers and a greater return for lenders.

In addition, the presence of inflation requires an investor to earn a rate of return greater than or equal to the expected inflation rate in order to avoid losing purchasing power. Investors select certain types of assets to act as hedges against inflation. As discussed in Chapter 2, real estate is a popular inflation hedge because property values generally rise as other prices rise in an economy.

The value of an investment return is affected by the value of money. As such, an investment’s rate of return in a particular year can be adjusted by the rate of inflation in that year. The stated rate of return on an investment without adjustment for inflation or other factors is called the nominal rate of return. The rate of return on an investment after adjustment for inflation is called the real rate of return. After adjusting for each year’s rate of inflation, an investor can compare real rates of return from different periods to evaluate an investment’s actual performance over a period of time. The formula for the real rate of return is

Real rate of return = Nominal rate of return – Inflation rate

The above formula is commonly used to approximate the real rate of return. Although there is another version of the formula that provides a more precise calculation, the above formula is simpler and more intuitive. Thus, when calculating the real rate of return later in this chapter, we use the version of the formula stated above.

 

The Business Cycle

The business cycle is a recurring pattern of fluctuations in economic activity that is characterized as expansion, peak, contraction, and trough. Phases of the business cycle can last for months or years. The following insight provides more information about the four phases of the business cycle.

INSIGHT

The Phases of the Business Cycle

Expansion: The phase in the business cycle in which unemployment is low and the pace of economic growth is accelerating.

Peak: A point in the business cycle when economic growth stabilizes and then begins to decline; the phase after expansion and before contraction.

Contraction: A phase in the business cycle in which unemployment rises and the pace of economic activity slows down. Note that recessions and depressions only occur during the contraction phase. While economists differ in their technical definitions, a recession is generally an economic downturn lasting between a few months and a couple of years. A depression is generally a severe economic downturn that lasts for a period of at least two years. Depressions are less frequent than recessions; therefore, most economic downturns during the contractionary phase tend to be recessions.

Trough: A point in the business cycle when conditions stabilize after the end of a significant decline in economic activity; the phase after contraction and before expansion.

Generally, the business cycle indicates whether a given economy is increasing or decreasing its production of goods and services. Economic activity grows during the expansion phase and shrinks during the contraction phase. The economic growth rate stabilizes and then changes direction at the peak and trough phases; growth begins to fall after the peak phase and begins to rise after the trough phase.

Investors monitor the phases of the business cycle to help them determine how to allocate their capital. During the expansionary phase of the business cycle, security valuations usually rise as businesses profit from increases in economic activity. The market values of some assets—such as stocks and real estate—can appreciate significantly, which makes them more appealing to investors. During the contractionary phase, the weakening economy usually prompts investors to seek out conservative investments, such as bonds and dividend-paying stocks.

The relationship between interest rates, inflation, and the business cycle is complex. For example, sometimes the increases in economic activity and the rate of inflation can prompt a rise in interest rates. Other times, inflation and economic activity respond to interest-rate changes. All three are dynamic market forces that react to each other.

pages.title: Measuring Investment Returns
pages.contents:
Measuring Investment Returns

Investors can measure investment returns for individual investments and investment portfolios. For the sake of simplicity, this chapter focuses on measuring returns of individual investments.

An investment return for a specific period can be expressed as a monetary amount or a percentage. To find the rate of return—which is expressed as a percentage—the investor divides the monetary amount of the return by the principal amount of the investment, as represented in the following formula:

Rate of return = Amount of return × 100
Principal amount

EXAMPLE

Eliza Dawson invested a principal amount of $10,000 in a mutual fund. After one year, the fund earned a return in the amount of $750. The rate of return on Eliza’s investment is 7.5%, calculated as follows:

Rate of return = Amount of return × 100
Principal amount
 
  = $750 × 100
$10,000
  = (0.075) x 100 = 7.5%

Many investors express investment returns using rates of return. By using a percentage rate to represent their returns, investors can easily compare rates of return from a variety of investments—regardless of the differences in the type of asset, amount invested, or location of the investment.

Often, the expressed rate of return is the nominal rate of return. However, in periods of high inflation, the real rate of return is a better indicator of an investment’s growth in value. To find the real rate of return for a given period, investors need to adjust for the rate of inflation in that period.

EXAMPLE

In 2018, Algravita Fund Company earned a nominal rate of return of 8.5% on its investment portfolio. If the rate of inflation for 2018 was 2.0%, then Algravita’s real rate of return in 2018 was 6.5%, found as 8.5% – 2.0%.

 

Total Return

For a single investment or an investment portfolio, the total return is the sum of all returns—including all income as well as all realized and unrealized gains or losses—from the investment over a given period, typically one year. For performance measurement, total return is usually presented as a percentage. The formulas to express total return as an amount and a percentage are

Amount of total return = Income received + Realized gain/loss + Unrealized gain/loss
Rate of total return = Amount of total return x 100
Principal amount

EXAMPLE

Laila Gregovich purchased $10,000 worth of shares of Lauticoal Company stock. Laila did not sell any shares for one year. After one year, her shares were worth $11,000. During the year, she also received $200 in dividend payments on her Lauticoal stock. Laila wants to calculate the rate of total return she received on her Lauticoal shares over the course of the year.

Analysis: First, Laila calculates her unrealized gain of $1,000, found as $11,000 – $10,000. Because she did not sell any shares, she does not have a realized gain.

Next, she calculates the amount of the total return for the year:

Amount of total return = Income received + Realized gain/loss + Unrealized gain/loss
  = $200 + $0 + $1,000
  = $1,200

Using the amount of her total return, Laila calculates her rate of total return:

Rate of total return = Amount of total return x 100
Principal amount
  = $1,200 x 100
$10,000
  = (0.12) x 100 = 12%

In addition to measuring individual asset returns, institutional investors measure investment portfolio returns. For a portfolio, total return encompasses all sources of return for all assets in a portfolio. Calculating total return for a diversified portfolio can be complex and may not be the best tool for measuring the performance of institutional portfolios. We discuss other measures of portfolio returns in Chapter 9.

 

Required Return

Investors use historical returns to estimate future returns for assets. A historical return, also known as an actual return, is a known investment performance result for a given period. A historical return can be expressed as a monetary amount or a percentage rate of return.

Using an asset’s historical returns, an investor estimates the probability that the asset’s future return will match its historical return. The investor also assigns probabilities based on a study of market and economic factors affecting the investment. Using these probabilities, the investor calculates the expected return, which is the estimated future return—expressed as a monetary amount or a percentage rate of return—that an investor anticipates earning from an investment.

Theoretically, the expected rate of return of an asset must meet or exceed an investor’s required rate of return before the investor will invest in the asset. The required rate of return is the annual rate of investment return an investor requires as reasonable compensation for a given level of risk and to satisfy the investor’s objectives. The formula for required rate of return is

Required rate of return = Inflation rate + Risk - free rate of return + Risk premium

The required rate of return is calculated as the sum of the inflation rate and an investment’s

  • Risk-free rate of return, which is the rate of return on a “risk-free” investment—that is, the least risky investment opportunity available in the market. In the United States, investors commonly use the current interest rate on a three-month U.S. Treasury bill to represent the risk-free rate because they consider it unlikely that the government would default on its payments. In other countries, the current interest rates of short-term sovereign bonds that are highly stable and have almost no risk of default can serve as the risk-free rate of return.

and

  • Risk premium, which is the portion of the rate of return in excess of the risk-free rate of return. The risk premium is required to compensate an investor for taking the extra risk associated with a specific type of investment. Typically, the risk premium for an equity security is higher than the risk premium for a debt security.

EXAMPLE

Bernard Westhaus, an investment analyst, is assessing a potential purchase of Lauticoal Company stock for his company’s investment portfolio. He wants to determine whether buying Lauticoal shares is appropriate for his company by comparing the stock’s expected rate of return to his company’s required rate of return for stocks.

Bernard estimates that the expected rate of return on Lauticoal’s shares is 10% annually. The current annual inflation rate is 1% and the risk-free rate is 2%. Bernard’s company has calculated the risk premium on stocks to be 5%.

Analysis:

Required rate of return = Inflation rate + Risk - free rate + Risk premium
  = 1% + 2% + 5%
  = 8%

The 10% expected rate of return on Lauticoal shares is greater than the company’s 8% required rate of return on stocks. Therefore, Bernard can consider recommending a purchase of Lauticoal Company shares to his portfolio manager.

Based on their objectives, investors can have different values for required rates of return. For an institutional investor, an organizational value for the required rate of return takes into account the organization’s growth goals and the minimum rate of return needed to sustain the business.

 

Varying Time Periods

Investment returns can be measured over the entire time an investment is held, or measured over a uniform time period—typically one year. Three types of return calculations that depend on the time period used are holding period return, arithmetic mean annual return, and annualized return.

 

Holding Period Return

For an individual investment, an investor’s holding period is the length of time that the investor owns the investment. The holding period return, also known as holding period rate of return, is the rate of return on an investment over the entire period of owning the investment. Typically, investors calculate the holding period return for investments that they held for less than a full year. Expressed as a percentage, the holding period rate of return formula is

Holding period rate of return = Amount of total return for the period x 100
Principal amount

EXAMPLE

Sabrina invested $5,000 into a mutual fund. One month later, Karl invested $1,000 into the same mutual fund. Three months later, Sabrina and Karl sold their investments.

Over four months, Sabrina received a total return amount of $175. Her holding period rate of return is 3.5%, calculated as follows:

Holding period rate of return = Amount of total return for the period x 100
Principal amount
  = $175 x 100
$5,000
  = (0.035) x 100 = 3.5%

Over three months, Karl received a total return amount of $25. His holding period rate of return is 2.5%, calculated as follows:

Holding period rate of return = Amount of total return for the period x 100
Principal amount
  = $25 x 100
$1,000
  = (0.025) x 100 =2.5%  
 

Arithmetic Mean Annual Return

The arithmetic mean annual return is the average return—usually expressed as a percentage rate of return—of a series of annual investment returns during a multiyear holding period. The formula for calculating arithmetic mean annual return for an investment is

Arithmetic mean annual return = Year 1 return + Year 2 return + . . . Final year return
Total number of years

EXAMPLE

Algravita Fund Company held an investment for four years. The investment earned the following annual rates of return:

Year 1

Year 2

Year 3

Year 4

4%

1%

7%

12%

Over four years, the arithmetic mean annual return—expressed as a rate of return—of Algravita’s investment was 6%, calculated as follows:

Arithmetic mean annual return = Year 1 return + Year 2 return + Year 3 return + Year 4 return
Total number of years
  = (4% + 1% + 7% + 12%)
4
  = 24%
4
  = 6%

The arithmetic mean annual return can be misleading because the calculated value implies a steady rate of return for each year. In reality, the rates in some years may be close to the calculated average, while rates in other years may deviate significantly from the average.

The arithmetic mean annual return is a simple calculation that does not indicate the variability of returns in relation to the calculated average. Thus, the measure is not commonly used in investment performance calculations. Later in this chapter, we introduce a measure that uses the arithmetic mean to indicate the variability of returns.

 

Annualized Return

An annualized return, also known as a yearly rate of return or an annual rate of return, is a rate of return calculation that expresses a return for a period longer than a year as a rate of return for one whole year. The formula for annualized return is beyond the scope of this text, but it involves accounting for the effect of compounding returns.

Annualized returns are not the same as annual returns, which are measured over a period of one year. Annualization is an adjustment to transform a rate of return for a longer period into a one-year rate of return. Annualizing returns helps investors compare the returns of investments held for different lengths of time.

Technically, one could annualize a return for a period of less than one year. However, certain international investment performance reporting standards—which we introduce in Chapter 5—specify that returns for periods of less than one year should not be annualized.

pages.title: Volatility as a Measure of Investment Risk
pages.contents:
Volatility as a Measure of Investment Risk

As previously mentioned, many investment return measures do not indicate the likelihood that a particular investment’s rate of return in a given year will match the investment’s historical average rate of return. In other words, investors need a way to measure how much to expect an investment’s rate of return to vary from year to year. Turning to statistics, volatility is a measure of the tendency for a value to fluctuate over a specified time period.

Investors can use volatility to describe price movements, but in this chapter, we focus on its application to returns. In the context of investment returns, volatility measures the tendency for an investment’s rate of return to fluctuate from year to year, as indicated by the investment’s historical rates of return over a specified time period.

Many investors purchase an asset expecting to get a rate of return similar to the asset’s historical rate of return. However, an investment with high volatility can produce a single-year rate of return that deviates significantly from the expected rate of return. Investments with low volatility have a low range of variability in year-to-year rates of return. Thus, the returns of low-volatility investments are more predictable than the returns of high-volatility investments.

Volatility introduces investment risk in the form of uncertainty. The level of volatility of an asset indicates the level of uncertainty that asset owners will receive an actual rate of return that comes close to the expected rate of return. With a more volatile asset, asset owners have a higher risk that actual returns will be different from expected returns. While asset volatility means that an investor might not receive the average return in a given year, the investor does receive the potential to earn above-average returns in any given year.

People tend to think of “risk” in terms of downside potential or possible negative outcomes. For investment returns, risk is the concept that a return could be higher or lower than expected. Volatility measures can estimate the size of a return “surprise,” but do not indicate whether the surprise is positive or negative to the investor.

 

Standard Deviation

For investment returns, the preferred measure of volatility is standard deviation, which is a statistical measure of the dispersion of values in a data set around the mean of the data set. Dispersion refers to the distribution of data points around a specified central value—in this case, the mean, which is the average value for a data point in a data set. The standard deviation presents the measure of dispersion on the same numerical scale as the values in the data set. In general, the larger the standard deviation, the farther the values are distributed around the mean. Figure 4.2 illustrates the data dispersion of a sample portfolio’s annual rates of return around its mean annual rate of return.

Using historical return data for an asset, investors can (1) find the mean of a data set consisting of multiple annual rates of return during a specific time period and (2) calculate the standard deviation for the data set. Investors can use the calculated mean historical rate of return to represent the typical annual rate of return for the asset.

Investors also use standard deviation to create a range of expected return values for a given investment by (1) subtracting the standard deviation from the mean to get the lower end of the range and (2) adding the standard deviation from the mean to get the upper end of the range.

EXAMPLE

Roger Lesser calculates 10% as the mean annual rate of return for shares of Berriwyne Company stock over the last 50 years. He calculates 8% as the stock’s standard deviation during that period. Roger wants to estimate the range of return rates that he could expect if he owned Berriwyne shares for one year.

Analysis: At one standard deviation, the stock’s annual rate of return ranged from 2%, found as 10% – 8% to 18%, found as 10% + 8%. Using the stock’s measure of standard deviation, Roger expects that next year’s rate of return will fall within the range of 2% to 18%.

A higher standard deviation signifies greater volatility. The higher the standard deviation of the historical returns on an asset, the more an investor can expect the actual return for a given year to vary from the mean historical return. Therefore, a higher standard deviation indicates a greater risk that an investment’s future returns will not be consistent with the average returns it has earned in the past.

In addition, investors can compare the riskiness of two investments by comparing their standard deviations.

EXAMPLE

Over the same period, two investments have the following mean and standard deviation characteristics:

Investment

Mean Historical Rate of Return

Value of One Standard Deviation

Range of Expected Rates of Return

A

7%

3%

4% to 10%, found as 7% ± 3%

B

8%

10%

–2% to 18%, found as 8% ± 10%

Analysis: Although Investment B has a higher mean historical rate of return than Investment A, its returns are more volatile, as indicated by B’s higher standard deviation. B’s expected rate of return has a larger potential upside than A’s, but could also result in a loss (negative rate of return). Therefore, Investment B is riskier than Investment A.

 

Normal Distributions

When investors consider the dispersion of investment return values, they often assume that the values are distributed evenly on both sides of the mean. This dispersion pattern, called a normal distribution, is a type of data distribution in which the number of values that are less than the mean is the same as the number of values greater than the mean.

Data distributions can be normal or nonnormal. A nonnormal distribution is a type of data distribution in which the number of values on one side of the mean is greater than the number of values on the other side of the mean. Figure 4.3 illustrates the difference between normal and nonnormal data distributions.

Although normal distributions are an intuitive way to illustrate the standard deviation concept, in reality, some assets have historical returns that are distributed nonnormally. For example, a distribution could be nonnormal if the historical period being measured included a significant economic downturn. Still, many portfolio managers assume normal distributions as part of the theoretical basis that they use to construct portfolios.

Remember that actual returns for a holding period can deviate from historical averages, so an investor’s experience may differ from an asset’s normal distribution patterns. Thus, investors cannot guarantee that actual returns will fall within the range implied by a normal distribution pattern.

 

Confidence Intervals

In an earlier example, we demonstrated how to use an investment’s mean annual rate of return and one standard deviation to calculate its range of expected rates of return. Typically, if investors know the mean and standard deviation of historical returns, they can calculate ranges of expected returns. When investors can attach a confidence estimate to the range of estimated outcomes, the range is called a confidence interval. The confidence interval signifies the level of confidence that an investor has that an actual return will fall within the range of expected returns for that measure of deviation.

In a normal distribution, the relationship between the number of standard deviations and the confidence interval is as follows:

  • At one standard deviation, the confidence interval is approximately 67%.

  • At two standard deviations, the confidence interval is approximately 95%.

  • At three standard deviations, the confidence interval is approximately 99%.

For instance, at one standard deviation, about 67% of actual returns are expected to fall within the range of the mean minus the standard deviation and the mean plus the standard deviation.

EXAMPLE

An investment with a normal distribution of returns has a mean historical rate of return of 5% and one standard deviation of 10%. For each standard deviation, the range of expected rates of return and the confidence interval are:

Number of Standard Deviations

Range of Expected Rates of Return

Confidence Interval

One = 10%

–5% to 15%, found as 5% ± 10%

Approximately 67%

Two = 20%

–15% to 25%, found as 5% ± 20%

Approximately 95%

Three = 30%

–25% to 35%, found as 5% ± 30%

Approximately 99%

Analysis: As the number of standard deviations increases, the range of expected rates of return—which represents the range of probable outcomes—expands. In addition, as the likelihood that an actual return will fall within the range of expected returns increases, the confidence interval increases.

Many investors use two standard deviations to estimate the range of expected returns for an asset. Two standard deviations from the mean encompass approximately 95% of the outcomes in a normal distribution, so investors can have a great amount of confidence in their expected return estimates.

In a normal distribution curve, the areas containing values that are more than three standard distributions from the mean are called tails. Because three standard deviations from the mean encompasses approximately 99% of the estimated outcomes in a normal distribution, a low probability exists that a return will fall outside the expected range of outcomes. Such extreme return outcomes are tail risks, which generally signify risks of low-probability but high-impact occurrences. Return values that are far above the mean—indicating huge gains—are welcome, while values that are far less than the mean—indicating huge losses—are undesirable. Thus, tail risks have the potential to result in large financial losses on investments.

To summarize, Figure 4.4 shows two normal distribution curves with standard deviations of different sizes. The figure also illustrates tails beyond three standard deviations.

 

Investment Implications of Volatility

Volatility factors into the decisions that investors make. Greater volatility leads to greater uncertainty that an investment’s actual performance will be consistent with its average performance. Institutional investors plan their portfolios to achieve certain expected rates of return, so risky investments add doubt to their return projections.

Frequently, institutional investors use investment return estimates for long-term planning. Investments with higher return volatility are harder to incorporate into plans and can lead to challenging business situations. For example, an insurance company that earns actual investment returns that deviate from its expected returns may experience a mismatch between its asset portfolio and its liability portfolio. (We revisit this concept in Chapter 6.)

Typically, investment return volatility is more of a concern for investors with short holding periods. Over longer periods of time, overall returns tend to “average out,” or approach the typical return—a concept called mean reversion. In the context of investing, mean reversion is the theory that returns will eventually move back toward their historical averages after a temporary period of significant deviation. Thus, one method for decreasing the impact of return volatility on an investment portfolio is to hold volatile investments for longer periods than less volatile investments.

Another portfolio management method for decreasing the impact of return volatility is diversification. As you will read in Chapter 7, constructing a portfolio holding asset classes with different volatility characteristics can decrease the portfolio’s overall risk over the long term.

pages.title: The Risk-Return Trade-Off
pages.contents:
The Risk-Return Trade-Off

Investors must balance their desire to earn returns with their desire to limit risks. In investing, the risk-return trade-off is the relationship between risk and return in which higher risks offer the possibility of higher returns and lower risks tend to produce lower returns.

To achieve higher rates of return, investors typically have to accept more risk—in the form of uncertainty and volatility. However, future investment returns are not guaranteed; chasing potentially greater returns exposes an investor to potentially greater losses. Essentially, risk-return trade-off decisions involve exchanging safety for the possibility of larger returns.

Because different asset classes have different risk and return characteristics, the risk-return trade-off is one factor in asset class selection for investment portfolios. Some characteristics that indicate higher risk for an investment include

  • Longer investment holding periods

  • Lower credit ratings for borrowers

  • Higher interest rates charged to borrowers

  • Less knowledge about an investment’s risks

  • Less transparency in reporting about investment risks

  • Investments with low liquidity or low marketability

  • Loans made in the absence of security or collateral

  • Less information about or less certainty of income streams or cash flows

Figure 4.5 shows the trade-offs between risk and return for investments with various characteristics.

Each institutional investor sets its own policy for how much risk it is willing to accept to pursue a desired rate of return. In later chapters, you will read about how these policies are set at the corporate, functional, and operational levels. You will also read about specific calculations that investors use to adjust return measurements for the amounts of risk assumed.

For insurance companies, another type of risk-return trade-off to consider is the need to balance solvency and profitability. An insurer has to hold some money to ensure solvency, but needs to invest to improve its profitability. The trade-off involves assessing the appropriate amount of (1) capital to devote to each goal and (2) investment risk to assume. If an insurer

  • Holds too much money or does not assume enough investment risk, it could exceed its solvency goal, but profitability could be at risk

  • Invests too much money or assumes too much investment risk, it could exceed its profitability goal, but solvency could be at risk

pages.title: Risks Associated with Investing
pages.contents:
Risks Associated with Investing

In this chapter, we have discussed investment risk in general terms. Investment risks can also be categorized into two types of risks:

  • Systematic risks. A systematic risk—also known as a nondiversifiable risk or market risk—has a broad, similar effect on all elements in an economic system and cannot be eliminated through diversification. Within a given market, every investment is exposed to a systematic risk. For instance, the prospect of a shift in a central bank’s monetary policy that leads to a change in market interest rates is a systematic risk to all investments in that market. For a portfolio with investments in multiple countries, an important systematic risk is geopolitical risk, which is the risk that political instability or conflicts between countries adversely affect economic conditions. For example, a war between two neighboring countries is likely to have a negative economic effect on businesses operating in either country.

  • Specific risks. A specific risk—also known as a diversifiable risk or unsystematic risk—only affects certain assets or asset classes, and can be substantially reduced by diversification. A specific risk is associated with an individual company or industry, but not an entire market. For instance, the prospect of a new government regulation that affects only the airline industry is a specific risk for airline companies.

The difference between systematic risk and specific risk hinges on whether the relevant risk can be reduced in an investment portfolio through diversification. The following chart lists examples of systematic risks and specific risks—each of which you will learn about later in this section.

Systematic Risks

Specific Risks

Asset Bubbles

Interest-Rate Risk

Monetary Policy Changes

Credit Risk

Inflation

Real Estate Risk

Business Cycles

Liquidity Risk

Natural Disasters

Currency Risk
 

Systematic Risks

Systematic risks are hard to eliminate through diversification because these types of risks—many of which have a basis in broad economic conditions—have the potential to affect all investments in the marketplace. Diversification is intended to spread risk across assets, but if all asset choices are subject to the same type of market risk, then diversifying a portfolio does not help an investor avoid that risk.

Investors may not be able to avoid systematic risks, but they can hedge against them. For instance, an investment portfolio holding certain assets—such as bonds—that lose value because of inflation could hedge against that risk by purchasing assets—such as real estate properties—that hold or gain in value during periods of inflation. In this example, bonds and real estate properties are both affected by inflation, but in different ways.

Estimates of expected investment returns incorporate a risk premium for systematic risks but not specific risks. The “price of admission” to participate in a given market is exposure to its systematic risks; thus, investors need risk premiums as incentives to participate in markets. Because well-managed investment portfolios mitigate exposure to specific risks, investors do not require risk premiums to invest in assets that are subject to those risks.

 

Asset Bubbles

One type of systematic risk that can have a dramatic effect on asset prices is the risk of an asset bubble. An asset bubble, also called a speculative bubble or price bubble, is a phenomenon in which the market values of an entire asset class rise rapidly, so that prices of assets in the class come to greatly exceed their estimated values. Typically, asset price increases are driven by irrational enthusiasm and outpace increases in the asset’s true value.

In an asset bubble, asset prices rise to unsustainably high levels. Asset bubbles can grow—or “inflate”—for many years before prices reach their peaks. Bubbles can be difficult to spot while they are occurring, but one hallmark is a shift in market sentiment, so that most asset owners are speculators. Toward the peak, asset buyers are spurred by a feeling of missing out on gains and hope to ride the continuous upward momentum of prices.

Eventually, investors and other market participants realize that the asset prices in an asset bubble are due to unfounded optimism, and they sell these assets, causing the bubble to “burst.” After the bubble bursts, asset prices decline quickly, which can cause significant—and painful—losses for the asset owners. Widespread asset bubbles can adversely affect an entire economic system.

Asset bubbles have occurred many times throughout history. Notable bubbles range from the Dutch tulip bubble that burst in 1637 to the U.S. housing bubble that burst around 2007. The insight below describes the burst of the U.S. housing bubble in greater detail.

INSIGHT

The Bursting of the U.S. Housing Bubble

In the early 2000s, housing prices in the United States rose rapidly. Some contributing factors to rising house prices were

  • Increased demand from home buyers who qualified for mortgages under lowered underwriting standards
  • A period of low interest rates, which spurred real estate business and investment
  • Increased demand from financial companies for mortgage loans used for structured security origination and trading
  • Government regulations that provided incentives for home ownership

Around 2006, a combination of rising interest rates and defaults among high-risk borrowers with low credit ratings started to cause significant issues for the housing market. As mortgage defaults rose and demand for homes fell, housing values declined, resulting in a ripple effect among asset types related to property values. As a result, the market values of properties, mortgages, and related investments—such as mortgage-backed securities and derivatives—also began to decline rapidly, which jeopardized the solvency of financial institutions that held large amounts of these investments.

In 2007, the asset price decreases caused one prominent investment bank to go bankrupt, prompting concerns about the stability of the entire financial system in the United States. During this time, investors generally abandoned risky assets, selling them in large numbers. Demand for safe assets—such as Treasuries—increased rapidly.

In 2008, the financial crisis spread to other parts of the world, particularly Europe. In addition, the United States experienced a significant recession—one of the worst since the 1930s—that adversely affected the global economy. Worldwide, governments and central banks took extraordinary actions to prevent additional economic shocks, and the financial crisis gradually passed.

Since the 2007–2008 financial crisis, several aspects of housing and finance—including mortgage lending standards, credit ratings, uses of capital by financial institutions, and sizes of financial institutions—have received additional scrutiny. As a result, regulators have pushed for increased oversight to attempt to prevent the next financial crisis. In addition, central banks actively search for potential asset bubbles.

The asset bubble and resulting financial crisis described above resulted from a systematic risk that nearly became a systemic crisis. A systemic crisis is a series of adverse events occurring in a significant number of financial institutions or markets that has a catastrophic effect. A systemic crisis results in severe impairment or complete failure of the functioning of the financial system.

A systemic risk is a risk that (1) affects securities markets, banking systems, and currencies, and (2) can result in a systemic crisis. Systemic risks are related to systematic risks, but the terms are not interchangeable. A systematic risk can affect an entire market, but a systemic risk threatens to take down an entire interconnected financial system. Thus, only a particular type of systematic risk—such as an asset bubble in real estate prices—can also be a systemic risk. Regulatory entities around the world monitor systemic risks in an effort to prevent a systemic crisis from occurring.

 

Specific Risks

As we mentioned earlier, specific risks can be reduced through diversification. One benefit of portfolio diversification is that the impact of the specific risks associated with a single asset is reduced as more assets are included. Businesses face many kinds of specific risks—such as operational risk and reputational risk—but this section focuses on specific risks associated with investments.

Important categories of specific risks for insurance company investments include interest-rate risk, credit risk, real estate risk, liquidity risk, and currency risk.

 

Interest-Rate Risk

Interest-rate risk is the risk that the market value of an investment will change due to a change in nominal market interest rates. In general, for interest-bearing investments—such as bonds and mortgage loans—the market value of an existing investment will

  • Decrease as market interest rates increase

  • Increase as market interest rates decrease

For instance, in rising interest-rate environments, current issues of bonds typically fall in market value because new issues will be offered at higher coupon rates, which are more attractive to investors. In such cases, an investor can hold existing bonds to maturity, thus avoiding selling them at unfavorable market values. Note that life insurance companies generally purchase bonds and other debt securities with the intention of holding them to maturity.

Interest-rate risk affects virtually all investments. For example, real estate is subject to interest-rate risk because transactions are usually financed with interest-bearing loans. In addition, some stock market sectors—such as those comprising utility companies or financial companies—are more sensitive to interest rates than other sectors.

 
Reinvestment Risk

Generally, reinvestment risk is the risk that market conditions will be unfavorable when the investor needs to invest the proceeds from a prior investment. For an interest-bearing security, reinvestment risk is the risk that an investor will receive lower interest income after reinvesting the proceeds from an interest-bearing security that has matured. Reinvestment risk also applies to any interest payments that an investor receives while holding an interest-bearing security.

Reinvestment risk increases in a declining interest-rate environment. Insurance companies—and other institutional investors that hold many fixed-income investments—can miss out on investment income as it becomes harder to find bonds of a certain credit quality with coupon rates and yields as high as those for their recently matured bonds. In such a scenario, investors have two choices: (1) increase bond principal amounts to make up for lost income or (2) pursue riskier bonds with higher coupon rates.

 
Bond Duration

Bonds have different levels of sensitivity to interest-rate changes, depending on each bond’s coupon rate and term to maturity. Typically, two characteristics associated with greater interest-rate sensitivity are lower coupon rates and longer terms to maturity. In general, bonds with lower coupon rates take longer to generate cash flows that cover the original cost of purchase than bonds with higher coupon rates. Likewise, cash flows from bonds with longer terms to maturity generally take more time to cover the investor’s original cost than those of bonds with shorter terms to maturity. Bonds with greater interest-rate sensitivity also experience greater market value volatility.

Bond sensitivity is measured using duration, which is a statistic that measures the interest-rate sensitivity of an interest-bearing security. Duration can be defined as the responsiveness—expressed in years—of a security’s market value to changes in market interest rates. Investors can calculate duration in multiple ways, with different calculations emphasizing cash flows or price changes.

Interpreting Duration

A duration statistic of n years indicates that, for a change of 1% in interest rates, the price or market value of a security will change by approximately n% in the opposite direction. Thus, as the value of duration increases, interest-rate risk increases.

If two bonds are similar but have different durations, then the one with lower duration is less risky. However, the bond with lower duration also has less potential for price appreciation.

Margin Compression

In a period of increasing market interest rates, insurance companies can experience margin compression. Margin compression refers to the narrowing of an insurer’s interest margin, potentially because of market interest-rate changes. The interest margin, also known as the interest-rate margin or the interest spread, is the share of investment earnings that an insurer retains after crediting a share of investment earnings to policyowners.

Typically, when market interest rates are rising, policyowners immediately demand a higher crediting rate on their accounts. The company’s interest-bearing investments, however, continue to earn the older, lower rates that prevailed when the company purchased them. If the company immediately pays the new higher rate on its products, the company’s interest margin will narrow. If the company does not pay the new higher rate on its products, the company will likely lose customers and business from financial professionals. To minimize the risk of margin compression, insurance companies typically try to issue products that limit customer withdrawal rights during a policy’s early years. Margin compression also comes into play during periods of decreasing market interest rates if asset maturities are not properly aligned with the average life of the liabilities. The effects of margin compression due to falling market interest rates are realized slowly over time, as the insurer collects interest and principal payments on older interest-bearing investments, and must reinvest these amounts at lower rates.

Margin expansion refers to an increase in an insurer’s interest margin, potentially because of market interest-rate changes. Margin expansion occurs if the insurer reduces the interest-crediting rates it pays to customers while continuing to earn a higher overall rate of return on its existing invested assets. Margin expansion can also occur when a company experiences an increase in the market value of its existing assets after market interest rates fall.

 

Credit Risk

Credit risk is the risk that (1) a borrower defaults on debt obligations by failing to make payments of principal or interest on time or (2) a lender sustains a financial loss based on an adverse change in a borrower’s creditworthiness.

Due to the large holdings of debt-related investments in the general account of a typical life insurance company, credit risk exposures are one of the main threats of potential debt investment losses for insurer portfolios.

Two categories of credit risk that are relevant to investors are

  • Default risk. In the context of investing, default risk is the risk that an investor will not receive the cash flow payments to which it is entitled because a borrower fails to fulfill its debt obligations. Default risk affects all type of debt securities and also affects corporate equity securities, which lose substantial market value if the issuing company defaults on its debt obligations and becomes insolvent.

  • Downgrade risk. Downgrade risk involves the risk of deterioration in a credit rating assigned to an issuer of a debt security. A credit downgrade does not affect payments of principal or interest to investors. However, market value decreases usually accompany downgrades. Thus, if an investor must sell a downgraded security before maturity, the amount of money raised by the sale will be lower than it would have been prior to the downgrade.

The main threat of credit risk is that, when an investment goes into default or is downgraded, its market value also decreases. Typically, defaults cause larger market value drops than downgrades.

In the context of investing, credit analysts evaluate the credit quality—or “creditworthiness”—of the issuers of debt securities. As part of their evaluations, credit analysts assess the risk of default or downgrade by issuers.

Typically, sovereign debt is the least risky investment one can make in a given economy, but it still carries risks. Sovereign credit risk is the risk that a sovereign government will fail to meet its debt obligations, leading to sovereign default or sovereign debt restructuring. When analysts evaluate a sovereign credit risk, the sovereign government’s ability and willingness to repay borrowed money are both important factors to consider.

 

Real Estate Risk

Real estate risk is the potential for loss resulting from a decline in the value of real estate. Exposure to real estate risk can come from directly owning real estate properties or from owning assets—such as mortgages and mortgage-backed securities—whose value depends on real estate property values.

Losses on real estate properties can have a variety of causes. For example, low demand for local properties could be the result of new local construction, competitive rates for local rents, or adverse economic conditions. Real estate investors can evaluate real estate risk by monitoring market prices for properties that are similar to the ones they own.

For mortgage analysis, investors consider two ratios:

  • Loan-to-value (LTV) ratio, which is the ratio of a mortgage’s loan balance to the property’s value. Typically, the risk of mortgage default increases as the value of the property decreases.

  • Debt service coverage ratio, which is the ratio of a borrower’s monthly earnings—before interest and taxes—to its monthly mortgage payments owed. The higher the ratio, the easier the borrower is able to meet its mortgage loan obligations.

 

Liquidity Risk

In the context of investing, liquidity risk is the risk that an asset might not be easily sold for its underlying value. Liquidity risk can arise from a lack of buyers, lack of secondary markets, or the structure of the investment—as is often the case in alternative investments.

An investment is likely to have limited liquidity if it

  • Is traded privately or in OTC markets instead of on public exchanges

  • Contains restrictions that limit the frequency or timing of ownership transactions

  • Is issued in relatively small outstanding quantities

  • Is subject to regulatory or policy restrictions that limit institutional investor involvement

 

Currency Risk

Currency risk, also known as foreign exchange risk, is a risk arising from changes in currency exchange rates. When one currency falls in relation to another, the falling currency loses relative value and the rising currency gains relative value. Generally, currency risk can arise from geopolitical factors, fluctuations in the supply and demand of a country’s manufactured goods, inflation, and changes in government leadership.

Manufacturers typically price domestically produced products in the domestic currency; thus, an increase in demand for a country’s products can result in an increase in demand for that country’s currency. Increased demand for a particular country’s currency increases the price of that currency relative to the currencies of other countries.

Investments in foreign markets are subject to currency risk. Investors with exposure to currency risk can hedge their risk by holding foreign exchange derivatives.

pages.title: Basic Investment Goals
pages.contents:
Basic Investment Goals

Why do you invest money? How do you intend to use your investment gains? Investors have different answers based on their particular circumstances. However, most reasons for investing can be categorized according to three basic investment goals:

  • Capital protection, also called preservation of capital or preservation of principal, which prioritizes investing in stable assets that are unlikely to incur significant losses

  • Current income, which prioritizes investing in assets that generate regular income

  • Capital growth, also called capital appreciation or wealth accumulation, which prioritizes investing in assets with the greatest potential for gains

Capital protection is the most conservative of the basic investment goals. Investors with capital protection goals are concerned with maintaining their current level of capital. Thus, they choose investments that provide their portfolios with stability. Some investments that are suitable for capital protection goals are money market accounts, government bonds, and highly rated corporate bonds.

Many investors with current income goals need steady income to meet their cash needs. While they also value safe assets, they are willing to give up some safety to consider assets with higher yields. Some investments that are suitable for current income goals are fixed-income securities, dividend-paying stocks, real estate investment trusts (REITs), and funds that own bonds or dividend-paying stocks.

Capital growth is the most aggressive of the basic investment goals. Investors with capital growth goals have different levels of aggressiveness. For instance, an investor with moderate aggressiveness may aim for a rate of growth that outpaces inflation, whereas an investor with high aggressiveness may accept large risks in pursuit of large gains. Some investments that are suitable for capital growth goals are stocks—particularly in companies that invest capital into projects with high growth potential—funds that own stocks, real estate properties, and alternative investments.

Typically, investment goals are tied to an investor’s time horizon, which is the length of time that an investor plans to invest in order to reach an investment goal. For example, retail investors with short time horizons—such as workers who are two years away from retirement—do not have enough time to recover if their investments experience significant short-term losses. Therefore, such investors usually have capital protection goals. On the other hand, retail investors with long time horizons—such as workers who are thirty years away from retirement—can sustain short-term volatility in their investments, so they can afford to be more aggressive. Investors with long time horizons usually have capital growth goals.

Investment goals are also tied to an investor’s risk tolerance, which is the degree to which an investor is willing and able to accept risk:

  • Investors with low risk tolerances are more likely to have capital protection or current income goals because they (1) are uncomfortable with investment volatility or (2) have significant short-term cash needs.

  • Investors with high risk tolerances are more likely to have capital growth goals because they (1) are willing to endure high return volatility for the opportunity to earn large returns or (2) usually do not have immediate cash needs.

In general, an investor’s time horizon and risk tolerance are consistent. For instance, an institutional investor with a short time horizon plans to access its capital soon and does not want to take any large risks with its money. However, sometimes investors are not comfortable accepting the level of risk that would usually be appropriate given their time horizons.

EXAMPLE

Valerie Durham is investing her retirement savings. She plans to retire 20 years from now. Based on her time horizon of 20 years, she should consider investing in relatively risky assets with greater growth potential. However, she hates the idea of losing money in any year, even if she has many years to recover a given year’s investment loss. In fact, she would consider leaving her retirement savings in cash to avoid investment losses.

Analysis: Because of her strong aversion to risk, Valerie has a very low risk tolerance. Even though she has a long time horizon, her risk tolerance suggests that she would feel more comfortable with a capital protection goal for her investments.

Investors can choose to focus exclusively on one of the basic investment goals, but some pursue a combination of goals. For example, many retirees want to protect capital and generate income; their investment portfolios tend to hold a large percentage of bonds. Other investors may want a portfolio with moderate growth and income generation. These investors could hold a combination of stocks—especially dividend-paying stocks—and bonds. Their portfolios receive the capital appreciation potential of stocks and the coupon payments of bonds.

Ideally, every investment portfolio would protect capital, generate plenty of income, and earn large capital gains. However, investors have to factor in the risk-return trade-off when selecting their goals. For example,

  • Capital protection investors who value the safety of low-risk investments have to be willing to accept the possibility of lower investment returns.

  • Capital growth investors who desire the potential for large returns have to be willing to accept more risk.

Therefore, investors usually prioritize their investment goals when constructing their portfolios.

Investment goals can also shift over time. For instance, a person who is investing for retirement may gradually change his goal from capital growth to capital protection as he approaches retirement and has less time to recover from large investment losses. In this case, the composition of the investments in his portfolio would change to match his shifting goals.

In addition to the basic investment goals, investors may have secondary considerations that influence the investments they choose. For example, an investor who needs to maintain a certain amount of liquidity may need to avoid alternative investments, which are generally illiquid. Another investor may choose investments with favorable tax treatment, such as municipal bonds, to minimize the income taxes that she has to pay on her investment earnings.
