pages.title: Portfolio Objectives and Constraints
pages.contents:
Portfolio Objectives and Constraints

Institutional investors incorporate basic investment goals into their portfolios by designating a portfolio’s investment objectives. Investment objectives are statements that describe a portfolio’s purpose, typically by describing how the portfolio will meet an investor’s financial goals.

When constructing a portfolio, an investor may have to work around investment constraints, which are circumstances that limit the investment options that an investor has for a particular portfolio.

 

Investment Objectives

As part of portfolio planning, an investor needs to determine the portfolio’s objective(s). Typically, an objective is a brief sentence or two that describes the purpose of the portfolio or how the portfolio meets an investor’s needs.

EXAMPLE

Investment Objective

The objective of this investment portfolio is to meet the current income requirements of the Camion Industrial Corporation’s employee pension plan while protecting the value of the plan’s invested capital.

Accurately defining an investment objective is important because portfolio managers use objectives to guide their selection and management of portfolio investments. To arrive at an appropriate investment objective, a portfolio manager needs to understand the investor’s

  • Return requirements

  • Risk tolerance

Institutional investors have a variety of reasons for investing. The following chart provides examples of investment goals and needs for different types of institutional investors. The last row on the chart is for a sovereign wealth fund, which is an investment fund that invests a national government’s excess revenues to earn long-term returns. For example, a significant portion of the economy of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) is dependent on revenue from oil exports. The UAE’s sovereign wealth fund grows capital that the country can rely on during periods of weak oil revenues.

Institution

Goal(s)

Purpose/Need

Life Insurance Company

Current income and capital protection, with moderate capital growth

Support life insurance and retirement products, which typically have long-term contracts

Property and Casualty Insurance Company

Capital protection

Support financial protection products that usually have short-term contracts

Pension Fund

Capital growth, then current income and capital protection

Support payouts of pension liabilities

Retirement Fund

Capital growth, then current income and capital protection

Accumulate wealth for individuals for the end of their working years

College Endowment Fund

Capital growth, possibly with current income

Sustain an educational institution beyond the lifetime of current students and alumni

Charitable Foundation

Capital growth

Sustain a social program beyond the lifetime of the founder

Sovereign Wealth Fund

Capital growth

Invest to build and sustain government services and public infrastructure over many years
 

Investment Constraints

A portfolio manager also has to be aware of a portfolio’s investment constraints, which typically include

  • Time horizon. The time horizon indicates the length of time the portfolio has for meeting its objectives, which are linked to the investor’s financial needs. The time horizon guides the portfolio manager’s selection of certain assets and asset classes. For example, a large percentage of volatile investments—such as equity securities—would be inappropriate for a portfolio with a short time horizon.

  • Liquidity. Investors may have specific cash needs that limit the suitability of certain types of assets. For example, a retail investor may be planning for a large cash outflow, such as a down payment for a house purchase. In this case, the investment portfolio should hold assets that can be easily converted to cash.

  • Tax considerations. In general, all individuals and institutions want to minimize taxes, but some investors have a strong desire to use their investments as part of a tax minimization strategy. For example, in a country where investment income is taxed at a higher rate than capital gains, an investor may restrict certain investments—such as dividend-paying stocks—that increase his taxable income.

  • Legal and regulatory constraints. These constraints usually apply to institutional investors. For example, life insurance regulators place limitations on the amount of certain types of assets—such as derivatives—that an insurer can hold.

  • Special circumstances. The investor may place restrictions on portfolio investments based on personal preferences. For example, a charitable foundation may specify industries to avoid investing in, such as the alcohol industry, because the charity’s founders believed that such industries were harmful to society.

 

Asset Allocation

Once a portfolio’s objectives and constraints are clearly described, a portfolio manager can develop a strategy to achieve the objectives. One of the first steps is deciding which asset classes to use and how to divide capital among those classes. In portfolio management, the asset allocation—also known as the asset mix—is the percentage distribution of all portfolio holdings across a specified array of asset classes, such as various subcategories of stocks and bonds.

EXAMPLE

The Algravita Fund Company’s VITA 60/40 Fund is designed to allocate 60% of the fund’s capital to stocks and 40% to bonds. The fund manager chose that asset allocation to help the fund achieve its objectives of moderately growing capital while generating some current income.

Watch Video 5.1 to see an example of how a portfolio’s asset allocation changes as it adds investments in different asset classes.

Video 5.1 Various Asset Allocations

Various Asset Allocations

The asset allocation for any portfolio reflects the objectives and philosophy of the portfolio, while factoring in regulations and other constraints. Proper asset allocation diversifies a portfolio’s holdings among different asset classes to align the portfolio’s risks and expected returns with the investor’s (1) portfolio objectives, (2) risk tolerance, and (3) time horizon. For instance, an investor with a growth objective, a high tolerance for risk, and a long time horizon is likely to have a large percentage of equity securities in her portfolio.

In addition, asset allocation reflects return expectations. Portfolio managers assess financial market conditions and the economic environment when developing their long-term expectations for the performance of specific asset classes. They use their asset class return expectations to help them determine the best asset allocation to meet portfolio objectives.

For institutional investment portfolios, portfolio managers are responsible for maintaining appropriate asset allocations. When initially constructing a portfolio, the portfolio manager purchases assets in the proportions specified by the planned asset allocation. Over time, market values fluctuate and actual asset proportions usually drift from a portfolio’s intended asset proportions. The portfolio manager can return the portfolio to the intended asset allocation by rebalancing it. Rebalancing is the process of periodically adjusting the percentage of funds invested in a particular asset class in an investment portfolio to ensure that the portfolio continues to contain the desired mix of assets.

EXAMPLE

The VITA 60/40 Fund’s desired asset allocation is 60% stocks and 40% bonds. One year after the fund’s launch, its actual asset allocation is as follows:

Analysis: The 80% allocation to stocks is too high and the 20% allocation to bonds is too low. To return the fund to its proper allocation, the fund manager needs to rebalance the portfolio. The fund manager sells shares from the stock holdings and uses the proceeds to purchase more bonds for the portfolio. Once the fund manager sells enough stock shares and purchases enough bonds, the percentages will be back in line with the intended asset allocation, and the portfolio rebalancing will be complete.

pages.title: Investment Policy Statements for Institutional Portfolios
pages.contents:
Investment Policy Statements for Institutional Portfolios

For institutional investors, objectives and constraints form the backbone of an investment policy. Established by an institutional investor’s board of directors, an investment policy is a statement that outlines a set of formal rules and guidelines for investing.

Financial services companies establish investment policies at several levels. Figure 5.1 illustrates the typical investment policy hierarchy, which you will learn more about during the rest of this chapter.

At the corporate level, an investment policy specifies broad guidelines that apply to all company assets. For example, one such guideline might be that investment management should follow all applicable laws and regulations.

The corporate investment policy also identifies specific corporate investment constraints. For example, a company might prohibit investing in a socially controversial industry, such as the firearms industry.

In the corporate investment policy, the board of directors communicates to the company’s investment function its views on how to manage corporate assets. At the functional level, the investment policy provides more detailed guidelines for managing an investment portfolio or group of portfolios. For instance, the investment function’s investment policy may provide guidelines for using derivatives and other asset classes within a portfolio.

At the operational level, investment professionals implement plans for specific portfolios. Planning for institutional portfolio management involves creating a specific portfolio’s investment policy statement (IPS), which is a written document that describes the portfolio’s investment goals and strategies, the type and amount of risk the institution is willing and able to accept within the portfolio, and the investment costs the institution is willing to incur for the portfolio’s management. The IPS guides portfolio activities at the operational level.

An IPS describes the roles and responsibilities of the parties involved—such as the institution’s board of directors and the portfolio manager—with regard to a particular investment portfolio. The institutional investor decides the portfolio’s objectives and constraints. The portfolio manager then

  • Works with the investor to create the IPS

  • Implements the portfolio’s investment strategy

  • Monitors and evaluates the portfolio’s performance

  • Ensures the portfolio’s compliance with the IPS

Creating the IPS is an important step in developing a portfolio’s investment strategy because it provides parameters. In other words, the details in a portfolio’s IPS guide the decisions that portfolio managers make to reach specific investment goals. For instance, even if a portfolio manager strongly believes that growth-oriented equity securities will significantly outperform all other investments over the next couple of years, she cannot increase a portfolio’s equity allocation beyond the level outlined in its IPS.

In addition, an IPS forces discipline and accountability on investment professionals. All investors, even professionals, can be tempted to react emotionally to changes—actual and anticipated—in market conditions. A formalized plan can act as a check against an investment professional’s counterproductive impulses and behaviors because the portfolio management team is required to stick to the plan. Furthermore, an IPS expresses a portfolio’s goals and constraints in measureable terms—which enables the investor to evaluate how effective the portfolio management team is in executing the plan for a given portfolio.

The IPS should be reviewed periodically to ensure that it accurately reflects the investor’s circumstances and requirements. During an IPS review, investment professionals may also review a portfolio’s risk and return objectives to ensure alignment with corporate goals. After a review, the IPS can be adjusted as necessary.

No standard format exists for an IPS. Therefore, the elements of an IPS are customizable, depending on the needs and policies of an institutional investor. However, an institutional investor’s IPS typically includes the following elements:

  • Portfolio return and risk objectives

  • Asset allocation criteria, including authorized asset classes

  • Guidelines for portfolio management

  • Standards for monitoring and evaluating investment performance

  • Instructions for ensuring compliance with investment reporting standards, as well as with the IPS

The insight below is a simplified example of an IPS for a life insurance company’s general account.

INSIGHT

Sample General Account Investment Policy Statement

Investment Policy Statement

Primary Investment Objective

The portfolio’s primary investment objective is to ensure the company always has sufficient capital to support its general account obligations.

Secondary Investment Objectives

The portfolio’s secondary investment objectives are to (1) maximize long-term returns for the benefit of the company’s shareholders and (2) manage the company’s capital in accordance with industry regulations.

Authorized Asset Classes

Cash; bonds, including corporate and U.S. government bonds; stocks, including common and preferred stocks; commercial mortgages; REITs; structured securities, including asset-backed securities and mortgage-backed securities; alternative investments, including hedge funds and private equity funds; and derivatives.

Asset Allocation Guidelines

The portfolio should not exceed the following limits without approval from the company’s board of directors:

  • Cash: 1–5%
  • Bonds: 55–85%
  • Stocks: 0–15%
  • Commercial Mortgages: 0–10%
  • REITs: 0–5%
  • Structured Securities: 10–30%
  • Alternative Investments: 5–20%
  • Derivatives: 0–3%

Individual Asset Concentration Limitations

No more than 5% of the portfolio’s stock allocation may be held in any one issuer. No more than 1% of the portfolio’s total market value may be committed to any single bond issue.

Fixed-Income Credit Quality Limitations

If a debt security held by the portfolio is downgraded below a Baa3 (Moody’s) and BBB– (S&P) rating, it must be placed on a “watch list” for closer monitoring. Board approval must be received for any security that appears on the watch list for three consecutive years.

The portfolio cannot hold debt securities for which the Moody’s or S&P rating is less than B. If a debt security is downgraded below a B rating by both Moody’s and S&P, it must be sold at the best available price within three months.

Portfolio Reviews

The portfolio will be reviewed quarterly by the company’s asset-liability management committee. Each quarterly review will evaluate the portfolio’s investment performance and its adherence to this investment policy statement.

Performance Evaluation

Portfolio performance will be measured quarterly on an absolute basis and against a designated market index.

 

Portfolio Objectives

The IPS explicitly states the portfolio’s objective(s). Because a portfolio’s performance will be judged against the objectives outlined in the IPS, the objectives must be reasonable and measureable. In other words, an objective must be attainable through the responsible application of an investment strategy.

Although the portfolio objective is a brief statement in an IPS, a lot of consideration goes into shaping the statement. For example, the institutional investor must choose return and risk objectives for the portfolio.

Return objectives can be expressed as absolute or relative returns. An absolute return objective simply states a portfolio’s target return for a given period, while a relative return objective states a portfolio’s target return as compared to another metric—such as the rate of inflation or the performance of a market index—over a given period.

EXAMPLE

Absolute and Relative Return Objectives

  • Absolute return objective: The portfolio should earn an annualized rate of return of 8% over the next 10 years.
  • Relative return objective: The portfolio’s rate of return should outpace the rate of inflation over the next five years.

As you read in the previous chapter, investment returns can be measured in different ways, such as total return or rate of return. Similarly, portfolio return objectives are expressed using different return measurements. For instance, an important return objective for many life insurer portfolios is earning a specified book yield. For bond investments, the book yield is based on the investor’s actual purchase price instead of the bond’s current market price. Achieving the portfolio’s book yield return objective helps an insurer earn sufficient investment income, which it needs to meet its future liability obligations.

 

Risk Appetite and Risk Tolerance

In an IPS, portfolio risk objectives typically reflect the investor’s risk tolerance, which we previously defined as the willingness and ability to accept risk. However, companies with risk management functions can define the term “risk tolerance” differently. In the context of a company’s risk management framework,

  • Risk appetite is the amount and type of risk that a company is prepared to seek in the pursuit of profits or other strategic objectives

  • Risk tolerance describes the company’s capacity to bear a risk in order to achieve its objectives

Although the two terms appear to be interchangeable, there are some notable differences. Risk appetite broadly describes a company’s attitude toward risk—such as aggressive or risk-averse. Risk tolerance expands on a company’s risk appetite by defining the acceptable levels of variation from a company’s risk objectives. Essentially, risk appetite reflects a company’s willingness to bear risk, whereas risk tolerance reflects the company’s ability to bear risk.

A company clarifies its risk tolerance by establishing risk limits. A risk limit, also known as a risk criterion, is a quantitative statement that expresses how the company will assess and monitor its risk appetite and risk tolerance. A risk limit specifies the maximum variance that a company will tolerate. Risk limits translate a company’s risk tolerance into guidelines that the company can use on a day-to-day basis.

EXAMPLE

The investment professionals at Dexicos Life Insurance Company are developing an IPS for a new portfolio. They need Dexicos Life’s board of directors to clarify the company’s positions on investment risk. The board provides the following information to the investment function:

Risk appetite: Dexicos Life is generally conservative toward risk, but is willing to accept some investment risk to achieve long-term growth.

Risk tolerance: A portfolio’s bond investments should comprise investment-grade bonds. If a bond investment’s credit rating falls below investment grade, it will be added to a company watch list for monitoring.

Risk limits: A portfolio can have no more than 30% of its bond investments on the company watch list. If the portfolio exceeds this percentage, the portfolio manager must recommend steps to bring the credit quality of the bond investments back into alignment with the IPS. The recommendations must be approved by management before implementation.

For institutional investors, risk appetite, risk tolerance, and risk limits are established by a company’s risk policy. A risk policy is a corporate policy statement that explains the principles the company will follow for managing risk, outlines the process for managing risk, specifies the authority and responsibility for risk management, and establishes risk reporting and risk controls.

For operational guidance, the risk appetite and risk tolerance for an institutional investor’s investment function are often translated into quantifiable indicators, as follows:

  • A key performance indicator (KPI) is a quantitative measure that indicates success for a specified process or activity that is critical to the success of an organization. The attributes of a KPI include a target performance value, the currently achieved value, and identifiable trends. A KPI indirectly addresses risk appetite. For instance, a portfolio’s annual rate of return target is an investment KPI; setting a target of 10% signals that a company has a strong appetite for investment risk.

  • A key risk indicator (KRI) is a quantitative measure that indicates the level of potential adverse impact on a given activity. A KRI should be readily observable and should be closely correlated with the likelihood of a risk impact. A KRI directly addresses risk tolerances. For instance, a portfolio’s derivatives allocation is a KRI; the portfolio exceeds its risk tolerance if the percentage of assets made up of derivatives is greater than the stated limit of 5%.

KPIs and KRIs can be displayed on a performance dashboard, which is a computer-based graphical display of the current status of a company’s most important performance measures, presented in a readily understood format. Dashboards support decision making throughout all levels of an organization by showing a comparison of actual performance to performance standards. Figure 5.2 illustrates a sample dashboard containing some investment KPIs and KRIs.

In the investment function, a performance dashboard typically indicates relevant KPIs and KRIs. Through performance dashboards, portfolio managers have access to the current status of an array of important portfolio measures. For example, a performance dashboard can provide the following types of information to a portfolio manager:

  • Whether each monitored risk is (1) safely within risk limits, (2) approaching its limits, or (3) outside of its limits

  • How a portfolio is currently performing relative to the performance of an established standard, such as a market index

  • How well a portfolio’s actual asset allocations match its planned asset allocations

 

Asset Allocation Criteria

Another common element of an IPS is the asset allocation criteria—also known as diversification criteria or limitations on asset concentrations—which consist of rules stating limits on the portion of a portfolio that may be invested in a stated category.

EXAMPLE

Asset Allocation Criteria

Assets will be divided so that no single security will have a significant negative impact on the market value of the total portfolio. Assets will be diversified according to asset type, risk characteristics, and number of investments.

  • Investments in a single industry or a single company are limited to 20% and 5% of total assets, respectively.
  • Total international investments may not exceed 20% of the portfolio’s investments.
  • Total high-yield (speculative) bond investments may not exceed 5% of the portfolio’s bond investments.

A portfolio that becomes too concentrated in certain types of assets also becomes too exposed to the risks associated with those asset types. Therefore, asset allocation criteria serve to reduce portfolio risk by restricting the amount of each asset type to a level appropriate for the portfolio’s risk and return objectives.

 

Authorized Asset Classes

Typically, an IPS will include a list of authorized asset classes that have been deemed suitable for the portfolio. The authorized asset classes must have the potential to meet the portfolio’s risk and return objectives given the market conditions expected during the investor’s time horizon. Note that asset classes subject to risks that exceed established risk tolerances are not eligible for inclusion on the list of authorized asset classes.

The list may also specify a target percentage or acceptable percentage range that a portfolio can allocate to each asset class.

EXAMPLE

Authorized Asset Classes

  • Between 55 and 85% of total funds will be invested in fixed income investments.
  • Between 5 and 25% of total funds will be invested in equity investments.
  • Between 0 and 5% of total funds will be held in cash or cash investments.

Within the investment function, investment professionals evaluate each potential asset class in terms of the company’s established risk control framework. Institutional investors maintain lists of asset classes that have been approved by the company, and portfolio managers must justify and obtain approval for adding any asset class not already on the list.

 

Portfolio Management Guidelines

The IPS includes guidelines for managing the investment portfolio. Typical guidelines include instructions for periodic—usually quarterly or annual—rebalancing of the portfolio and criteria for asset trading practices. Two examples of trading instructions are to (1) seek the best execution price in all trades and (2) provide periodic reports on commissions paid for trade executions.

Some investors, including a growing number of institutional investors, have specific beliefs about suitable portfolio investments and may include portfolio management guidelines to reflect those beliefs. For example, an institution could restrict investing in tobacco companies because of the harmful effects of such products. According to this investment practice, called socially responsible investing (SRI), investors consider the nature of the business a company engages in before making a decision about whether to invest in the company.

The IPS stipulates that the institutional investor and portfolio manager must periodically review the statement and discuss potential changes. During a review, the IPS can be adjusted to account for changing needs or added constraints. An IPS may also need to be adjusted if the long-term economic environment shifts, prompting changes in asset allocation and other aspects of the portfolio’s investment strategy.

EXAMPLE

The global economy was in a recession but is entering a period of expansion. During the annual IPS review of the portfolio for the Camion Industrial Corporation’s employee pension plan, the portfolio manager suggests updating the portfolio’s future return expectations to reflect the new economic conditions.

 

Performance Evaluation

The IPS outlines standards for monitoring and measuring the performance of the portfolio’s investments. One of the most important factors in performance evaluation is choosing appropriate benchmarks, which are performance standards that represent portfolio performance goals. Investment professionals use objective benchmarks to set portfolio performance expectations and evaluate performance outcomes. Figure 5.3 shows a portfolio’s performance relative to its benchmark.

One common benchmark is a relevant market index. A market index allows investment professionals to compare the actual performance of a portfolio—or a given asset class within a portfolio—to the average performance for that market. If used as the benchmark for a specified asset class, a market index must closely reflect the long-term behavior of the asset class.

EXAMPLE

Standards for Monitoring Performance

The portfolio manager will monitor the performance of the portfolio’s equity securities in comparison to the S&P 500 Index. Performance should be monitored at least on a quarterly basis.

Portfolio managers continually monitor their portfolios against established benchmarks. Portfolios are guided by clear performance targets, which then form the basis for portfolio performance evaluation. For instance, if an IPS states that a portfolio’s expected rate of return is 8% per year, then the portfolio’s actual rate of return is judged against that target each year.

 

Reporting and Compliance

Investment professionals are responsible for regularly communicating the results of a portfolio’s investment activities. Portfolio performance reporting standards are practices accepted throughout the securities industry for proper reporting of portfolio values as of a specified date.

The CFA Institute’s Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS®) are standards for consistent reporting of investment performance and are designed to ensure fair representation and full disclosure of investment performance across a global market. The GIPS provide a universal investment reporting methodology that allows a direct, apples-to-apples comparison of investment performance across different investment management firms, portfolios, portfolio managers, and jurisdictions.

In order to claim compliance with GIPS, institutional investors must follow the requirements for performance measurement and presentation included in GIPS. The CFA Institute also recommends independent third-party verification of investment professionals’ compliance with GIPS.

In addition to complying with GIPS, investment professionals must also follow applicable regulatory requirements related to the presentation of investment performance. For example, in the United States, SEC-sponsored financial reporting and control standards apply to companies that issue investment vehicles. In addition, insurance companies in the United States must follow state regulatory requirements for the valuation and reporting of securities held in their general account portfolios.

Besides compliance with performance reporting standards, investment professionals must follow the guidelines in each IPS. For instance, the investment function may fail to comply with an IPS by conducting portfolio transactions that are inconsistent with the portfolio’s stated risk appetite.

Institutional monitoring systems generate noncompliance reports if a portfolio manager exceeds risk limits. Other types of ongoing compliance checks ensure that a portfolio operates within specific return and risk objectives.

pages.title: Investment Objectives for Life Insurers
pages.contents:
Investment Objectives for Life Insurers

Life insurance companies manage general account and separate account portfolios. The varying needs of the different types of insurer portfolios result in differences in their respective portfolio objectives. Because the insurer bears the investment risk for general account assets but not for separate account assets, insurer investment policies focus heavily on general account portfolios. Therefore, the insurer portfolio objectives and constraints discussed in the remainder of this chapter apply mostly to general account portfolios.

A life insurance company’s general account supports many of the company’s product liabilities and other general obligations. In turn, the general account is affected by the company’s liabilities. A company’s general obligations have the following broad characteristics:

They can be lengthy, sometimes extending beyond 30 years.

They are typically illiquid and are not easily assigned a market value.

Their values can be sensitive to movements in market interest rates.

Some are specific in timing and amount—enabling the company to predict future payouts—but others have imprecise timing or unknown payouts.

They involve some risks that cannot be fully diversified or hedged.

Objectives for the general account portfolio typically require an insurance company to balance assets with liabilities so that the company

  • Always has ample capital to protect holders of the company’s general account obligations and meet regulatory requirements

  • Receives total cash inflows equal to or exceeding total cash outflows

  • Earns an optimal return for the company’s owners, while staying within regulatory constraints and the company’s performance objectives

  • Mitigates certain risk exposures between its assets and liabilities through diversification and hedging

  • Can actively manage its remaining risks after mitigating certain risk exposures

Because a life insurer needs to have cash on hand to cover product obligations and capital requirements, capital protection and current income are the main objectives for a general account portfolio. However, many contractual obligations extend years—or decades—into the future, so an insurer must also achieve appropriate rates of capital growth to cover future cash needs. By extension, insurers must accept some investment risk to achieve their long-term return objectives.

Separate account portfolios are different because the policyowners pick investment funds—called subaccounts—based on their personal investment goals. As you’ll see in Chapter 7, each subaccount has its own objective. Because policyowners pick the subaccounts, the investment function is not creating investment strategies for separate account portfolios. Instead, the insurer’s main responsibilities are to select a suitable range of fund options, perform due diligence on externally managed funds, and invest cash in selected funds on behalf of the policyowners.

 

Investment Income

When an insurance company designs a new product, it makes assumptions about the contractual obligations it can expect once the product is sold. The insurer also determines the crediting rate that policyowners will receive for an interest-bearing product.

A significant portion of an insurer’s general account profitability comes from the margin between invested asset returns and the costs to support insurer products and capital obligations. As a result, the insurer’s rate of return on the general account portfolio must, at a minimum, maintain a comfortable margin above the interest rate credited to its product liabilities.

To express the required rate of return on a general account portfolio, the insurer specifies a target yield for the portfolio and monitors actual performance relative to the target. If portfolio investments earn a yield that meets or exceeds the target, the insurer should be able to cover the crediting rate.

General account portfolios are also designed to generate sufficient investment income to meet the insurer’s cash needs. Therefore, as you will read in the next chapter, monitoring cash flows—including cash flows generated by investments—is part of an insurer’s asset-liability management (ALM) strategy.

 

Risk-Adjusted Returns

Riskier asset classes, such as stocks and real estate, have the potential to produce larger returns than safer asset classes, such as bonds. As you read earlier, to have the opportunity to earn larger returns, the insurer must generally accept more risk.

In general, investors do not consider investment returns without also considering risks. For instance, simply looking at the potential returns of stocks versus bonds would lead an investor to choose stocks every time to maximize returns. Obviously, though, not every investor is willing or able to accept the risk required for a chance to earn the potential returns that stocks offer. Therefore, investors need a way to compare investment returns across asset types while factoring in the different levels of risk associated with each type. Investors can make this comparison by calculating an asset’s risk-adjusted return, which is a measure that presents an investment return in the context of the amount of risk accepted to earn that return.

Investors use different metrics to express risk-adjusted returns. In Chapter 9, we cover specific ratios used by insurers to evaluate risk-adjusted returns. For a given portfolio, an insurer’s return objectives may designate target values for certain risk-adjusted return ratios.

 

Solvency and Liquidity

To maintain solvency, an insurance company must take prudent risks and earn sufficient returns to pay contractual obligations and cover company expenses. The investment function’s role is to take enough risk to earn adequate returns, but not so much risk that overwhelming losses occur.

Because life insurers must meet their obligations in cash, they also monitor their liquidity risk through ALM analysis. The investment function selects investments to facilitate liquidity.

In selecting investments that satisfy liquidity and solvency needs, insurers must perform a balancing act between portfolio objectives. Emphasizing capital protection will ensure that enough capital remains to satisfy liquidity needs. However, capital growth is necessary to ensure the company’s solvency.

In addition, capital growth is necessary to create and grow an insurer’s surplus, which is the cumulative amount of money that remains in an insurance company over time and is calculated as the insurer’s assets minus its liabilities and its capital. An associated return objective could be to maintain a stable level of surplus.

Insurers are subject to minimum capital and surplus requirements, which are solvency requirements that set specific minimum dollar amounts of capital and surplus for an insurer as a whole and for each of the company’s product lines. Minimum capital and surplus requirements, also known as statutory minimum capitalization requirements, are established by each jurisdiction’s insurance regulators. An insurer’s general account portfolio objectives should account for the minimum capital and surplus requirements designated by regulators.

 

Supporting Obligations

For life insurers, one of the main purposes of investing is to support product obligations. Because of the long-term nature of their liabilities and their need for steady income, insurer general account portfolios typically hold more debt securities than equity securities.

Portfolio return objectives may designate target values for debt security investments. For example, insurers can assess bond performance by measuring changes in market values, yields, and durations. By monitoring fluctuations in these values, investment professionals can determine whether a portfolio’s bond investments are adequately meeting its objectives.

pages.title: Investment Constraints for Life Insurers
pages.contents:
Investment Constraints for Life Insurers

Life insurance companies face many investment constraints in managing their general account portfolios. For instance, insurer constraints typically include

  • Liquidity. The need for liquidity to pay obligations in a timely manner requires portfolio investments that generate steady cash flows.

  • Time horizon. Life insurers have long time horizons, so they may prefer investments that can be held for long periods, such as bonds with 30 years until maturity.

  • Credit quality. To mitigate credit risk, life insurers typically hold a significant amount of securities with high credit quality, such as investment-grade bonds.

  • Regulations. Arguably the most important constraint for insurers, regulations can limit the types and amounts of risk assumed, restrict the use of certain types of assets, and require the insurer to hold certain amounts of capital.

The insurer’s investment function often faces additional constraints. For example, the investment function must incorporate risk limitations, rating and asset selection constraints, and regulatory capital requirements into portfolio planning and management.

 

Risk Limitations

An insurer’s investment function needs to be aware of the risk limits defined in the company’s risk policy. Within the investment function, investment professionals must adhere to authorization limits for securities trading.

Another risk limit in investments is a stop-loss limit, which indicates an amount of money that a portfolio’s single-period market loss should not exceed. The period may be a day, a week, a month, or longer. A limit violation occurs whenever a single-period market loss exceeds a portfolio’s stop-loss limit. In such a situation, the investment professionals should develop a plan for bringing the portfolio back to an acceptable market value.

 

Rating Constraints

Typically, insurance company bond investments are categorized by their credit quality. Corporate risk policy may require the investment function’s bond investments to possess investment-grade ratings from external credit rating agencies, such as Moody’s Investors Service and Standard & Poor’s (S&P) in the United States.

Insurance regulators also limit a life insurer’s bond holdings based on credit quality. In the United States, state regulators may require insurers to only invest in bonds that achieve a specific rating, or designation, assigned by the NAIC. The Securities Valuation Office (SVO) is the NAIC department that (1) assesses the credit quality of the fixed-income investments of insurance companies and (2) assigns designations and valuations to such investments. The NAIC’s credit rating system comprises six rating classes, ranging from NAIC 1—which represents the best rating—to NAIC 6, which represents the worst rating. Figure 5.4 lists the scales that Moody’s, S&P, and the NAIC’s SVO use for rating long-term bonds.

NAIC designations are intended for statutory accounting and financial reporting purposes in the United States. The NAIC considers its ratings to be regulatory ratings, not public ratings. Therefore, NAIC designations are not intended to aid investment decision making. In reality, however, an insurer’s investment professionals will consider NAIC designations along with agency credit ratings when evaluating potential bond purchases.

NAIC designations and valuations are particularly important for investments that are not actively traded and are not rated by external credit rating agencies, such as private placement securities. As securities exchanges do not maintain or publish transaction information involving private placement securities, NAIC designations are an important source of information for insurers investing in such securities.

Internal and external credit rating constraints are intended to protect the solvency of the insurance company, thus ensuring that the company can fulfill its obligations to its policyowners.

 

Asset Selection Constraints

As previously stated, asset allocation criteria can impose constraints on the amount of capital that can be allocated to a given asset class. For insurers, these constraints encourage diversification by restricting concentration in a given asset or asset class.

In addition to diversifying among asset classes, insurance companies can diversify within an asset class among (1) different sectors or industries or (2) different levels of creditworthiness. By diversifying a portfolio in these ways, insurers can mitigate the specific risks covered in Chapter 4.

The investment function may also face constraints on the investment vehicles it can use. Certain vehicles with greater liquidity risk—such as derivatives, private placement securities, and alternative investments—are more likely to be limited in insurer portfolios. These limitations are typically established by regulators, although a company’s risk policy may also place restrictions on particular investment vehicles.

 

Regulatory Capital

Regulatory capital, also called a capital requirement, is the legal minimum standard of capital that an insurer must maintain in order to be considered solvent by the regulatory authorities. Regulatory capital is a constraint because it requires insurers to hold money that could otherwise be invested—thus earning the company additional returns that increase profitability and grow the company’s surplus.

Insurance regulators evaluate the adequacy of an insurer’s capital by using risk-based capital requirements. Risk-based capital (RBC) requirements determine the minimum capital level for an insurer based on that insurer’s size and risk profile, as identified by a risk-weighted formula. The amount of regulatory capital that an insurer must hold is generated by the RBC formula.

RBC requirements can require insurers of the same size to hold different amounts of regulatory capital based on each insurer’s risk levels. Regulators apply risk capital charges to an insurer’s asset values to reflect each asset’s level of risk. For example, lower risk charges are applied to debt securities with the best NAIC ratings, and higher risk charges are applied to debt securities with the worst NAIC ratings. Higher risk charges mean companies with higher risks must hold higher amounts of regulatory capital. You will read more about regulatory capital requirements in Chapter 10.

Generally speaking, insurance companies are in the business of managing risk. In addition to managing risks for their customers, they are skilled at managing their own risks. To manage risks, each company conducts risk oversight at the enterprise level and the functional levels.

The risks that insurance companies manage affect the strategies they use for their investment portfolios. In this chapter, you will learn about the (1) asset-liability management (ALM) process for life insurer general accounts, (2) tools that insurers use for ALM analysis, and (3) investment strategies related to ALM.

pages.title: Enterprise Risk Management
pages.contents:
Enterprise Risk Management

Insurance companies face many types of risks across multiple parts of their businesses. Examples of regulatory, operational, financial, and strategic risks include:

Regulatory risks: New laws and regulations, changes to the regulatory environment that affect the insurance industry

Operational risks: Mispricing of products, inappropriate underwriting decisions, claims fraud, privacy and cybersecurity breaches

Financial risks: Fluctuations in market values of investments, interest-rate risk, liquidity risk

Strategic risks: Loss of market share to competitors, disruption from new entrants to the insurance industry, geopolitical risk

To address all of the risks to their businesses, most insurers engage in enterprise risk management. Enterprise risk management (ERM) is a cross-functional system that (1) identifies and quantifies risks and (2) uses a coordinated approach to manage those risks. In addition to identifying risks, ERM involves prioritizing risks based on potential losses, planning responses to potential threats, and monitoring corporate progress on controlling risks.

ERM supports a company’s strategic objectives by providing a comprehensive framework for risk management. An ERM program shapes a company’s risk policy and risk management practices. All insurer functions, including the investment function, are affected by ERM decisions.

Many external parties assess an insurer’s ERM practices. For example, regulators scrutinize the risk management function of insurance companies. In addition to ensuring regulatory compliance, an effective ERM process promotes efficient operations and prudent financial management. Thus, ERM programs are impactful to customers, employees, and other company stakeholders.

 

Asset-Liability Management

ERM encompasses asset-liability management. As previously defined, ALM coordinates risks between an insurer’s assets and its liabilities. For instance, ALM focuses on the timing of cash inflows and outflows. The ALM function monitors an insurer’s liquidity and is responsible for ensuring that the company always has enough cash available to pay its obligations on time.

ALM also ensures the company remains solvent by monitoring cash-flow issues that could cause significant financial losses over time. Thus, ALM is an important component of an insurance company’s capital management practices.

ALM involves interaction between the functions within an insurance company. For instance, in performing ALM roles, investment and actuarial professionals attempt to achieve a pattern of investment cash inflows that will, along with other kinds of cash inflows, ensure that the company’s cash on hand always remains equal to or greater than its cash outflows.

EXAMPLE

Roles of Professionals in ALM

Product actuaries: Properly design products so that cash flows from assets are able to support the products

Investment professionals: Manage investments to meet current and future demands for cash

 

ERM and ALM Systems

Because risks can be complex and interrelated, insurance companies use a number of management systems, including ERM and ALM systems. For example, ALM professionals use ALM systems to identify mismatches between asset and liability cash flows.

ERM and ALM systems

  • Collect and manage information pertaining to a company’s KPIs and KRIs

  • Generate performance dashboards and reports that senior management can use to track and analyze key metrics

  • Generate a variety of reports that provide relevant information to regulators, internal auditors, and managers of specific business lines

Typically, an ALM system includes financial modeling capabilities. A financial modelis a computer-based mathematical model that approximates the operation of real-world financial processes. Financial models rely on complex calculations to produce likely outcomes for a given set of circumstances, called modeling assumptions. As you will see, ALM professionals use financial modeling to simulate a variety of situations that can affect asset and liability cash flows.

pages.title: Organization of the ALM Function
pages.contents:
Organization of the ALM Function

The ALM function is responsible for conducting appropriate analysis, communicating the results of the analysis, recommending ALM policy, supporting ALM policy implementation, and establishing systems for ensuring that policies are implemented.

Insurance companies define the authority, roles, and accountabilities at various levels of the ALM process. While each company may have a different organizational structure for its ALM function, the function generally consists of a risk committee, an ALM committee, and an ALM unit.

 

Risk Committee

An insurance company’s board of directors establishes a permanent oversight committee to oversee the company’s ERM efforts. The risk committee, also known as the enterprise risk committee, assists the board of directors in supervising the management of the company’s assets, liabilities, capital, and risks.

The risk committee typically supervises the ALM function. The committee

  • Defines roles and assigns ALM responsibilities

  • Oversees the ALM structure and process

  • Makes decisions regarding ALM policy and implementation

The risk committee also supervises the ALM committee and coordinates that committee’s efforts within the broader ERM framework.

 

ALM Committee

The ALM committee is a cross-functional committee that reports to the board’s risk committee. Typically, the ALM committee includes senior-level personnel. Comprising selected actuarial and investment professionals, the ALM committee reviews ALM performance and recommends ALM policy changes to the risk committee.

 

ALM Unit

Most large companies also have an ALM unit that reports to the ALM committee. The ALM unit brings together actuarial and investment professionals who analyze ALM risks. Many of these professionals specialize in ALM-related job functions.

The ALM unit works at the operational level, implementing the ALM framework and performing ALM support activities. As such, the ALM unit is directly accountable for ALM performance.

pages.title: The ALM Process for General Accounts
pages.contents:
The ALM Process for General Accounts

ALM is not equally important for all the products that insurance companies offer. For instance, ALM has less importance for separate account products, in which the insurer passes investment risk directly to the customer. Therefore, this chapter concentrates on the ALM process for products supported by the general account.

For the general account, the ALM process

  • Associates assets with specified products through portfolio segmentation

  • Connects investment income with specified products through different investment income allocation methods

  • Integrates asset and liability performance in a portfolio benchmarking model

 

Portfolio Segmentation

In the context of insurance company investment portfolios, segmentation is the practice of dividing the general account into smaller groupings of assets, or segments. The insurer typically assigns each segment to a specified product line, as illustrated by the example in Figure 6.1. Thus, segmentation aligns the objectives of a portfolio segment with those of a specific product line.

Each portfolio segment may have its own set of investment objectives designed to support a particular product line. In addition, an insurer may include guidelines for circumstances unique to a particular segment. Therefore, each segment is subject to its own investment policies as well as the company’s general account investment policies.

For an insurance company, segmentation can provide multiple benefits, including

  • Supporting efforts to match asset cash flows with liability cash flows

  • Supporting efforts to manage exposure to interest-rate risk

  • Providing a clear basis for evaluating the performance of each product line relative to its management objectives

  • Facilitating communication between the actuarial and investment functions

Portfolio segmentation provides a framework for analyzing general account assets and can aid managers in decision-making. However, segmentation is simply a convenient way of organizing assets; ultimately, all general account assets are available to support any liabilities of the general account.

 

Investment Income Allocation

For insurers, two primary sources of income are premiums and investments. Premium income is closely identified with a specified product. Thus, allocation of premium income within a company’s accounting system is usually straightforward.

However, investment income may not be clearly connected with a given product or product line. Therefore, companies establish internal investment income allocation methods to reasonably and fairly assign investment income to product lines.

Companies can develop various methods for assigning general account investment income. Two common investment income allocation methods are the mean liabilities method and the investment segmentation method.

 

Mean Liabilities Method

For an insurer, reserves are liabilities that represent the amounts of money that the insurer expects to need to meet future contractual obligations. With the mean liabilities method, an insurer assigns investment income to each of its product lines in proportion to the reserves attributed to that product line. For example, if 40% of the insurer’s reserves are attributable to group life insurance, then the group life product line will receive 40% of the general account’s investment income.

One problem associated with the mean liabilities method is that newer lines of business may be allocated a share of the investment income generated by older, high-yielding investments that were purchased before the new products existed. For example, in a falling interest rate environment, (1) newer product lines generally have lower liability amounts and require less investment income than older product lines, and (2) the insurer’s newer investments generally have lower yields than its older investments, which were purchased during periods of higher interest rates. In this case, the insurer is partially supporting older product lines with investments that have lower yields than assumed during product development. Therefore, the insurer’s general account investments may not generate enough income to fully support the liabilities of the older products.

EXAMPLE

Reserves attributable to the group life product line account for 40% of an insurer’s total reserves. Under the mean liabilities method of investment income allocation, the line receives 40% of investment income generated by the insurer’s general account assets. Accordingly, the amount of investment income that the group life product line received increased from Year 1 to Year 2 and decreased from Year 2 to Year 3. During product development, the insurer estimated that the group life product line would require annual investment income of $3,500,000. Based on the above allocations, the product line received sufficient income in Year 1 and Year 2, but insufficient income in Year 3.

 

Investment Segmentation Method

In the investment segmentation method, an insurance company uses the cash flows associated with a product line or portfolio segment to purchase specific assets for that line or segment. In essence, each segment’s products generate premiums that are used to purchase assets that the segment “owns.” As such, the segment receives any investment income that its assets generate.

Under this method, an insurer can develop separate investment strategies for different lines of business. Such versatility is important because cash flow patterns and investment income requirements differ among product lines. For instance, the cash flows of an insurer’s annuity products differ from those of its whole life insurance products.

The investment segmentation method of investment income allocation is best illustrated through an example. Video 6.1 demonstrates the investment segmentation method in action.

In comparison with the mean liabilities method, each product line has more certainty regarding the amount of investment income that it will receive under the investment segmentation method. For a particular segment—which is usually associated with a specific product line—the insurer selects assets that will earn enough investment income to support the segment’s cash flow needs. Because the segment knows which assets it “owns,” it can predict the amount of investment income those assets will pay. The following chart summarizes and compares the mean liabilities method and the investment segmentation method.

Investment Segmentation Method

Purpose of Method

Basis for Investment Income Allocation

Proportional. A product line’s share of the total investment income is based on the percentage of total reserves that are attributable to that particular line.

In general, is the method sensitive to the income needs of each product line or segment?

No. This method splits investment income proportionally. If the total amount of income generated declines over time, some product lines may receive an insufficient amount of income, regardless of the share they receive.

Yes. The insurer can tailor its asset purchases for a particular segment to meet the segment’s distinct investment income needs.
 

Integrated Portfolio Benchmarking Model

In the previous chapter, you learned that investment professionals use benchmarks to evaluate portfolio performance. Insurance companies can take the portfolio benchmarking concept and apply it to general account assets and liabilities. We call this approach the integrated portfolio benchmarking model.

While each company’s integrated portfolio benchmarking model will be different, these models generally contain

  • Actual portfolios. The insurer’s general account is represented by current or “actual” portfolios comprising similar groupings, such as assets or liabilities. The actual portfolios are managed according to specific objectives.

  • Strategic benchmarks. Actual portfolios are matched with strategic benchmarks. These benchmarks support planning, control, and performance analysis.

In the remainder of this section, we describe one possible version of an integrated portfolio benchmarking model, as seen in Figure 6.2.

 

Actual Portfolios

In our sample model, the three actual portfolios the insurance company creates are the

  • Assets portfolio, which contains all of the insurer’s general account assets

  • Liabilities portfolio, which represents the insurer’s contractual obligations to customers

  • Capital portfolio—sometimes known as the surplus portfolio—which represents the assets remaining after liabilities are subtracted from general account assets

These portfolios are the objects of analysis in the integrated model. For analytical purposes, the model treats liabilities as contra assets, meaning they act as offsets against assets. As contra assets, the liabilities represent claims against assets and take on negative values.

General account assets back both the company’s liabilities and its capital. However, companies differ in how they apply benchmarking information to the assets backing their capital. For example, some companies combine the actual portfolios backing liabilities and capital. In contrast, other companies assign the assets backing capital to an actual capital portfolio and a capital benchmark. (In our model and Figure 6.2, we use the latter approach.)

 

Strategic Benchmarks

Using the integrated portfolio benchmarking model, actual portfolios are evaluated and analyzed against the performance results of their expected benchmarks. As Figure 6.2 shows, our sample model uses four benchmarks:

  • Assets benchmark. The assets benchmark serves as the performance standard for a company’s actual assets portfolio. To develop the benchmark, companies typically assemble a suitable grouping of market indexes and blend the index performance data in appropriate proportions. The resulting blend should have a similar allocation as the assets portfolio to enable effective performance evaluation.

  • Liabilities benchmark. The liabilities benchmark serves as the performance standard for a company’s actual liabilities portfolio. We discuss developing a specific type of liabilities benchmark in the next section.

  • Asset-liability (A/L) benchmark. If a company uses modeling software to create its integrated model, it may use the software to combine the actual assets and liabilities portfolios. In this case, the resulting asset-liability portfolio is compared to an integrated asset-liability (A/L) benchmark. Based on the insurer’s risk and return objectives, the modeling software develops an A/L benchmark to reflect an ideal proportion of assets to liabilities.

  • Capital benchmark. The capital benchmark—also called the surplus benchmark—serves as the performance standard for a company’s actual capital portfolio. To develop a capital benchmark, modeling software determines the best possible performance for the assets backing the company’s capital while taking into account its risk tolerances.

Insurance companies can develop strategic benchmarks by using optimization modeling, which is a form of mathematical modeling that focuses on finding an optimal solution to several simultaneous equations. To optimize a portfolio, the model searches for an ideal or “optimal” combination of risk and return measures, in which return is maximized for a specified level of risk.

Modeling software develops an optimal A/L portfolio and A/L benchmark. An insurer uses the A/L portfolio as a target portfolio because it represents the ideal long-run positioning for its general account assets after factoring in its liability considerations.

The insurer uses investment strategies to reposition assets so that the assets portfolio will eventually acquire the risk-and-return profile of the A/L benchmark. As the strategies are implemented over time, the asset allocations will shift, and the assets benchmark will migrate until it more closely resembles the A/L benchmark. Therefore, insurers use the A/L benchmark as a long-term target for the performance of general account assets.

The characteristics of the actual liabilities portfolio change over time with the addition of new liabilities. As the liabilities portfolio changes, the liabilities benchmark and the A/L benchmark change accordingly.

By comparing the changes in the A/L benchmark to changes in the assets benchmark and liabilities benchmark, insurance companies can examine the different benchmark performances. Such analysis (1) may provide insights into the performance of their assets and liabilities portfolios and (2) can indicate which portfolios need adjustments if benchmarks are not being met.

 

Replicating Portfolio for Liabilities

One type of liabilities benchmark that insurance companies develop for their benchmarking portfolios is a replicating portfolio. For an insurance company, a replicating portfolio is a virtual pool of assets created to mimic the cash flows and market values observed in a specified pool of liabilities.

Portfolio modeling professionals view insurance products as having an identifiable set of financial risk and return characteristics—such as fixed cash flows, distributions of dividends or excess interest, and minimum guaranteed values. Therefore, to create a replicating portfolio for a pool of liabilities, a modeler finds publicly traded investment vehicles that match the identified risk and return characteristics of the liability pool. Figure 6.3 lists the steps for creating a replicating portfolio.

First, modelers identify market-traded assets that exhibit the financial risk and return characteristics of the company’s liabilities. Then they select market indexes that display the relevant characteristics of the selected asset classes. Published market indexes do not directly reflect replicating portfolio market values because insurance company liabilities are not generally traded in public securities markets. However, market indexes for publicly traded assets can be used as source data for replicating portfolios.

After choosing market indexes, modelers assemble the component market indexes in suitable proportions to form a virtual portfolio that reasonably approximates the financial profile of a given product type—or even the company’s entire pool of liabilities. In essence, the insurer is choosing assets that will behave like its liabilities. For example, the cash flows of a selected group of bonds with 10 years until maturity could replicate the cash flows of a group of term life policies with 10 years until expiration.

Liability cash flows can be hard to estimate for some insurance products, so a replicating portfolio is unlikely to be a perfect match for an actual liability pool. Nevertheless, creating a replicating portfolio on a best-efforts basis is a valuable exercise for an insurance company.

Insurers can use replicating portfolios to measure liability performance or to run simulations in quantitative models. For example, by using assets with obtainable market values as a proxy for liability market values, insurance companies can quickly model the effects that changes in financial conditions have on their liability pools.

In addition, replicating portfolios allow insurance companies to create an integrated view of assets and liabilities, which they can use to perform detailed analysis of ALM risks. 1 Thus, replicating portfolios provide risk management and decision-making benefits.

pages.title: Tools for ALM Analysis
pages.contents:
Tools for ALM Analysis

ALM professionals at life insurance companies monitor anticipated cash flows and project the future values of their assets, liabilities, and capital. They also use asset adequacy analysis, which determines whether the company’s assets are sufficient to support certain reserves and other liabilities. In addition, asset adequacy analysis tests the liquidity of assets, which is important because insurers must be able to pay obligations in cash on short notice.

As part of ALM, insurers need to be able to measure their risk exposures and asset adequacy. Insurers use cash-flow testing and a variety of reports as tools for their ALM analysis.

 

Cash-Flow Testing

For insurance companies, the most popular method of asset adequacy analysis is cash-flow testing. Cash-flow testing uses simulation modeling to project the cash flows associated with an insurance company’s assets and liabilities as of a given valuation date in the future. Insurers can also use cash-flow testing to compare the timing and amounts of asset and liability cash flows at various times after the valuation date.

Insurance companies generally use cash-flow testing when the cash flows of assets, products, or other liabilities have the potential to vary under different economic scenarios, such as an increase in inflation or a decrease in market interest rates. Insurers use financial modeling software to project the future values of cash

  • Inflows from investments. Projection begins with asset values and applies mathematical processes to reflect the company’s assumptions for prevailing market interest rates, inflation or deflation rates, asset return rates, asset prepayment rates, asset default rates, and reinvestment rates.

  • Outflows to support products. Projection begins with data about liability reserve values and applies processes to reflect (1) assumptions about interest rates and other economic variables, (2) anticipated product cash outflows—including interest-crediting rates on certain products—and (3) policyowner behavior variables, such as withdrawal and surrender rates.

Modeling uses assumptions to generate probable outcomes, but a model’s output is only as good as its inputs. Thus, insurers must select appropriate assumptions for use in their models. Acceptable assumptions can be based on data from a company’s historical experience, data from industry studies, or random variables based on statistical distributions. Insurers conduct back-testing, which involves applying the models and their assumptions to known past data, to see if the models produce accurate projections of known data. By back-testing models and assumptions, insurers can identify areas for improvement.

To test the adequacy of cash flows, insurers analyze the projected net cash flow values for their assets and liabilities. Two common approaches to this analysis are sensitivity analysis and scenario testing.

 

Sensitivity Analysis

Insurers can run multiple simulations to understand the effects that increases or decreases in a given variable would have on their assets and liabilities portfolios. In other words, they can determine how sensitive their portfolios are to changes in that one variable through sensitivity analysis. Sensitivity analysisis a method of measuring the responsiveness of the outputs produced by a mathematical model to changes in the values of the model’s input variables.

Insurers can apply sensitivity analysis to an entire portfolio or to just a portfolio segment. For example, by changing the assumed surrender rate for its whole life insurance product, an insurer can see how various surrender rates affect the liabilities portfolio segment devoted to whole life policies.

An important type of sensitivity analysis for insurers is duration analysis, which evaluates the market-value sensitivity of assets and liabilities portfolios to changes in market interest rates. ALM professionals compare the two portfolios for differences in duration. A duration gap is a type of ALM mismatch in which the asset duration does not match the liability duration. Duration gaps can be

  • Positive, meaning asset duration is greater than liability duration. If interest rates change, asset values will move more than liability values.

  • Negative, meaning asset duration is less than liability duration. If interest rates change, asset values will move less than liability values.

Whether a duration gap is good or bad for an insurer depends on the type of gap and the direction of market interest rate changes. Regardless, the ALM function tries to avoid duration gaps. As you will see later in this chapter, investment professionals have a technique for narrowing duration gaps.

 

Scenario Testing

Using financial modeling simulations, insurance companies project multiple scenarios for their assets and liabilities portfolios. Scenario testing is a method of evaluating modeling results that involves entering different sets of data—which represent a given scenario—into a model and then determining how changes in the input data affect the model’s output.

Unlike sensitivity analysis, which changes the input of one variable between a series of simulations, scenario testing changes the inputs of multiple variables for a single simulation. As such, scenario testing seeks to identify the probable outcome given a particular set of circumstances. For example, one testable scenario is an economic recession, which would involve a contracting economic growth rate, falling market interest rates, and, generally, falling asset values.

For each scenario, ALM professionals assign values to their assumptions that reflect the scenario’s characteristics. Then they run their model to simulate the scenario, which generates outcomes for the assets portfolio and the liabilities portfolio. ALM professionals run multiple simulations, moderately changing input values for each scenario, to create a variety of outcomes that they can study.

Typically, insurers run multiple interest-rate scenarios to test cash flows for their assets and liabilities portfolios. Examples of other possible scenarios to test are different economic growth stages or financial market environments.

Insurers can include stress tests as part of their scenario testing protocol. A stress test is a form of scenario testing that uses an extreme scenario, such as a severe economic downturn, to test a portfolio’s expected performance during adverse conditions. Since the 2007–2008 financial crisis, the results of stress tests are of increasing interest to regulators around the world.

Sensitivity Analysis or Scenario Testing?

Sensitivity analysis and scenario testing both start with selecting all of the variable inputs for the first simulation, but differ in the number of variables changed in subsequent simulations. Thus, the number of variables changed depends on the purpose of the simulations.

If you are changing the input of one variable in multiple simulations to see how much a portfolio responds, you are conducting sensitivity analysis. For example, run multiple simulations with different values for the market interest rate if you want to determine how sensitive your portfolio is to market interest rate changes. By keeping the values of other variables constant, you can isolate the effects of market interest rate changes on your portfolio.

If you are changing the inputs of multiple variables in a single simulation to see how a portfolio responds to a particular set of inputs, you are conducting scenario testing. For example, if you want to see how your portfolio would respond during a recession, input values that reflect conditions during a recession—such as a low value for the economic growth rate and a high value for the unemployment rate. In addition, you could determine how your portfolio would respond if the recession worsens by testing another scenario with less favorable variable inputs than the first recession scenario—such as a lower economic growth rate value and a higher unemployment rate value.

 

Internal Reports

Insurance companies use a variety of internal reports for ALM. Some reports provide details concerning the company’s liabilities. Other reports provide details about investments in the assets portfolio. Some common investment reports are the investment activity report, investment portfolio performance review, duration gap report, risk positioning report, and hedge effectiveness report.

 

Investment Activity Report

An investment activity report specifies the details of all investment portfolio transactions, including all asset acquisitions and all dispositions of assets from the portfolio through sales, prepayments, or repayment at maturity. The report also specifies realized and unrealized capital gain and loss status, estimated investment returns, and the portfolio’s risk metrics in relation to the company’s risk policies.

Although narrow in scope, the investment activity report is usually the most detailed and most frequently produced of the investment reports used for ALM purposes. For instance, for each newly acquired debt security, the investment activity report typically provides the asset’s yield, term to maturity, duration, and quality ratings.

 

Investment Portfolio Performance Review

An investment portfolio performance review is a management report that presents a portfolio’s investment performance for presentation to the company’s oversight committees. This report is usually the broadest in scope of any ALM report, but is not the most detailed because it covers much of the information in summary form.

The investment portfolio performance review typically presents quarterly and year-to-date information about the following aspects of investment performance:

  • Details about overall growth trends in the portfolio’s monetary value, specified in terms of market value appreciation and income growth

  • Analysis of realized capital gains and losses

  • Analysis of changes in asset market values

  • Summary of purchases and sales of assets by asset type

  • Analysis of the effect of purchases and sales on asset yields

  • Discussion of the portfolio’s asset allocation, including the suitability of the current asset mix

  • Explanations of key events in the external environment that affect investments and the company’s strategic responses to those events

  • Summary reports on special topics such as problem assets, real estate investments, and international investments

 

Duration Gap Report

A duration gap report provides a snapshot of a company’s asset-liability match at the time of the report. Typically, the duration gap report is submitted quarterly to the company’s board of directors.

The report describes the results of duration analysis of the company’s assets and liabilities and discusses the insurer’s current exposure to cash-flow mismatches arising from changes in market interest rates. Even small changes in market interest rates can produce dramatic changes in the asset-liability duration gap, so information in the gap report is time-sensitive.

A duration gap report can include (1) duration statistics for assets and liabilities portfolios and (2) actual portfolio durations as compared to target portfolio durations.

 

Risk Positioning Report

For fixed-income assets, a risk positioning report typically shows an actual versus target comparison for security quality, duration, and performance relative to benchmarks. For assets portfolios, the report shows how far current asset allocations have drifted from the intended allocations.

 

Hedge Effectiveness Report

Many insurance companies use derivatives in their general accounts for hedging purposes. Each hedge position is intended to directly offset a specified financial risk. For a given hedge position, any change in the underlying risk exposure could prevent the hedge from fulfilling its intended purpose of risk reduction. Furthermore, these changes could cause derivative use to increase the financial risks to the company.

Typically, insurers apply statistical tests on at least a quarterly basis to establish the effectiveness of their hedging positions. Hedge effectiveness describes the extent to which a hedge position actually reduces risk in a portfolio. The hedge effectiveness report provides information on every position established for hedging purposes.

A particular hedge can lose its effectiveness when the insurance company

  • Purchases another derivative security that creates a better match

  • Sells the asset that formerly required a hedge

  • Reinsures a product liability that formerly required a hedge

  • Sells a product line that formerly required a hedge
