pages.title: Investment Strategies Related to ALM
pages.contents:
Investment Strategies Related to ALM

As part of an ALM framework, investment professionals coordinate investments to cover outgoing cash flows with incoming cash flows, both in the present and the future. However, financial risks—such as interest-rate risk and liquidity risk—can jeopardize cash flows.

To hedge against financial risks, investment professionals use derivatives—as you will read about in Chapter 8. In addition, they use portfolio management strategies such as portfolio immunization, portfolio dedication, and interest-rate anticipation. The strategy selected typically depends on the needs of each portfolio segment. In some situations, investment professionals apply aspects of several strategies to a particular segment.

 

Portfolio Immunization

Because life insurer investment portfolios contain debt securities, these portfolios are exposed to interest-rate risk. Investment professionals can protect portfolios from interest-rate risk through a complex investment strategy called portfolio immunization. In general, a portfolio immunization strategy consists of any measures taken to protect a portfolio against risk due to interest-rate changes. Effective immunization positions a portfolio so that the portfolio’s value is insensitive—or “immune”—to small changes in interest-rate risk.

 

Duration Matching

Insurers typically achieve portfolio immunization through the technique of duration matching, which involves matching the duration statistics for fixed-income assets—such as bonds—with the duration statistics for the insurance company liabilities that the assets support.

EXAMPLE

 Dexicos Life Insurance Company’s assets portfolio has a duration of six years. Its liabilities portfolio has a duration of seven years. To reduce the mismatch, the company’s investment professionals identify and purchase assets that will increase the assets portfolio’s duration.

Analysis: Once the assets portfolio’s duration is seven years, the duration difference will be zero and the general account portfolio’s duration gap will be closed.

Ideally, the assets duration perfectly matches the liabilities duration. However, because a perfect duration match is often difficult to obtain, life insurance companies usually set duration objectives in which the assets duration slightly exceeds the liabilities duration. With this approach, when interest rates are high and start to fall, asset values will rise faster than liability values. For assets and liabilities with long durations, duration matching is particularly important because their market values are more sensitive to market interest-rate changes.

Duration matching can be difficult to implement and maintain. Because the technique involves complicated duration calculations, investment professionals rely on optimization software. In addition, asset and liability durations do not stay constant, so professionals have to make periodic adjustments to keep durations matched. Furthermore, life insurers may have trouble finding assets with durations long enough to match the long durations of certain liabilities, such as contractual obligations for whole life insurance and annuity products.

Another drawback of duration matching is that it does not appropriately address insurer cash flow needs. For example, even when the asset and liability durations are matched, the asset cash inflows could be insufficient to match the liability cash outflows, which would threaten the insurer’s surplus.

 

Portfolio Dedication

Another ALM-related investment strategy for insurers involves the linking of asset and liability cash flows. A portfolio dedication strategy consists of deliberately structuring a portfolio of assets so that the anticipated future cash flows from those assets match the future cash needs that the portfolio was assembled to fulfill.

 

Cash-Flow Matching

Typically, insurers achieve portfolio dedication through the technique of cash-flow matching, which involves identifying the patterns of cash outflows for insurance products and matching those cash outflows with a selection of assets that will produce a similar pattern of cash inflows. In other words, portfolio assets are selected for their ability to generate cash inflows that offset the estimated cash outflows related to an insurer’s liabilities.

EXAMPLE

Dexicos Life has a cash flow mismatch between its assets and liabilities portfolios. In a given year, Dexicos is projected to have $25 million in inflows from assets but $30 million in outflows for liabilities. Investment professionals select and purchase a collection of bonds with varying face values, coupon rates, and maturity dates to bring projected cash inflows from assets to $30 million.

Analysis: By selecting assets with certain characteristics, Dexicos was able to match cash inflows with outflows. Thus, cash-flow matching reduced the risk that the company will not have enough cash to meet its contractual obligations.

In general, cash-flow matching works well for life insurance companies because their liabilities are fairly predictable and relatively long. Life insurers typically buy fixed-income investments to ensure predictable cash inflows. For debt securities, they plan to hold the securities until maturity, so they select securities with terms to maturity that match the anticipated length of time of their liabilities.

Cash-flow matching does have its drawbacks, though. Because many life insurers have large liabilities, they need to find enough assets with matching cash flow characteristics that also fall within their risk limits. These risk limits preclude certain investment options—for example, callable bonds are unattractive because they can be called before their maturity date, reducing the cash inflows available for matching to liability cash outflows.

Another challenge concerns the liability cash outflows that need matching. For instance, less predictable liability cash outflows are harder to match with asset cash inflows. In addition, the size of the liabilities can add complexity to the cash-flow matching exercise. Thus, insurers may require optimization software to maximize a portfolio dedication strategy.

Note that cash-flow matching can also be part of a portfolio immunization strategy. Asset cash inflows are matched to liability cash outflows in such a way that the portfolio’s cash flows are protected from interest-rate changes. For life insurers, cash-flow matching may be a more effective technique for immunizing a portfolio than duration matching. The following chart compares the techniques of duration matching and cash-flow matching.

 

Duration Matching

Cash-Flow Matching

Benefits
  • Ensures that a portfolio’s value is insensitive to small changes in interest-rate risk
  • Useful in protecting values of portfolios with long durations
  • Ensures that cash inflows from assets offset cash outflows related to liabilities
  • Generally well-suited to life insurance companies

Drawbacks
  • Requires periodic adjustments to keep asset and liability durations matched
  • May be difficult to find assets with durations that are long enough
  • Does not address cash-flow needs
  • May be difficult to find enough assets within risk limits that have required characteristics
  • Requires predictable liability cash outflows
 

Interest-Rate Anticipation

An investment professional using an interest-rate anticipation strategy trades fixed-income securities in anticipation of estimated future changes in market interest rates. This strategy has the objectives of (1) preserving capital when interest rates are increasing and (2) achieving capital appreciation when interest rates are decreasing.

Investment professionals can attain interest-rate anticipation objectives by altering a portfolio’s duration. Recall that portfolios with longer durations tend to gain the most in market value when interest rates decrease and lose the most in market value when interest rates increase. Therefore, when investment professionals expect interest rates to

  • Decrease, they should take steps to increase a portfolio’s duration, thus positioning the portfolio for larger gains in market value as rates decrease

  • Increase, they should take steps to reduce a portfolio’s duration, thus positioning the portfolio for smaller losses in market value as rates increase

EXAMPLE

Marie Gaudet manages a fixed-income portfolio. She expects market interest rates to decrease over the next three months. In anticipation of the rate changes, she sells some shorter-duration bonds from the portfolio and purchases bonds with longer durations to replace them.

Analysis: Marie’s transactions changed the composition of the portfolio and increased its overall duration. If interest rates decrease as Marie anticipates, her trades have positioned the portfolio for additional market-value gains.

If successful, an interest-rate anticipation strategy reduces interest-rate risk. However, this strategy is risky because it relies on the ability of investment professionals to accurately predict how and when market interest rates will change.

Typically, an investment professional uses an interest-rate anticipation strategy for the short-term positioning of interest-sensitive securities. For instance, some insurance companies may use the strategy for short-term positioning within certain portfolio segments. However, insurers generally consider the strategy to be unsuitable for entire general account portfolios.

As you will see in the next three chapters, the process of managing portfolios for institutional investors is a continuous process. This chapter introduces the first part of this process: portfolio construction. Portfolio construction is the systematic approach to building a portfolio of asset classes and allocations in accordance with the portfolio’s objectives and constraints. Subsequent chapters will cover strategies for managing institutional portfolios and evaluating portfolio performance. Figure 7.1 outlines the portfolio management process.

In the first part of this chapter, you will read about how investment professionals generally construct portfolios for institutional investors. These concepts apply to the general account portfolios of life insurance companies.

pages.title: Planning for Institutional Investment Portfolios
pages.contents:
Planning for Institutional Investment Portfolios

The institutional investment process begins with planning. One important aspect of this planning is portfolio construction. Thoughtful portfolio construction lays the foundation for investment success. Without structure within the portfolio, investment activities can become unfocused, and the portfolio could fail to achieve its objectives.

How Institutional Investing Is Like Cooking a Meal

Common Elements

Cooking a Meal

Institutional Investing

Objective

Your cooking objective is to prepare a particular meal.

An institutional investor has specific risk and return objectives for an investment portfolio.

Guidelines

The meal’s recipe provides the instructions that you use to cook the meal.

Investment professionals use stated objectives and other guidelines from the investment policy statement (IPS) to manage the portfolio’s assets.

Ingredients

You need specific ingredients to carry out the recipe’s instructions.

Each asset in the portfolio is like an ingredient in a recipe—it serves a particular purpose in achieving the end result.

Marketplace

You can buy the ingredients you need at the grocery store.

Investment professionals purchase assets through financial markets.

Preparation

You prepare a grocery list, which helps you identify what you need for the recipe when you arrive at the store.

Portfolio construction is like putting together a grocery list. Investment professionals construct the portfolio to meet its objectives.

Shopping

At the store, you use your grocery list as a guide while you search for, select, and buy the ingredients you need.

In the markets, investment professionals use a portfolio’s strategic asset allocation to guide them as they search for, select, and buy assets for the portfolio.

Implementation

When cooking the meal, you incorporate the ingredients in the proportions specified by the recipe.

Once they have a portfolio’s assets in place in the correct proportions, investment professionals can begin implementing portfolio management strategies, similar to the chef cooking the meal.

Evaluation

After the meal is finished, you evaluate the results of your cooking. Did the meal come out as intended?

During periodic reviews, investment professionals evaluate how well the portfolio achieved its objectives.

Analysis: As the grocery store has its variety of products, the financial marketplace offers many investments from which to choose. Without their “grocery list,” investors may get distracted and wander around the marketplace, picking investments that are appealing but do not help with achieving portfolio objectives.

 

The portfolio construction process involves

  • Determining the portfolio’s objectives and constraints

  • Identifying asset classes that are appropriate for the portfolio

  • Structuring the asset allocation to align the portfolio’s risk and return characteristics with its objectives and constraints

  • Selecting appropriate benchmarks to measure the portfolio’s performance

  • Evaluating and purchasing individual assets within each asset class included in the portfolio

 

Determining Portfolio Objectives and Constraints

As you read in Chapter 5, institutional portfolio planning involves determining the portfolio’s purpose, objectives, and constraints. Institutions create investment policies that provide investment professionals with guidance on required returns, risk appetite, risk tolerance, risk limits, and restrictions on investment practices. Investment professionals periodically review a portfolio’s investment policy statement (IPS) to ensure that it accurately reflects the portfolio’s circumstances and requirements.

Insurance companies set investment policies at the corporate level, but particular portfolios—such as ones devoted to certain segments or product lines—can have additional policies or requirements that require attention during portfolio construction. For example, the investment professionals working on a portfolio dedicated to fixed annuity products tailor the portfolio to meet specific return requirements.

 

Identifying Appropriate Asset Classes

Once investment professionals know a portfolio’s objectives and constraints, they consider which asset classes to include in the portfolio. Remember that an IPS can include limitations on which asset classes are acceptable for a given portfolio.

In addition, the investment function may provide investment professionals with a list of approved asset classes and sub-asset classes from which to choose. An asset class is a broad categorization, while a sub-asset class is a more detailed subset within an asset class that groups assets by common characteristics. For instance, within the bond asset class, investors could group sub-asset classes by

  • Issuer—such as with corporate, municipal, and sovereign bonds

  • Credit quality—such as with investment-grade and non-investment-grade bonds

  • Location—such as with domestic and foreign bonds

  • Maturity—such as with short-term, intermediate-term, and long-term bonds

Sub-asset classes help investors diversify their holdings within an asset class. Therefore, investment professionals use sub-asset classes to further customize a given portfolio’s risk profile.

In general, investment professionals work with an institution to determine the asset classes and sub-asset classes that are appropriate for a given portfolio. Recall that investors expect assets within an asset class to behave similarly, but each class may behave differently than other classes depending on the market environment. Investment professionals select each asset class in a portfolio for the particular risk and return features that it contributes to the overall portfolio.

EXAMPLE

For a portfolio with a capital growth objective and a long time horizon, Kinnow Asset Management plans to allocate a significant portion to the equities asset class.

Analysis: The higher volatility associated with equities is not a problem for this portfolio because of its longer time horizon. In addition, equities are more likely to produce large investment gains over time, so this asset class will help the portfolio achieve its growth objective.

 

Setting the Strategic Asset Allocation

After investment professionals identify which asset classes they want to use for a given portfolio, they need to determine the weighting to give each class. The result of this determination is the portfolio’s strategic asset allocation (SAA), which is the set of asset-class weights designed to most effectively achieve a portfolio’s long-term objectives, while remaining consistent with the investor’s risk tolerance and investment constraints.

A portfolio’s SAA reflects the expert judgment of investment professionals on the most effective asset-class weightings. Professionals design the SAA to give a portfolio the proper exposures to systematic risks, as well as to balance those risks in the best proportions for the portfolio. In other words, the SAA assigns appropriate proportions to systematic risk exposures. For example, a portfolio’s bond allocation can mitigate its exposure to the systematic risks inherent in its equity investments.

Setting the SAA is a deliberate, analytical process. Besides addressing the portfolio’s investment objectives and constraints, the SAA should incorporate the expected returns and standard deviations of returns of each asset class. For instance, if a portfolio needs to earn at least a certain rate of return each year, investment professionals must assign an appropriate weighting to asset classes that are capable of generating sufficient returns and can be reasonably expected to do so.

Arriving at the best possible SAA is challenging, so investment professionals use financial modeling to evaluate potential allocation choices. To select the SAA, they

  • Study the relationships between asset classes by conducting asset class correlation analysis

  • Run modeling to find the optimal asset class weightings for a given portfolio

  • Run additional modeling to test optimized allocations against various economic scenarios

  • Choose the optimized allocation that best fits their portfolio’s needs

 

Asset Class Correlation Analysis

Because each asset class behaves differently, a portfolio can reduce risk by diversifying among asset classes. To assess the potential diversification benefits that can result from including various asset-class pairings in a portfolio, investment professionals conduct correlation analysis. In the context of investing, correlation analysis is a statistical technique that measures the strength of the relationship between a pair of asset classes.

Two asset classes are correlated when a change in the market value of one asset class corresponds to a change in the market value of another asset class. Depending on the nature of the relationship, a pair of asset classes can be positively or negatively correlated. If the correlation is

  • Positive, the values of the asset classes move in the same direction

  • Negative, the values of the asset classes move in opposite directions

Positive correlation does not mean that the change in values is always positive for both asset classes. The values for both classes could go down during a given period; if positively correlated, the values go down together. Video 7.1 presents examples of positive and negative correlation for a pair of asset classes.

Video 7.1 Positive and Negative Correlation between Two Asset Classes

Positive and Negative Correlation between Two Asset Classes

Investment professionals can evaluate the strength of the relationship between two asset classes by using the correlation coefficient. The correlation coefficientis a statistical measure that indicates how closely movements in two asset classes track one another. The correlation coefficient expresses the risk correlation for any pairing of assets.

Correlation coefficient values range from –1, which represents perfect negative correlation, to +1, which represents perfect positive correlation. For instance, if two asset classes have a correlation coefficient of +1, then an increase in the values of one asset class corresponds to an exactly equal increase in the values of the other asset class. The following table indicates the strength of the correlation associated with certain ranges of correlation coefficient values.

Correlation Coefficient of Asset-Class Pair

Strength of Correlation

Equal to –1

Perfect negative correlation

Between –1 and –0.5

Strong negative correlation

Between –0.5 and 0

Modest negative correlation

Equal to 0

No correlation

Between 0 and +0.5

Modest positive correlation

Between +0.5 and +1

Strong positive correlation

Equal to +1

Perfect positive correlation

If two asset classes in a given portfolio are positively correlated, the portfolio faces the heightened risk that a market event will negatively affect the asset holdings from both classes at the same time, potentially resulting in larger losses for the investor. The stronger the positive correlation, the more the investor could potentially lose. However, by holding two asset classes that are negatively correlated, the portfolio avoids having all the asset values moving together. Therefore, pairing asset classes with negative correlations reduces the volatility of the portfolio’s overall returns.

EXAMPLE

In general, stocks and bonds are negatively correlated. Assume that a portfolio holds assets from both asset classes. When the portfolio’s stock holdings are increasing in market value, its bond holdings are typically decreasing in value. Likewise, when its bond holdings are increasing in market value, its stock holdings are typically decreasing in value.

Analysis: In essence, holding both stocks and bonds helps the portfolio “smooth out” its returns. Traditionally, negative returns in one asset class are usually offset by positive returns in the other. Thus, pairing these two asset classes increases the likelihood that, at any point in time, the portfolio holds some assets that are gaining in value.

Theoretically, a portfolio receives the greatest diversification benefits by pairing two asset classes with perfect negative correlation. However, finding a pair of asset classes with perfect negative correlation is extremely unlikely in practice.

Investment professionals compare the correlation coefficient of one asset-class pairing to coefficients of other pairings to identify the best diversification possibilities. Investment professionals recognize that even asset classes with a strong positive correlation do not behave exactly alike. Thus, while negatively correlated asset classes are preferable, any two classes with a correlation coefficient of lower than +1 provide some diversification benefits to a portfolio.

To compare correlation coefficients, investment professionals can use an asset-class correlation matrix, which is a table showing the correlation coefficients for all potential pairs of asset classes. Figure 7.2 is an example of a possible correlation matrix for several asset classes.

EXAMPLE

Cora Friel, a portfolio manager, is constructing a new portfolio. She already knows the portfolio will have a significant allocation to U.S. large-cap stocks. Therefore, she wants to add another asset class that will offer diversification benefits to her portfolio. Using the correlation coefficient data from the first column of Figure 7.2’s asset-class correlation matrix, what asset classes should she consider selecting?

Analysis: Any asset class with a correlation coefficient lower than +1 will provide some diversification benefits when paired with U.S. large-cap stocks. However, Cora will maximize the portfolio’s diversification benefit by selecting the asset class with the largest negative correlation coefficient—the coefficient closest to –1. If none of the asset classes are negatively correlated with U.S. large-cap stocks, she should select the asset class with the smallest positive correlation coefficient—the coefficient closest to 0. Based on Figure 7.2’s data, Cora should pair U.S. large-cap stocks with U.S. TIPS bonds (correlation coefficient of –0.05). Pairing U.S. large-cap stocks with cash (–0.03) or non-U.S. bonds (+0.05) would also be good choices.

While an asset-class correlation matrix is a useful tool during portfolio construction, asset-class correlations can shift over time, undermining the assumptions that investment professionals made when selecting the asset classes. Therefore, investment professionals monitor changes in asset-class correlations and may need to adjust a portfolio’s strategic asset allocation during a periodic review.

 

Mean Variance Optimization

Investment professionals use the results from correlation analysis when they perform mean variance optimization. Mean variance optimization (MVO), also known as mean optimization or mean variance analysis, is a quantitative modeling technique used to identify portfolio asset allocations that represent the most efficient portfolios. In MVO modeling, each potential mix of asset classes is an asset allocation scenario. MVO attempts to identify asset allocation scenarios that are projected to produce the maximum portfolio return for a given risk level; different risk levels are indicated by different levels of variability in portfolio returns. (Remember that Chapter 4 described how investment professionals use the variability of an asset’s returns to signify its level of risk. Also recall that standard deviation is a statistical measure of return variability and is used to represent risk.)

Important data inputs to an MVO model are the

  • Expected return for each asset class

  • Risk—as measured by the standard deviation of returns—for each asset class

  • Correlation coefficient of each potential pair of asset classes under consideration

The output from MVO modeling is a selection of several optimal asset allocation scenarios, called efficient portfolios. An efficient portfolio, also called an optimum portfolio, is a hypothetical portfolio that earns the highest expected return for a given level of risk. In other words, an efficient portfolio represents a theoretically ideal asset allocation at a specified level of portfolio risk.

MVO modeling generates a group of efficient portfolios to represent ideal allocations for a range of risk levels. Each efficient portfolio consists of a list of asset classes and proportions, along with projected portfolio returns for each asset class under each of several economic scenarios. Investment professionals analyze MVO modeling results to search for the best possible asset allocation scenario within established risk and return constraints.

 
The Efficient Frontier

When evaluating MVO-generated asset allocations, investment professionals use the efficient frontier, which is the set of all hypothetical portfolios having the greatest expected return, each for a specified level of risk. An MVO model applies a mathematical formula to calculate an efficient frontier showing the positions of all efficient portfolios consistent with the investor’s modeling constraints.

The efficient frontier is an upward-sloping curve that incorporates every efficient portfolio. Video 7.2 illustrates a sample efficient frontier with several efficient portfolios from which investment professionals can choose. For comparison, several inefficient portfolios are also illustrated.

One way to interpret the efficient frontier is as the visual representation of the risk-return trade-off, in the context of portfolio asset allocations. For each efficient portfolio on the efficient frontier, an investor cannot

  • Add assets to the portfolio to obtain a higher expected return without increasing portfolio risk

  • Reduce portfolio risk without decreasing the expected return

During portfolio construction, investment professionals use their judgment to pick the efficient portfolio most aligned with the investor’s objectives and constraints. The efficient portfolio’s asset allocations become the template for the investment portfolio’s SAA.

 
Limitations of MVO Modeling

While MVO modeling provides a useful framework for developing a portfolio’s SAA, the method does have some limitations. For example, MVO modeling depends on risk and return data inputs. Thus, one major limitation of MVO modeling is that small differences in the forecasts of risk and return for the asset classes can significantly affect the optimal asset allocation.

In addition, MVO incorporates assumptions that may not always be realistic. For instance, investment professionals typically base MVO calculations on historical returns. However, past investment results are not guaranteed to repeat in the future. In some circumstances, historical returns may be poor predictors of future asset class performance.

As another example, the theory behind many MVO models assumes that investment results are normally distributed. As you read in Chapter 4, some assets have historical return distributions that are nonnormal. Although beyond the scope of this text, more sophisticated MVO models add complexity to optimization analysis by allowing for nonnormal distributions of asset class returns.

Despite the limitations, MVO modeling helps investment professionals evaluate the potential outcomes of their asset allocation decisions. Knowing that modeling cannot accurately predict future portfolio performance, investment professionals exercise judgment in applying the insights gained from modeling activities such as MVO.

 

Monte Carlo Modeling

Before finalizing the SAA, investment professionals confirm their impressions of the results of MVO analysis by conducting additional modeling. One popular method of testing a potential SAA is Monte Carlo modeling. Monte Carlo modeling, also known as probabilistic modeling, is a form of modeling in which an automatic process (1) randomly assigns values to specified input data—thereby creating a large number of scenarios, (2) conducts numerous process iterations as needed, and (3) produces output data that can be described in the form of a probability distribution.

In Monte Carlo modeling, investment professionals assign input values that represent assumptions for a set of asset classes. Examples of asset class assumptions include estimated returns, standard deviations of returns, and correlation coefficients. During processing, the model uses these inputs to run potentially thousands of computer simulations under various economic scenarios. For each simulation, the model also randomly changes certain variables—such as U.S. Treasury yields, corporate bond rates, the inflation rate, and the economic growth rate.

After generating a large number of scenarios, the Monte Carlo model projects probable investment returns for each set of inputs over various time frames. Investment professionals use the model’s output to evaluate potential asset allocation scenarios. Thus, Monte Carlo modeling helps investment professionals

  • Determine the probability that a particular asset allocation will achieve the investor’s desired risk and return objectives over a given period

  • Identify which asset allocation would perform best over several years under certain economic conditions, such as a period of high inflation

Figure 7.3 presents a simplified example of outputs from Monte Carlo modeling.

Monte Carlo modeling has applications beyond investment portfolio analysis. For instance, life insurance companies also use Monte Carlo simulations to model product liabilities and satisfy regulatory requirements.

Selecting Portfolio Benchmarks

Once investment professionals have selected the asset classes and the SAA for a given portfolio, they select the portfolio’s benchmark, which they will use to evaluate the portfolio’s performance. To select a portfolio benchmark, investment professionals

  • Identify the appropriate benchmark for each asset class used in the portfolio

  • Create a blended benchmark that assigns weightings to asset class benchmarks according to the planned asset class mix

Generally, each actively traded asset class has at least one associated market index. Recall that a market index tracks the performance of a group of similar investments. Investment professionals use the market index associated with a particular asset class as a benchmark for its performance.

Using the asset class benchmarks, investment professionals create a blended benchmark for the entire portfolio. A blended benchmark comprises the asset class benchmarks in the proportion that each asset class will be held in a given portfolio. In other words, the asset class benchmarks are weighted according to the portfolio’s strategic asset allocation.

EXAMPLE

Suppose a portfolio manager plans a 60% allocation to stocks and a 40% allocation to bonds for a particular investment portfolio. The portfolio manager selects the S&P 500 Index as the benchmark for the portfolio’s stock asset class and the Barclays US Aggregate Bond Index as the benchmark for the bond asset class.

Analysis: The blended benchmark is a weighted combination of the asset class benchmarks. In this case, the portfolio’s blended benchmark is calculated as:

Blended benchmark = (0.60 x S&P 500 Index) + (0.40 x Barclays US Aggregate Bond Index)

By creating a blended benchmark, investment professionals have a more effective performance standard by which to measure a portfolio that holds several asset classes.

 

Selecting Assets for Each Asset Class

The final step in constructing an investment portfolio is purchasing individual assets for each asset class. Investment professionals purchase assets in specified proportions, according to the planned SAA. In investing, purchasing assets to fit a portfolio’s asset allocation is called positioning the portfolio.

To position a portfolio, the investment team identifies appropriate assets to represent each SAA asset class. The team ranks available assets in terms of their fit with the portfolio’s needs for various risks, returns, and other characteristics. Then the team purchases the assets that best meet the needs within each asset class. This process continues until all the asset classes are filled and the portfolio contains its initial array of asset holdings.

Typically, the factors that investment professionals use to identify, evaluate, and select individual assets depend on the type of asset being purchased. Later in the chapter, we provide an extended example to demonstrate a few factors for a couple of selected asset types.

Some selection factors are common to multiple asset types, as described in Chapters 2 and 3. Usually, a portfolio’s IPS provides guidelines regarding these factors. Some common factors are the asset’s sector and industry, ratings, liquidity, transaction costs, and environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors.

 

Sector and Industry

Investment professionals can group securities by the sector or industry of the issuer. For instance, investors could consider common stocks issued by companies in the energy sector or corporate bonds issued by health care sector companies.

Investors can also further categorize securities by grouping them according to sub-sector or sub-industry. For example, investors could group all corporate bonds issued by companies in the beverages industry. Within the beverages industry, sub-industries could include brewery companies, distillery companies, and soft drink companies.

Depending on an investment team’s research, it may decide to increase or decrease exposure to certain sectors or industries within an asset class. For instance, if a team is optimistic about the earnings prospects of the information technology sector, it might select more securities from that sector to include in the portfolio’s equity holdings.

 

Ratings

As previously discussed, rating agencies provide assessments on the quality of individual securities, security issuers, and funds. Investment professionals may use these ratings to supplement their own research. Some institutions, such as insurance companies, are subject to regulations concerning ratings that affect the securities they can own. For instance, in the United States, state regulators may restrict life insurers from investing in bonds that do not achieve a specific SVO designation.

 

Liquidity

Another factor influencing the selection process is asset liquidity. For investors with short time horizons, holding a large number of illiquid assets in their portfolios would be inappropriate. Investors with long time horizons are less concerned with asset liquidity because they do not need to convert their portfolio holdings into cash in the near future.

 

Transaction Costs

The transaction costs associated with a particular asset or asset type are an important consideration during asset selection. Because these costs reduce the amount of money that investment professionals can invest, they strive to minimize these costs so that they can earn the best possible returns. For example, alternative investments have relatively high transaction costs, which limits their attractiveness to some investors.

 

Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) Factors

In Chapter 5, we introduced the concept of socially responsible investing (SRI). For institutional investors, SRI generally involves excluding certain types of investments based on a particular institution’s beliefs.

In recent years, investors have started applying SRI concepts to the analysis of potential investments by considering how companies perform on measures of sustainability and ethical behaviors. Environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors are a set of standards that screen potential investments based on a company’s practices regarding environmental, social, and governance issues. Figure 7.4 provides some examples of the kinds of criteria used in ESG screening.

Companies that score higher on ESG factors tend to be more conscientious about managing risks, increasing value for all stakeholders, and promoting long-term profitability. Academic research also suggests that these companies demonstrate stronger long-term financial performance than companies with lower scores on the same factors.

Institutional investors are placing a higher priority on investing in companies that reflect the values of an institution’s constituents. Therefore, more investment professionals are considering ESG factors—in addition to the traditional financial metrics—to identify the best investments for institutional portfolios.

pages.contents:
Hypothetical Security Evaluation and Selection Scenarios

Investors can use many kinds of criteria to evaluate assets, but many of them are asset-specific. This text does not discuss every possible criterion. Instead, we present a hypothetical portfolio and discuss how one portfolio manager might pick individual assets for certain asset classes. In each section, we present some of the criteria that investment professionals may use while evaluating and selecting an asset to represent a particular asset class. Although our examples are relatively simple, the decision-making process can be much more complex.

Tia Ingram, a portfolio manager for Dexicos Life Insurance Company, is selecting assets for a new investment portfolio supporting general account products. The portfolio’s strategic asset allocation will be as follows:

Asset Type

Portfolio Allocation

Corporate Bonds

40%

U.S. Treasury Bonds

15%

Mortgages

10%

Structured Securities

10%

Alternative Investments

10%

Common Stocks

5%

Real Estate

5%

Derivatives

3%

Cash

2%

Total

100%

For each asset type, Tia’s investment team has performed research and identified potential investments. Based on the information that her investment analysts provide, Tia needs to select the assets that will position the portfolio to meet the company’s risk and return objectives.

In the following sections, Tia selects one corporate bond and one common stock using information that her analysts provide. While we describe Tia’s process for selecting two assets, note that she needs to select several assets to complete the portfolio’s construction. The order in which she selects assets could affect her selection criteria for subsequent assets. However, for simplicity, assume that her corporate bond selection does not affect her common stock selection, and vice versa.

 

Selecting a Corporate Bond

Tia needs to select a corporate bond that has approximately 30 years until maturity and an investment-grade credit rating. Tia’s analysts have provided the following information for three potential choices:

Criteria

Bond A

Bond B

Bond C

Term to Maturity

24 years

25 years

28 years

Yield to Maturity (YTM)

5.15%

3.92%

6.87%

Duration

7.6 years

8.1 years

9.25 years

Credit Ratings

A / A / NAIC1

Aa / AA / NAIC1

Baa / BBB / NAIC2

Tia wants to choose the bond with the best combination of a long term to maturity, high yield to maturity, low duration, and high credit ratings. She evaluates the three bonds against her desired characteristics.

All three bonds have similar term-to-maturity length, although Bond C has the longest. While Bond C has the highest YTM, it also has the highest duration and lowest credit ratings, so Tia eliminates Bond C as a possibility.

Bond A has a higher YTM and lower duration than Bond B. While Bond B has a slightly better set of credit ratings, both sets of ratings are strong. Because Bond A is the best match with Tia’s criteria, she selects it and instructs her team’s trader to purchase it for the portfolio.

 

Selecting a Common Stock

Tia needs to select a large-cap common stock that pays a dividend. The market capitalization, or market cap, is the total market value of all of a company’s outstanding shares of stock, which is calculated by multiplying the number of outstanding shares by the price per share. Typically, investors classify stocks as small-cap, mid-cap, or large-cap, depending on the issuing company’s market capitalization.

Tia’s investment team has researched several potential large-cap common stocks to evaluate the profitability and growth prospects of the issuing companies. To aid in analysis, the team used profitability ratios, which are financial ratios that measure a company’s profitability by comparing the company’s gain from operations to the resources employed or invested to earn the gain.

One commonly used profitability ratio is earnings per share (EPS), which is the portion of a company’s net profit after taxes that is attributable to each outstanding share of the company’s common stock. Higher EPS values indicate greater profitability. Investors calculate EPS according to the following formula:

Earnings per share (EPS) = Net profit after taxes
Number of outstanding common stock shares

For each stock issuer, Tia’s team also studied the company’s leverage, which—in the context of corporate finance—is a measure of the amount of debt a company is using to support its operations. If a company has too much leverage, it may not be able to keep up with the interest payments on its debt. Therefore, investment professionals use different leverage ratios to measure financial risk. A leverage ratio is a comparison of values that represent (1) the amount of a company’s debt obligations and (2) its ability to meet those obligations.

Tia’s team narrowed the list of large-cap common stocks to three possible choices. Tia requested information on each stock’s historical returns and standard deviations over the past 10 years. In addition, she requested each stock’s dividend yield, which is the ratio of a company’s annual dividend payments to its current market price. A stock’s dividend yield indicates the annual percentage return earned by the dividends paid on a share of stock. Investors calculate dividend yield as follows:

Dividend yield = Annual dividend amount paid per share
Market price per share

When market interest rates are low, stocks that have a high dividend yield can be an attractive investment alternative to debt securities, especially for investors seeking current income. Potential investors can compare a stock’s dividend yield to the market interest rate on a debt security to help determine which investment will likely provide the higher income yield.

Tia doesn’t want to pay too much for a stock with the desired risk and return characteristics, so she also wants to review some valuation ratios. A valuation ratio compares a share’s market price to another measure of a company’s ability to generate value for shareholders. Investment professionals use several types of valuation ratios to evaluate whether a particular stock’s shares are overvalued or undervalued.

One of the most common valuation ratios used in stock analysis is the price/earnings (P/E) ratio, which compares a stock’s market price per share to its earnings per share. The formula for the P/E ratio is:

Price/earnings (P/E) ratio = Market price per share
Earnings per share (EPS)

Investment professionals use the P/E ratio to determine if the market share price is reasonable relative to the earnings of the company. A stock may be overpriced if it has a high P/E value relative to the stocks of other companies in the same industry. Conversely, a stock with a relatively low P/E value may be a good value.

pages.title: Fund Evaluation and Selection
pages.contents:
Fund Evaluation and Selection

In the previous section, you read about some of the ways that investment professionals can select investments for portfolios that support life insurer general account products. For separate account portfolios, insurance companies do not select investments on behalf of their customers. Instead, they are responsible for offering a menu of investment fund options called subaccounts, as we defined in Chapter 1. An insurer’s investment function evaluates and selects the subaccounts offered to separate account customers.

Traditionally, insurers structured subaccounts to operate like mutual funds. In recent years, as exchange-traded fund (ETF) use has generally increased, insurance companies are offering more subaccounts that are structured like ETFs. Because of operational differences, ETFs generally have lower costs than mutual funds that hold a similar group of securities.

An insurer’s subaccount menu can include both internally managed and externally managed fund options. The fund managers of external fund options are known as subadvisors. Typically, insurance companies enter into agreements with subadvisors to increase the number of investment options available to separate account customers. In many cases, a subadvised subaccount is managed to be nearly identical to a fund that the subadvisor offers its customers.

Subaccounts: Not Exactly the Funds They Mimic

Essentially, a subaccount is a clone of another fund. For instance, suppose Dexicos Life Insurance Company offers a subaccount based on Algravita Fund Company’s VITA 60/40 Fund. The subaccount is called Dexicos VITA 60/40 Fund to signify that it is a separate offering from the fund that Algravita, the subadvisor, offers to its customers.

Because of structural aspects that are beyond the scope of this text, a subaccount may experience slight differences in fees and performance when compared to the fund it is based on. Therefore, the historical performance of a subaccount is reported separately from that of the fund it mimics. For investors, such differences can complicate efforts to evaluate a subaccount and compare it to its peers.

Insurance companies want to ensure that their current subaccount menus meet the objectives of their separate accounts. Thus, investment professionals are continually evaluating their company’s collection of subaccounts as well as other funds that are potential candidates for inclusion in their offerings. The investment team can make recommendations for adding new subaccounts and removing existing subaccounts that no longer meet the company’s needs. Typically, subaccount recommendations are supported by due diligence and must comply with regulatory standards.

Insurers set corporate policies to guide decisions about their subaccount menus. Such policies set constraints on the menu of fund options and their internal and external administration. These constraints typically address

  • The assortment of proposed fund categories

  • Number of funds permitted in each category

  • Procedures for approving and removing fund options

  • Operational controls and limitations

EXAMPLE

Sample Policy Constraint on External Fund Options

To be considered for inclusion in the subaccount menu, an externally managed fund must have existed for a minimum of three years and hold assets in excess of $100 million. In addition, the fund must maintain a consistent management philosophy, as indicated by adherence to the fund style outlined in its prospectus.

Investment professionals evaluate a variety of factors to evaluate and select fund options for their subaccount menus. Some factors, such as historical returns and return volatility, have been covered in previous chapters. Other notable factors are the fund’s classification, investment style, management team, expense ratio, ratings, and comparison to fund peers.

 

Fund Classifications and Investment Styles

Financial services companies have many options for classifying mutual funds and ETFs. In addition, some fund providers include multiple classifications in one name.

EXAMPLE

Dexicos Investment Management offers a mutual fund called Dexicos International Large-Cap Growth Fund. The fund invests internationally in equities with a large market capitalization and a growth orientation.

Investment professionals usually classify funds according to observable characteristics. Some characteristics are subjective, so classifications can be somewhat arbitrary. Notable methods of fund classification include

  • Asset class

  • Management approach

  • Investment style

  • Market capitalization

  • Asset allocation

  • Geography

  • Sector

In fund investing, style boxes graphically represent fund information. Investors can use style boxes to quickly recognize a fund’s classification. We discuss style boxes later in this chapter.

 

Asset Class

Funds can be classified by asset classes and sub-asset classes. Three common classifications by asset class are equity, fixed-income, and absolute return:

  • The assets of equity funds, also called stock funds, typically consist of common stocks, but may also include preferred stocks or real estate. Equity funds are often categorized by market cap, industry sector, and/or geographic location. The fund in the previous example, the Dexicos International Large-Cap Growth Fund, is an equity fund.

  • Fixed-income funds typically consist of specified debt instruments and are categorized by the specified type of debt instrument. Further classifications include (1) type of debt instrument held, (2) average term to maturity of held assets, (3) credit quality, and (4) geographic location. For example, a fixed-income fund may be categorized as a government bond fund, a long-term bond fund, or an investment-grade bond fund. A multisector bond fund invests in bonds from several fixed-income sectors—including U.S. government obligations, U.S. corporate bonds, foreign bonds, and high-yield U.S. debt securities.

  • Absolute return funds seek to achieve positive returns in all market conditions by investing in a variety of asset classes—including alternative investments and derivatives—and employing alternative investment management techniques.

 

Management Approach

Depending on the management approach of the fund managers, investors can broadly categorize a fund as

  • Active. In the context of fund investing, an active management strategy attempts to outperform the average market return earned by fund peers. However, an active management strategy risks underperforming the average market return.

  • Passive. In the context of fund investing, a passive management strategy attempts to earn the average market return that fund peers earn. Compared to active management, passive management typically involves longer holding periods and less frequent trading, which results in lower transaction costs. Because a passive management strategy is characterized by a low portfolio turnover rate, it is also known as a buy-and-hold strategy. The portfolio turnover rate is the rate at which the fund buys or sells securities, expressed as a percentage of average total assets.

The differences in the active and passive management approaches can be seen in the way that a fund manager treats portfolio holdings. For instance, an active manager may trade a bond before maturity if the bond’s current price is above par value. In contrast, a passive manager usually intends to hold a bond to maturity. Note that in both cases, the fund manager is constantly monitoring the bond holding; a passive management strategy does not mean that the fund manager ignores the bond until maturity.

Typically, investors judge actively and passively managed funds against market indexes. In addition, many passively managed funds are constructed to replicate indexes. Such funds, called index funds, seek to produce a pattern of performance similar to that of a specified market index.

EXAMPLE

The Dexicos S&P 500 Index Fund is a mutual fund that invests in stocks in the S&P 500 Index. The fund is constructed to closely track the index’s returns. Thus, fund investors earn roughly the same rate of return as the S&P 500 Index.

 

Investment Style

One of the most common fund classifications is by investment style. For example, investors typically divide equity funds into

  • Growth funds, which invest in stocks of companies with the potential for above-average growth, resulting in capital appreciation. Growth stocks typically have high P/E ratio values and pay little or no dividends.

  • Value funds, which invest in stocks of companies that are undervalued in relation to the overall market and that often pay significant dividends. Value stocks are generally associated with patient investors who will wait for a stock’s market price to rise to the value they believe it deserves. Compared to growth funds, value funds usually have lower price volatility. In addition, value funds tend to outperform growth funds during economic recessions. On the other hand, growth funds usually outperform value funds during periods of economic expansion.

  • Core funds, or blend funds, are a type of fund that seeks growth and value stocks. Some fund providers also use the term “core fund” to indicate funds that can invest in both stocks and bonds.

Other fund styles are designed to achieve a certain objective. For instance, income fundsare dedicated to earning a reliable income stream from investments that provide interest, dividend payments, or rent. Stable value funds are conservative funds that focus on capital preservation and offer a guaranteed minimum rate of return plus the potential for excess interest crediting. The following chart summarizes the fund styles mentioned above.

Fund Style

Typical Investments

Growth fund

Stocks with above-average growth potential

Value fund

Stocks that are undervalued by the market

Core fund

A blend of growth and value stocks

Income fund

Assets that generate reliable income streams

Stable value fund

Safe assets that will conserve investor capital
 

Market Capitalization

Funds, particularly equity funds, can be categorized by the size of the companies they invest in:

  • Small-cap funds invest in companies with a small market capitalization—for example, less than $2 billion.

  • Mid-cap funds invest in companies with a medium market capitalization—for example, $2 billion to $10 billion.

  • Large-cap funds invest in companies with a large market capitalization—for example, greater than $10 billion.

The exact amounts for each capitalization level are not universally recognized. In addition, some investors recognize additional market cap sizes. For instance, some consider micro-cap stocks to have capitalizations below $300 million and mega-cap stocks to have capitalizations above $100 billion.

 

Asset Allocation

Some funds are categorized according to the asset allocation they maintain. Each asset allocation category tailors the fund’s asset allocation to a certain level of risk tolerance.

A lifestyle fund, also known as an asset allocation fund or risk-based fund, has the objective of maintaining a specific level of risk at all times. The three main types of lifestyle funds are

  • Aggressive allocation funds, designed for investors with high risk tolerances

  • Moderate allocation funds, designed for investors with moderate risk tolerances

  • Conservative allocation funds, designed for investors with low risk tolerances

While lifestyle funds generally maintain a specific risk level, other funds adjust their allocations in anticipation of steady changes in an investor’s risk tolerance. Target-date funds, also known as lifecycle funds, invest in various asset classes and automatically change the asset allocation over a period of time. Typically, a target-date fund is designed with an end date in mind. The main objective of a target-date fund is to support an investor’s goal of accumulating a certain amount of money by the specified date.

Initially, a target-date fund has a relatively aggressive allocation—for example, the fund might hold a high percentage of equity investments. As the fund’s target date approaches, the fund’s allocation gradually becomes more conservative and its risk level gradually decreases. Because of the feature that automatically shifts allocations over time, target-date funds are popular in the retirement services industry.

 

Geography

Funds that invest in securities issued by companies with international operations are classified according to the country or region in which those companies are located. For instance,

  • Global funds, also known as world funds, invest in companies located both in the investor’s home country and beyond; for a U.S. investor, global funds can include companies located in the United States and outside of the United States

  • International funds, also known as foreign funds, invest exclusively in companies located outside of the investor’s home country; for a U.S. investor, international funds exclude companies located in the United States but can include companies located anywhere else

  • Regional funds invest in companies located in only a particular geographic region—such as Europe, Asia, or Latin America

  • Country funds invest in companies located in one particular country

  • Emerging market funds invest in companies located in developing countries, which are typically countries with low levels of income per citizen and little industrialization

 

Sector

Sector funds invest in companies in a particular sector or industry. Common types of sector funds include communications funds, energy funds, financial services funds, health care funds, and technology funds. Sector funds provide less diversification than other types of funds but can generate higher returns when the particular sector performs well.

 

Style Boxes

Morningstar, a company that provides investment research services, popularized the use of style boxes in its fund ratings. The Morningstar Style Box is a nine-square grid that provides a graphical representation of a fund’s investment style. The appropriate box on the grid is blackened or checked to provide a quick visual cue as to the fund’s basic style classification. Figure 7.5 illustrates typical equity and fixed-income style boxes.

 

Management Team

Investment professionals look at a fund’s management team to evaluate whether its managers can achieve the fund’s objectives. Examples of questions that investment professionals may ask during fund analysis include

  • Does the management team have a well-developed, consistent investment process?

  • How closely does the management team adhere to the fund’s stated style?

  • Does the management team’s style result in excessive portfolio turnover?

  • Do the managers invest their personal money in this fund?

  • How many years has the current management team managed this fund?

  • Has the fund changed managers at any point in the last several years?

Investment professionals may have the opportunity to interview key management team members. In this case, the investment professionals hope to learn more about the management team’s decision-making process. They also investigate a fund manager’s administrative support systems, operations, procedures, and personnel. In particular, they examine the fund’s

  • Methods of pricing securities and creating daily fund values

  • Trading systems and practices

  • Accounting, recordkeeping, and financial reporting systems

  • Internal risk management framework

  • Ethics policy

  • Regulatory compliance function

 

Expense Ratios

Investment professionals also look at a fund’s expense ratio, which expresses the fund’s total annual operating expenses during a given period as a percentage of the fund’s average net assets during the same period. Fund operating expenses can include expenses related to auditing, accounting and other recordkeeping, taxes, custody services, paying the fund managers, and marketing.

Because expenses reduce the potential returns for fund investors, investment professionals generally prefer funds with low expense ratios. Investment professionals often compare a particular fund’s expense ratio to those of other funds in its peer group. A peer group is a collection of funds that have the same style, share similar risk characteristics, and are competitors within their market niche.

In general, actively managed funds have higher expense ratios than passively managed funds. Actively managed funds charge higher management fees to compensate for the additional resources used in pursuit of market outperformance. In contrast, passively managed funds generally charge lower management fees because they simply attempt to earn the average market return.

 

Fund Ratings

Institutions may not rely solely on their own investment team’s findings for fund analysis. External fund advisory services provide ratings, research, and commentary for fund investors. Thus, investment professionals can review external fund ratings to supplement their own research and analysis.

For some institutional investors—such as insurance companies—incorporating external ratings is part of responsible due diligence when offering funds as investment options for customers. In addition, using external fund ratings helps institutions avoid the appearance of conflict of interest in analyzing the funds that they offer to customers. For instance, an insurance company that also serves as a fund provider could appear to favor internally managed funds in its subaccount menu. However, by using independent fund analysis to support its subaccount selections, the insurer can maintain the appearance of impartiality.

 

Fund Comparisons

Investment professionals typically compare a fund’s performance to the performance of a benchmark index, such as a market index. They also compare the total returns of a particular fund to the total returns of other funds in the same peer group.

Through these comparisons, investment professionals can evaluate a fund’s relative performance. Investment professionals generally prefer funds that consistently outperform the benchmark and most of the peer group over a period long enough to represent varying market conditions—such as a 10-year period.

One tool that investment professionals use to support fund comparisons is a scorecard, which is a table or worksheet used for analyzing or comparing various funds. Investment professionals use a scorecard as part of identifying fund option candidates, as well as for ongoing monitoring of a company’s menu of fund options. Figure 7.6 presents an example of a scorecard.

Scorecards grade a group of funds on a set of measures, such as the expense ratio or 5-year return. For each criterion, funds are ranked from best to worst based on their score. Some scorecards assign funds a numerical ranking, while others assign a letter grade or multiple stars.

Scoring and ranking of funds can indicate the quality of a particular fund compared to its peer group and benchmark. In addition, some scorecards calculate the average score for all funds in a peer group, and then group them into percentiles or quartiles.

Investment professionals can use scorecards to screen new funds for possible inclusion in a company’s menu of fund options. The relative rankings can quickly identify funds that are unsuitable for inclusion.

Chapter 7 covers constructing the portfolio. Steps include determiningthe portfolio’s objectives and constraints; identifying, analyzing, andselecting the appropriate asset classes; setting the strategic asset allocation;developing a blended benchmark as a performance standard; and analyzing,selecting, and purchasing initial investments within each asset class.

pages.contents:
Objectives

After studying this chapter, you should be able to

  • 8 A Describe diversification and hedging and explain how institutional investors can use each strategy to manage specific risks in portfolios
  • 8 B Compare and contrast the security selection strategies of (1) value and growth investing and (2) bottom-up and top-down investing
  • 8 C Explain how portfolio managers use tactical asset allocation (TAA) to enhance portfolio returns
  • 8 D Describe the market timing strategies of momentum investing and contrarian investing
  • 8 E Describe the buy-and-hold, laddering, and barbell strategies for managing a portfolio’s bond investments
  • 8 F Explain how bond traders use yield spreads to evaluate and compare individual bonds

pages.title: Strategies for Managing Specific Risks
pages.contents:
Strategies for Managing Specific Risks

In Chapter 4, we discussed the risks associated with investing and specifically about the two types of risks:

  • Systematic risks, which are nondiversifiable and can affect every investment in a given market

  • Specific risks, which are diversifiable and only affect certain investments in a given market

For investors, systematic risks are unavoidable. To have the opportunity to earn investment returns, investors have to accept exposure to certain market risks, such as interest-rate changes or inflation. Thus, portfolio managers focus their risk management efforts on the types of risks they can control—the specific risks within a particular portfolio.

A portfolio manager can apply diversification and hedging strategies to reduce a portfolio’s overall risk. As you learned in Chapter 2,

  • Diversification spreads out risk by investing in a variety of assets with different risk characteristics

  • Hedging balances one risk with a complementary risk that will ideally offset the original risk

 

Diversification

Typically, the primary way to diversify a portfolio is by including multiple asset classes—ideally, asset classes with negative correlations to the other classes in the portfolio. In the last chapter, we explained how asset allocation incorporates diversification among asset classes. We also mentioned that investment professionals can further diversify a portfolio by investing among various sub-asset classes within an asset class.

In addition to asset class diversification, investment professionals can diversify portfolios in many other ways. For instance, they can diversify a portfolio’s investments through different

  • Investment vehicles—such as splitting a bond allocation between individual bonds and bond exchange traded funds (ETFs)

  • Investment styles—such as holding both growth and value stocks

  • Sectors or industries—such as holding corporate bonds from the industrial, financial, and health care sectors

  • Income streams—such as holding assets that generate interest income, dividend income, and rental income

  • Market caps—such as holding small-cap and large-cap stocks

  • Maturities—such as holding short-term, intermediate-term, and long-term bonds

  • Geographic regions—such as holding securities issued in North America, Europe, Africa, and Asia

Regardless of the manner of diversifying, the goal is the same: to include investments that reduce a portfolio’s exposure to the specific risks related to its existing investments. You’ve heard the adage “Don’t put all your eggs in one basket.” Diversification places portfolio investments in multiple “baskets,” or asset categories, so the portfolio is less dependent on the success of any one basket. In other words, diversification reduces the portfolio’s asset concentration risk, which is the risk that results when investments are concentrated excessively in any single category.

EXAMPLE

Laurie Bordeaux is a portfolio manager for an institutional investor that is building an investment portfolio of Canadian real estate properties. The portfolio currently owns one property, a multifamily residential property in Vancouver. Because the real estate portfolio consists of one property, it is entirely dependent on that property’s value. Thus, the portfolio’s risk is concentrated.

Analysis: The portfolio’s real estate property could lose value for a variety of reasons—damage from a fire or flood, increased competition from a new apartment complex built nearby, or a broad downturn in the Vancouver economy. To diversify the portfolio, Laurie could purchase properties with different characteristics—such as residential properties in different sizes, styles, and locations. To further diversify, Laurie could purchase nonresidential properties outside of Vancouver. For example, she could purchase an office building in Montreal or an agricultural property near Winnipeg.

Diversification is a long-term portfolio management strategy. Over time, proper diversification reduces specific risks so that the majority of the portfolio’s remaining risk is made up of systematic risk. Figure 8.1 illustrates this concept.

 

Hedging

An investor can use a hedge to protect against an adverse outcome that results in a financial loss. An effective hedge balances out an investment loss with an increase in the hedge’s value. By counterbalancing a potential loss, a hedge works to reduce a portfolio’s overall risk.

In practice, however, an investment professional may have a difficult time creating a hedge that perfectly offsets a potential loss. Therefore, hedging is generally an investment risk reduction strategy, not a risk elimination strategy.

In contrast to diversification, hedging is a short-term portfolio management strategy. Investment professionals use hedges to offset adverse price movements in their investments within given periods. After a period of time, a hedge may lose its effectiveness, requiring additional action.

Investment professionals use hedges to protect against specific risks—such as currency risk or interest-rate risk. As introduced in Chapter 4, currency risk arises from changes in currency exchange rates, and interest-rate risk arises from changes in market interest rates. Such changes could cause particular investments in a portfolio to lose value. Thus, hedging those investments reduces the potential loss for the investor.

Derivatives are one of the popular investment vehicles for creating hedges. As we mentioned in Chapter 3, derivatives derive their values from underlying assets. For example, the value of a particular put option on a common stock depends on the fluctuating market price of the stock’s shares. Because of the relationship between a derivative and its underlying asset, an investment professional can position a derivative to gain in value as the underlying asset loses value, thus reducing the effect of the underlying asset’s lost value.

EXAMPLE

An investor, Helen Flynn, holds shares of a stock and a put option on the same stock. The put option gives Helen the right to sell shares at the strike price until the option expires.

Analysis: If the price of Helen’s stock shares falls below the strike price, then exercising the option will limit her loss. Note that as the stock price falls further below the strike price, the put option becomes more valuable to the option holder—which, in this case, is Helen.

Derivative values can also be based on other financial market values, such as exchange rates or interest rates. For instance, an interest-rate swap between two parties exchanges the cash flows based on a fixed interest rate with the cash flows based on a variable, or floating, interest rate. Because the assets and liabilities of life insurance companies are sensitive to interest-rate fluctuations, many insurers use interest-rate swaps to hedge interest-rate risk.

EXAMPLE

Dexicos Life Insurance Company wants to hedge against the risk of falling market interest rates. Specifically, Dexicos wants to ensure that it can receive a fixed stream of cash flows even as it reinvests money from maturing bonds into bonds with lower coupon rates. Therefore, Dexicos enters into an interest-rate swap agreement with Palance Bank based on a specified principal amount.

Analysis: Dexicos holds a bond with a floating coupon rate that is pegged to changes in the Treasury bill rate. Dexicos pays Palance the interest payments that Dexicos receives from this bond. Meanwhile, Palance pays Dexicos the interest payments it receives from a long-term bond it holds that has a fixed coupon rate. Because Palance’s long-term bond pays a consistent interest rate, the interest payments are a steady stream of cash that Palance is paying to Dexicos. Dexicos uses the payments to ensure that it can match its asset and liability cash flows, thus hedging against the risk of falling interest rates.

Traditionally, derivatives were the primary instruments for hedging a portfolio’s investments. However, as ETF offerings grow more diverse, some sophisticated ETFs allow investors to hedge against specific risks, such as interest-rate risk or currency risk. Because ETFs are generally cheaper and more liquid than derivatives, ETFs are appealing options for institutional investors looking to create hedges in their portfolios.
